DEBATE.TITLE: BANKING (QUEENSLAND INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 2 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to bring the Queensland Industry Development Corporation, QIDC, under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. QIDC is a financial institution which is wholly owned by the Queensland government and which undertakes commercial lending to primary, secondary and tertiary industry within the state of Queensland. While in recent years it has sought to adhere to Reserve Bank standards, QIDC has not been formally supervised by the Reserve Bank.

PARA.TAB: The Queensland government has recently corporatised QIDC and as part of this exercise is seeking to enhance the accountability of QIDC by enabling it to be brought under Reserve Bank supervision. This bill amends the Banking Act 1959 to bring QIDC under Reserve Bank prudential supervision. To this end, the Queensland government has recently referred its banking powers, with respect to QIDC, to the Commonwealth. Specifically, this bill includes QIDC within the definition of a bank in section 5 of the Banking Act 1959, thereby establishing a legislative basis for Reserve Bank supervision of QIDC. This will ensure that QIDC follows Reserve Bank requirements and is subject to the supervision of the Reserve Bank in relation to prudential matters.

The Commonwealth government endorses Reserve Bank supervision of QIDC. As a substantial commercial lender, QIDC effectively operates as a business bank and its formal supervision by the Reserve Bank is entirely appropriate. Such supervision will help to ensure that QIDC remains financially sound and, accordingly, will help to underpin the security of the financial sector more generally.
I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains a more detailed explanation of the provisions of the bill. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has indicated, this bill is before the House because the Queensland government has sought to enhance the accountability of the Queensland Industry Development Corporation by enabling it to be brought under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. That is being facilitated in the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill by listing the QIDC under the definition in section 5 of the Banking Act 1959. This establishes a legislative basis for the Reserve Bank supervision of the QIDC.

PARA.TAB: The bill includes provisions complementary to Queensland legislation, under which the Queensland government transferred its constitutional banking power, as it relates specifically to the QIDC, to the Commonwealth government. The purpose of this measure is to ensure that QIDC follows the requirements of, and is subject to, the supervision of the Reserve Bank in relation to prudential matters.

I indicate that the coalition does not oppose this legislation. However, there are two or three concerns which I wish to raise in the House. The first matter I wish to raise is the provision of prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank itself. If it is expected, or told to Queensland people, that this somehow provides a degree of insurance or immunity for the activities of the QIDC, then one only needs to look at the report of the Reserve Bank itself to illustrate that that is a limited immunity or a limited insurance which is provided. For example, the Reserve Bank stated in its annual report for the year ending 30 June 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: Prudential supervision does not have as an objective the immunisation of banks from the risk of loss.
The report went on to say:
Managers and shareholders should factor the inevitability of the economic cycle into their decision-making, and they must pay the price for errors of judgment and carelessness.

In his remarks to the Queensland parliament, the Queensland Treasurer, Mr De Lacy, pointed to Reserve Bank supervision as an insurance against loss by taxpayers. To suggest that somehow prudential supervision will, by itself, provide an insurance policy against any loss that could be incurred by the QIDC as a bank and an insurance against loss by Queensland taxpayers is somewhat misleading. One has only to look at what happened to banks in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia to see that the ultimate insurance for such activities is not the Reserve Bank through its prudential supervision but, in fact, the taxpayers, the constituents, of those states themselves.

PARA.TAB: The second matter I wish to raise is the activities of the bank and what seemed to be suggested to the people of Queensland that the QIDC would be able to do. If honourable members look at the explanation of the Queensland QIDC bill, they will see that the Treasurer of Queensland, Mr De Lacy, told the Queensland parliament that the QIDC would not be able to call itself a bank because:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is not able to fully perform as a bank in that it cannot provide retail banking facilities or provide finance for what are essentially owner-occupied homes.
He went on to say:

Although QIDC would gain the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank, the State legislation precludes the Commonwealth of Australia from requiring QIDC to possess a banking authority to carry out the business of banking.
The Queensland Treasurer summed up by saying:
This option means that although QIDC is defined as a `bank' under the Banking Act 1959—
that is, the Commonwealth act—
it is not authorised to operate as a bank in the wider sense because it does not have a banking authority.

This bank, if one looks at the speech that has just been made by the Assistant Treasurer, is able to carry out a whole range of banking activities. I quote the Assistant Treasurer's remarks prior to mine in this chamber today:
QIDC is a financial institution which is wholly owned by the Queensland government and which undertakes commercial lending to primary, secondary and tertiary industry within the state of Queensland.

There is no restriction on the activities of the QIDC and as a bank it can carry out a full range of banking functions. So for Mr De Lacy to indicate to the people of Queensland that somehow prudential supervision and the passage of this legislation and the complementary legislation in the Queensland parliament are going to restrict the activities of the QIDC is simply misleading.

PARA.TAB: If one takes it further, the QIDC will, under the very provisions of this legislation, be able to entitle itself and call itself a bank in any other part of Australia. So anybody who would be seeking to invest or to have some operation in relation to the QIDC, for example a resident of New South Wales, Victoria or any of the other states, would for all intents and purposes and under the terms of this legislation be dealing with a bank constituted as such under the authority of this bill and the authority of the complementary bill in Queensland.

It was somewhat misleading for the Treasurer of Queensland to suggest to the Queensland parliament and to the people of Queensland that this would in some way restrict the activities of the QIDC. In fact, the passage of this very legislation has the opposite effect: it gives theQIDC a wide range of banking authority under the Commonwealth and under the legislation of Queensland as well.

The third matter I want to raise is what this means in terms of the direction of banking itself. It is interesting that in some respects this indicates that the Queensland government is moving in a direction which is opposite to that being taken by state governments elsewhere in Australia and, in relation to the proposal by the Commonwealth to sell its share in the Commonwealth Bank, opposite to that which the Commonwealth has taken. We see other states getting out of the business of banking. The Commonwealth is doing that in its budget proposals for the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Yet under the direction of the Goss government it seems to be moving through this legislation in the opposite direction, namely, by expanding the operation of the QIDC and turning it into a more fully fledged bank than it has operated as at present.

That is curious and intriguing because the Premier of Queensland has said in parliament that he did not resile from the position that `state governments should not be in the banking and insurance business'. Yet in an indirect way this does involve the state government of Queensland in the banking and insurance business. Whilst there is nothing to suggest that the activities of the QIDC are anything but carried out in the most professional and most competent manner, it is a curious matter that we have a different direction being taken here in relation to banking by a state than has been taken by the other states in Australia after the disastrous occurrences with banks such as Tricontinental and others, and different from the direction which is being taken by the Commonwealth in relation to the Commonwealth Bank itself. Apart from those concerns, the opposition will not be opposing this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill 1995, to talk about the purposes of the bill and to indicate my full support and the support of all Queensland members of this parliament for this legislation. As has been outlined by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), this is complementary legislation to similar legislation that was passed in the state parliament of Queensland some months ago.

PARA.TAB: The Queensland Industry Development Corporation commenced operations in July 1986. The main functions of the QIDC are the provision of financial services to Queensland industry and the administration in Queensland of certain federal and state business and rural assistance schemes, including the rural adjustment scheme, the natural disasters assistance scheme, the small business debt assistance scheme and the rural housing scheme. The QIDC provides a broad range of products, including development capital, interest rate swaps, bridging loans, mortgages, commercial bills and investment services. It is a very important institution for the economic welfare of Queensland and Queensland businesses.

As of 30 June 1994, the QIDC had net assets of $151.335 million and total operating revenue of $248.444 million. Government business enterprises in Queensland are currently undergoing a process of corporatisation. The reform and restructuring of the QIDC is a part of that process. It should be noted that the administration of the QIDC under the Goss Labor government is in marked contrast to the administration during its formative years under the National Party regime that we, thankfully, threw out of office on 2 December 1989.

The QIDC was a potential financial disaster when it was taken over by the Goss Labor government in December of 1989. If it had not been for the sound administration that came in on 2 December 1989 and the very sound administration by the Goss Labor government of the QIDC, the problems that were alluded to in terms of other state financial institutions could very well have been visited upon the QIDC.

Prior to the election of the Goss Labor government, the QIDC was a considerable risk to Queensland taxpayers because of the way in which the National Party administration had supervised its operations. It had used the QIDC as a slush bucket for its own cronyism and pork-barrelling. It was a breeding ground for the corruption and pork-barrelling that was endemic in the National Party administration prior to 1989.

If it were not for the election of the Goss Labor government, there would have been a major financial disaster, and Queensland taxpayers would have been responsible for paying for it. Thankfully, the Labor government of Wayne Goss was elected on 2 December 1989, and sound financial administration was put into place—and I can verify those statements.

An independent review of QIDC was undertaken in 1990. It found substantial evidence of political interference by National Party members and ministers in the operation of the QIDC. That review identified cases of commercial conflict of interest with directors and staff; lack of proper board leadership; poor or no risk management systems; and examples of rorting of government assistance schemes. That is the track record of the previous National Party government's supervision of the QIDC.

I note that, according to today's speakers list, a number of my Queensland colleagues, particularly a number of my Queensland National Party colleagues, will be speaking on this bill. I am sure it is no coincidence. I am sure they are speaking on this bill today because they want to use the opportunity to try to engage in a bit of political doubletalk with regard to the Queensland state election. They are going to try to use the debate on this legislation to prop up their failing colleagues in the Queensland state election.

Let us have the facts on the record before we start hearing the distortions that I am sure some of my National Party colleagues will come out with. The fact is that an independent financial review of the administration of the QIDC by the previous National Party government proved, beyond doubt, that that National Party administration was guilty, in its operations of the QIDC, of using political interference. Members of the National Party used the taxpayers' funds which the QIDC had supervision of to pork-barrel their own electorates. They were also guilty of poor administration and poor management of the QIDC.

That will come as no surprise to the people of Queensland, because they saw that type of endemic problem within the administration of the previous National Party state government across all areas of administration in Queensland. This was the same National Party administration that saw five of its ministers convicted of and gaoled for various levels of corruption. We saw its former leader, its former Premier, tried for corruption and for contempt, and we saw the Queensland Police Commissioner and half of the senior members of the Queensland Police Service proven to be corrupt and on the take.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney should be brought back into the chamber. Once you are in the House you cannot leave the House for a quorum.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that National Party members do not like the truth being told in this parliament about their total maladministration and the fact that they were proven to be such a corrupt administration in Queensland. One of the very good examples of that was the way in which they administered the Queensland Industry Development Corporation. There was an independent financial review of the QIDC that clearly indicated that they used the funds of the QIDC for corruption and pork-barrelling of their own electorates. No phoney attempt by National Party members opposite to try to silence me by calling quorums is going to stop me emphasising the fact that the people of Queensland know the truth about the National Party—and there is no way they are going to put the National Party back into power so that it can get its grubby fingers back into taxpayers' money in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: It is absolute hypocrisy on the part of Queensland National Party members and Liberal Party members in this federal parliament to come in here and try to criticise the Goss government over this, because it was the Goss government that got the QIDC back into a sound financial position—and that is very much exemplified by this legislation. The Queensland government is seeking through this legislation to put prudent financial auditing requirements and prudent regulatory requirements in place so that the Reserve Bank is able to adequately supervise the operations of the QIDC. Interruptions from members of the National Party are not going to silence me. The members of the National Party should hang their heads in shame. What amazes me even more is that the Queensland Liberals are now back in bed with the Nationals. They are now in this unholy alliance called the coalition in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member will return to the matter before the House.

—I am speaking about that matter, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am talking about the fact that the Queensland Liberals and the Queensland Nationals have taken a position in regard to the QIDC of disagreeing in the state parliament with the Goss government's legislation on this matter, which is the complementary legislation to the legislation that we are debating here. It is very clearly an indication of their failures.

PARA.TAB: I am surprised that the Queensland Liberals are prepared to go back into coalition with the Queensland National Party and to seek votes from the people of Queensland to become the next government, when they know that there are still many members of the Queensland National Party who were members of the proven corrupt administration of the last National Party government. It must be of great surprise and disquiet to the former Queensland Liberal leader, Terry White, that today's Liberal Party in Queensland is prepared to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will speak to the bill. The chair has so ruled.

—I recognise that, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I am speaking about the position that the Queensland Liberals and the members of the Queensland National Party have taken in the state parliament on this complementary legislation that was carried in the state parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that under the Goss Labor government the QIDC is no longer going to be used as a political brown paper bag, which was the way it was used under the former National Party administration. Instead of being used as a slush fund for political favours for the rural and regional areas of certain National Party members, under the Goss Labor government the QIDC has now diversified its lending portfolio to include secondary and tertiary industries.

The QIDC is now a much broader investment portfolio bank, which is designed to support the depth of Queensland industries, and not just narrow sectional interests. That is why we have this legislation before us today. QIDC is a development corporation designed to benefit all Queenslanders and to benefit all Queensland industries, not just the narrow sectional interests that the National Party represented.

There is a very good example of that. Recently, on the border between my electorate and that of the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), a national relay service was established to assist deaf people and people with communication difficulties. That service was established with assistance from the QIDC, which saw it as not only a sound business enterprise, because QIDC would be paid for the phone calls that it is providing the relay service for, but also a major community service. The service will also receive $21 million of Commonwealth funding over the next three years—joint funding from the Department of Communications and the Arts and the Department of Human Services and Health.

It was the QIDC that gave that service a start, and that gave it the money to get under way. That national relay service is going to benefit deaf people and people with communication difficulties throughout Australia. It is funded by the QIDC. Such a loan would never have been possible under the former National Party administration because, to get any sort of money from the QIDC, it was then necessary to be a member of the National Party or a mate of the National Party. That no longer occurs because the QIDC is now on a sound financial footing.

The QIDC still has a very strong rural focus. Its lending to rural producers has been increased from $250 million to more than $1,000 million in 1995. So the QIDC still has that very strong rural focus, but it has also diversified and broadened its interests into a lot of other areas as well. The reason the legislation is before the House today is that the Reserve Bank of Australia has the power, under the Banking Act 1959, to supervise the prudential standards applicable to this bank, as it does with all other banks.

The honourable member for Menzies made some points in his address about the fact that by this legislation the QIDC can operate as a normal bank like every other bank registered under the charter. That is recognised, but it is not the intention of the government to go that way. The Queensland government has made it quite clear that it is not going to expand the role of the QIDC into a full state bank with all the normal operations a bank would have.

That is a clear political statement that the Queensland government has made. It believes the benefits to the people of Queensland, by bringing the QIDC under Reserve Bank supervision, is very important. Such an arrangement ensures that all taxpayers in Queensland will know that this bank is adequately and very carefully being supervised, that its operations are open to full public scrutiny and that there will be none of the slush fund and corrupt actions that were the hallmark of the previous National Party administration of the QIDC. That is not just me the politician talking, for the track record of corruption and misuse of QIDC funds was clearly outlined in an independent examination of the QIDC in 1990.

The move to RBA supervision has not been done by stealth. It is not some sort of secret deal. It is being made clear at all times that the QIDC would become technically a bank for the purposes of prudential supervision, but the government has made it clear that there is no intention to expand into that role. What is relevant is that the QIDC is now a prudentially sound financial institution which is free of corruption and political interference and is now subject to rigorous independent supervision.

The restructuring and the realignment of the QIDC is just one of many major achievements of the Goss Labor government which has a record second to none in Australia for financial management and prudent dealings with taxpayers' funds. The operation and supervision of the QIDC is just one example of the way in which the Goss Labor government has been extremely careful to ensure that the state of Queensland is well run and well administered.

There are many indicators to show, as independent market assessments from around the world have shown, that the Queensland state government and the Queensland financial situation is second to none. I will quote from the Natwest capital markets report of October 1994. The report was called `State of the states' and it said:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be hard to find a national or sub-national government anywhere in the world that has a superior financial position to Queensland.

This unique financial position has enabled businesses throughout Queensland to have a huge competitive advantage. While the other states use, on average, $25 in every $100 of their own source revenue in servicing their $75 billion debt load, Queensland actually earns net interest income.

PARA.TAB: We are net debt free in Queensland. Queensland has the lowest per capita tax collections of any state in Australia. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that in 1994-95 residents in other states were paying an average 37 per cent more in state taxes than the average paid by Queenslanders. Queensland is the only state to be net debt free.

The Goss government has completely eliminated the net debt of $4.2 billion that was inherited from the previous National Party government. Let there be no excuses such as, `That was all because of the sound policies of the previous National Party government.' When the Goss government was elected it had $4.2 billion of debt and now it is net debt free, and that is due to the sound administration of the Goss government. I commend the QIDC legislation to the House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to contribute to the debate on the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill. The QIDC, as we affectionately know it in Queensland, commenced operation in July 1986 under its new name. Prior to that it had a role as a development bank in Queensland. One of the great things about the QIDC is that it has always kept its base out there in rural Australia. As we have seen only recently, the major commercial banks are continuing to withdraw their presence in a physical sense from rural Australia, while the QIDC has been expanding its operations, particularly in rural Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The QIDC offers very important banking services to the people of rural Australia. In future, the void that is being created by the withdrawal of the major commercial banks from rural Queensland may be filled by banks such as the Queensland Industry Development Corporation. The main functions of the Queensland Industry Development Corporation are the provision of financial services to Queensland industries.

These include a broad range of products, such as development capital, interest rate swaps, bridging loans, mortgages, commercial bills and investment services. It is also responsible for the administration of Commonwealth and state business and rural assistance schemes. We all know of the situation out there in rural Australia, because of the high interest rates that are a legacy of the Labor administration here in Canberra. We know what those interest rates have meant to rural communities, not only to the farm sector but also to the small business sector right across this nation.

Amongst the schemes that the QIDC administers are the rural adjustment scheme, the natural disaster assistance scheme, the rural housing scheme and the small business debtor scheme. It is a bank that has a major role in rural Australia and in rural communities generally. The QIDC is not only a bank which lends to the agricultural sector, as did the former Agricultural Bank of Queensland, it now lends to a broader cross-section of the community and administers many schemes, both state and federal.

The purpose of this bill is to subject the QIDC, for the first time, to prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. These are the same standards which apply to banks, and relate to matters such as capital adequacy and prudential risk management of bank assets. This arrangement will be implemented by including the QIDC in the definition of a `bank' under the Commonwealth's Banking Act.

This bill is a stark reminder of the duplicity of the Goss government and why Queenslanders should not trust it with their future on July 15. On repeated occasions the Queensland Labor Party, both in and out of government, gave cast-iron guarantees that the traditional role of the QIDC would be respected, and that its prime purpose would be to promote the interests and development of Queensland. On repeated occasions the Premier has stated that the QIDC would not become a bank, with all the implications that this would carry for the bank's operations. Premier Goss gave these assurances as recently as last year, when introducing legislation complementary to that now before this House. He said that the QIDC would not become another bank.

However, the net result of declaring the QIDC a bank under section 5 of the Commonwealth's Banking Act, will be to give it a complete range of banking powers. The Premier's assurances obviously amount to nothing. Whilst this breach of firm undertakings is bad enough, the consequences for Queensland of the corporation's change of status could well be diabolical.

As a result of this legislation, this great Queensland institution will be subject to federal banking controls. The member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) was earlier referring to the corruption or the maladministration of the previous conservative administration in Queensland. He failed to tell the House that the Queensland government inherited a very well managed state. The finances were in excellent order, and the QIDC was a bank that was fulfilling a role. We only have to look at Labor administrations in Victoria and in South Australia to find that a bank under a Labor administration in Victoria cost the taxpayers $2 billion to bail out and in South Australia, notwithstanding the fact that it was under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank. The cost to the taxpayers was $2.2 billion. No such evidence of this sort of failure within a state controlled lending institution can be levelled at the former administration in Queensland. One can witness also the former administrations of Western Australia and Tasmania.

The member for Moreton berates the House with points about a previous administration which left Queensland in a great position. The Queensland Industry Development Corporation was not broke; it was not costing the taxpayers any money. In fact, as the member for Moreton said, the rating of Queensland for its financial performance ranks second to none. The Goss administration inherited that position; it did not build it. It is about time members on the other side of the House told the truth about where the great legacy that was handed to the Labor administration came from, something the people of Queensland know very well. We must also always remind members on the other side of the House that the Labor Party cannot be trusted to be in charge of money, particularly taxpayers' money.

Examples which will illustrate the cronyism and downright disregard for taxpayers' funds that have become the hallmark of Labor in power include the $170 million of fees to outside consultants hired by its departments to tell the departments what to do. Only recently we have seen a $10 million consultancy go to the advertising agency which ran the Labor Party advertising campaign in the last federal election, a $10 million consultancy to identify the best way to sell and float Qantas. Eighty-six million dollars of taxpayers' money has been given to the ALP for escalating rent on Labor's Centenary House, which is now occupied by the National Audit Office.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! I had to call on the last speaker to stay with the bill, and I repeat the request to the present speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I respect your ruling. I was merely going on from the failure of the State Bank in Victoria and the State Bank in South Australia to how the Labor Party misuses taxpayers' money when given control of it. However, I will come back to the bill before the House.

PARA.TAB: The Queensland Industry Development Corporation, as I said earlier, has a proud past and I hope it has a proud future in developing the state. One of the great visionary projects which have been promoted by independent commentators and investors recently has been the building of the great inland rail bridge between Brisbane and Melbourne via the inland towns of Goondiwindi and Moree, through Narrabri and the heart of the Murray-Darling Basin. Such a bridge could well mean the further development of value adding industries where 50 per cent of Australia's agricultural production comes from.

The QIDC could well play a role in the development of that visionary scheme, particularly through the provision of finance. Queensland and the port of Brisbane are so near to the great Murray-Darling basin river system where 50 per cent of Australia's agricultural production comes from. It is those sorts of projects which the QIDC and other development organisations could well look at as projects which would bring benefits not only to Queensland, to the people who live along that rail link, but also to the nation as a whole.

The Queensland Industry Development Corporation will now take on the status of a bank and have a wider role in rural Queensland, perhaps taking over the role of some of the major banks. That is a role which I commend to the bank. I only hope that it keeps up a presence in rural Australia. Perhaps it will find a niche under its new charter to be more of a bank out there when the major commercial banks leave rural Australia.

I hope that because it is going to become a bank with full prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank of Australia it does not go the way of our major commercial banks that are leaving rural Australia. I hope that it does not in turn, because of the decisions of economic rationalists that are made at a capital city level, withdraw its agencies from rural Queensland.

It is vitally important that it consider a service to the community in rural Queensland as well as attempt to broaden its base into more development opportunities by lending in areas beyond the rural and small business sector. I hope that the economic rationalists are not in there saying that it is not commercially sound to have these branch structures throughout rural Queensland. I hope that we do not see the QIDC going down the same path as did many of our major commercial banks that have removed their physical presence from rural Queensland. Whilst it is their right to make those commercial judgments and withdraw their physical presence from rural Queensland, I think there is a role for government to ensure that there are banking services provided to the people who live in rural Australia.

I want to touch on a comment made by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in relation to the Commonwealth Bank and what its privatisation and sale could mean. In answer to a question from the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) the other day whether free banking services would still be available under a fully privatised Commonwealth Bank to almost 4.5 million pensioners, students and veterans, the Treasurer failed to give an assurance to this House and to those people—those 4.5 million people, those low income families who bank now with the Commonwealth Bank and those who may have a housing loan—that they will continue to have free banking services once it is a fully commercial bank and there is no longer any ownership by the Commonwealth.

It is extremely important that we ensure that out there in rural Australia we still have banking facilities that are available not only to the business sector and the farm sector but also to people on low incomes—families, pensioners and veterans—so that they have access to banking services. It is one of the fundamental services that any community needs. It is not good enough to say that with modern technology you are going to be able to replace banks with plastic cards and electronic funds transfer and that this will be able to be a service that will be understood and be completely adequate for the people who live and work in rural and remote Queensland.

In conclusion, I trust that the QIDC, with its changed status as a result of this bill, will continue to develop and push its agencies and its branch level activities out into rural Queensland whilst at the same time it develops into a larger, more commercial bank in the activities of capital city lending and opportunities in the wider investment world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the previous speaker and shadow minister, the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), speak on the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill 1995, you would think that there were no problems with the QIDC when the Labor government came into power in Queensland in 1989. Nothing could be further from the truth. The reality is that in 1989 the Goss government was faced with a real problem, in that the QIDC presented a great risk to the taxpayers of Queensland at that time. If the situation had been allowed to continue, as happened in other states, the Queensland taxpayers would have been required to pick up the tab for years of National Party mismanagement of the QIDC.

PARA.TAB: The Goss government had to do something about that and in 1990 it got an independent academic, Mr John Polichronis, to undertake a report into the QIDC. The report that Mr Polichronis gave was damning of the previous National Party government and damning of its administration of the QIDC. It showed evidence of political interference in commercial matters under the National Party government. As well, it showed cases of commercial conflict of interest by the National Party appointed directors and staff of the board of the QIDC. It also gave evidence of lack of board leadership and abuse of schemes administered by the relevant division of the QIDC.

We should not be surprised about that, given the record of that government. That was the government that would not even introduce a public accounts committee into the parliament of Queensland. It would not even have parliamentary scrutiny of any government institutions. That was the government, as was said earlier, that operated by the brown paper bag. If you wanted to become a knight, that required a financial transaction with the previous National Party government. If you wanted a knighthood, you sent some money in a brown paper bag to Bjelke-Petersen House. That was the sort of financial transaction that was highlighted by the Fitzgerald royal commission. So that is the sort of government the people of Queensland had before 1989. That is the sort of government that was highlighted by the Fitzgerald royal commission and that is the sort of government that was highlighted by Mr Polichronis in his report on the QIDC. So, far from the picture that was painted by the shadow minister, who is at the table, the QIDC was in a mess. Not only that; potentially it was in the same situation as those other unfortunate financial institutions in the southern states.

But a Labor administration in Queensland saw the situation, picked up the report that I referred to and introduced reforms. One of the major reforms is before the House today, that is, bringing the QIDC under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. National Party members do not seem to like that. I can assure them they will not be in government after the middle of next month, but I suspect that they think they have a chance. They want to get their finger in the till again, so they do not want the QIDC to have prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's rubbish.

—The honourable member says that is rubbish. It is certainly the situation that after that report by Mr Polichronis in 1990 the Goss government acted to reform the QIDC. One of the reforms was the corporatisation of the QIDC. The second reform was to bring the QIDC under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank. There was an option of bringing the QIDC into the Queensland Office of Financial Supervision, but that institution looks more at smaller banks and building societies and it was considered more appropriate that the Reserve Bank be the supervisor.

PARA.TAB: It is very significant to note that the Goss government has led the way in terms of national reform of building societies and credit unions. The national financial institutions scheme is the model scheme for other states and territories and the Australian Financial Institutions Commission has its headquarters in Brisbane. So there is no doubt that there has been significant recognition of the Queensland government's achievement in this area. Queensland is widely recognised as having the strongest financial position of all the Australian states and, indeed, its financial position is unrivalled amongst its competitors in the Asia-Pacific region. The Natwest capital market report, State of the states, in October 1994, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be hard to find a national or sub-national government anywhere in the world that has a superior financial position to Queensland

That is the true situation. Of course, this unique financial position has given business in Queensland a huge competitive advantage. While other states use on average $25 in every $100 of their own source revenue in servicing their $75 million debt load, Queensland actually earns net interest income.

PARA.TAB: Queensland is the only state to be debt free. The combined debt of the other states and territories is about $75 billion. The Goss government has completely eliminated the debt of $4.2 billion inherited from the previous National Party government. Indeed, by June 1996, the Queensland government is expected to have net assets of $1.6 billion. So let us not hear any of the nonsense that has been bandied about here that somehow the Goss government does not have a good financial record in Queensland.

Getting back to the QIDC, the QIDC has been substantially reformed in other areas. The government schemes that I previously referred to, the government schemes that were previously manipulated by the National Party government, have been removed from the QIDC and are now administered by the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority. The QIDC is now run by an independent professional board—no more National Party cronies on the board. It is an independent board that is running the scheme very well. I would not want the House to think that, by changing its emphasis and transferring the government schemes to the administration of the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority, there is a neglect of the rural sector. I think there was some suggestion in the previous speaker's remarks that that was the case. The proof is in the figures, because lending to rural producers from the QIDC increased from $250 million in 1986 to over $1,000 million in 1995.

Before this legislation could come into place, the Reserve Bank expected and got an audit of the QIDC. The Reserve Bank found that the systems of the QIDC were of the highest standard. One may compare that with the report which was brought down in 1990, which referred to cronyism and to conflict of interest, and see the vast difference between the administration under the Goss Labor government and that under the previous National Party government.

This is not the only monitoring of the QIDC that takes place. The QIDC is monitored also by the government owned enterprise unit within Treasury. So there is a whole range of systems. There is now a public accounts committee in the Queensland parliament. Someone coming from any other parliament in the world would say, `So what? We have had public accounts committees for 10 or 20 years,' but in Queensland it has come in only since 1989, when the Goss government came in.

Yet these people claim that they can govern Queensland. These are the people that claim that they are ready to govern again. I think the Queensland people will have a very different message for them and a very different message for the Liberal and National Party government—or the National-Liberal government, I am sorry, because there will never be a Liberal government in Queensland. We know that a vote for the Liberals in Queensland is really a vote for the Nationals, and that is something that we will be very clearly telling the people of Queensland in the next two or three weeks.

The Queensland government does have a very good economic record. The previous speaker was talking about economic development. In April this year the Goss government released From strength to strength, a comprehensive blueprint for the state's future economic development, which included public sector reform, micro-economic reform, tax concessions—$9 billion worth of fiscal infrastructure—programs for the development of education and training, research and development, and trade and investment initiatives.
There has been some debate in the House about the Queensland government's economic performance in the social welfare area, in terms of social justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's that got to do with it?

—There has been a debate, and it is relevant because there has been a wide ranging debate here about the economic performance of Queensland. There are long-term structural problems in relation to social infrastructure in Queensland. In 1989 Queensland was the lowest spending state in public housing and in 1989 Queensland had the lowest expenditure on education of any state. That was consistent through the 1970s and through the 1980s—totally consistent. The figures are there and these things do not change overnight.

PARA.TAB: The opposition, in the parliament yesterday, was handing out a document that purported to suggest that poverty was worst in Queensland. The real danger signals that were given by that report were that Queensland would have been in a situation where Queensland taxpayers would have had to bail out the QIDC because of the stated mismanagement of having loans being determined by political cronyism and not by commercial considerations.

PARA.TAB: In some ways, that is what happened in the southern states in relation to other institutions. It was not quite the same thing but, clearly, there were inappropriate loans in the southern states. The difference with Queensland is this: the people in Victoria and South Australia were overly generous with their loans, but there was never any suggestion that there was political interference in terms of who got the loans; and it is very clear indeed that the QIDC, pre-1989, was subject to political interference. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: I see that my colleague the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) cannot wait to get going, but I am sure that he will have a chance in a moment. This is a timely debate on the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill because it coincides with the election campaign that is now under way in Queensland. In many respects, this particular debate also brings us, as has been noted on this side, to the important question of credibility as far as the Queensland Goss government is concerned. This may not be a major election issue up there, as I can think of a number of others; nevertheless, this is an important issue and it ought to be an election issue.

PARA.TAB: A lot of Queenslanders, once they become completely aware of what the Queensland government is up to, will be a little unsure about what the government actually proposes to do. Earlier this year, the Queensland Treasurer assured the parliament of Queensland that the QIDC was not to become a bank. Clearly, he misled the parliament when he said that, and he has also misled the people of Queensland. He seems to think that this is a debate about semantics. I note that the Courier-Mail editorial of 9 May makes this point, when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: But the Treasurer must expect to be closely scrutinised on any agency within his brief that has large cheques to offer people with ideas. The Opposition was right to ask the question. A clear answer, without semantics, should be put on the public record.
It has not been put on the public record. In a sense, the question is still unanswered, the concerns remain—and they are very real concerns as far as many other Queenslanders and I are concerned.

PARA.TAB: When is a bank not a bank? By any definition, the QIDC will be a bank with the passing of the legislation that we are dealing with today. It will be registered under section 5 of the Banking Act. No amount of obfuscation by the Queensland Treasurer, no amount of quick sidestepping, can avoid that issue. It will be a bank. The fact that it will be a bank should be of concern to many Queenslanders because, clearly, governments do not run banks very well. In fact, what this amounts to is the people of Queensland signing a blank cheque for the Goss government, and many Queenslanders would want to think very carefully about whether or not they want to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had a good history in South Australia and Victoria.

—I am coming to that, which is the point of raising the whole issue. The member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) in his contribution to this debate earlier talked about the previous administration of the QIDC, and I am sure the member for Kennedy will want to talk about that. But the member for Moreton and none of his colleagues want to talk in any balanced way about the state banks of South Australia or Victoria. They really want to avoid those issues. I can understand why they do not want to get into that area because the performance of those state owned banks ought to be—and will be for a very long time—a great embarrassment to the Labor Party because the losses in those states amounted to billions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: Let us be quite clear that, when the QIDC was corporatised and went through that process, its debts were guaranteed and are guaranteed by the Queensland government. While it had limitations on its activities, those guarantees may not have been of great concern but, once it becomes a bank, they ought to be of concern and that ought to be a worry to all Queenslanders.

Let us just get back to what the extent of this problem was. The State Bank of South Australia has so far cost the taxpayers of that state $3,200 million—over $3 billion lost by the State Bank of South Australia so far. The fiasco in Victoria in banking cost the taxpayers of Victoria $2,000 million, over $2 billion. Now we have the Goss government going down the same track of getting into the banking business.

Make no mistake: the QIDC is operating in a high-risk area. It is essentially lending to industry. It is not engaged in lending for home loans, which of course is the safe end of the lending spectrum, by and large. And Queenslanders might not be aware that, by virtue of this authority, it is authorised to operate in the derivatives market. I do not want to overstate that because, frankly, I am relieved from discussions I have had with the Governor of the Reserve Bank and others involved in the derivatives area that there is no real cause for concern about our banks' activities in respect of derivatives, which are a genuine part of their operations.

Of course, there may be a Nick Leeson hanging around there somewhere. I am not suggesting he would be but, as the Governor of the Reserve Bank told the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration on 20 April:

SPEECH.PARA: You cannot legislate against incompetence or dishonesty.

The fact is that this bank, QIDC, will be operating in a high-risk area, as were the State Bank of South Australia and the State Bank of Victoria. Honourable members should look at the losses they made. I am not casting aspersions on the board of the QIDC at all. It happens to be a very well balanced and qualified board, but the point we are making is that there has been some obfuscation by the Queensland Treasurer about whether it was a bank of not. It is a bank and it is operating as a bank. It is guaranteed by the Queensland government, and that ought to be up-front.

PARA.TAB: Why has the Treasurer of Queensland not admitted that this is the case? At least what he is doing in Queensland would then be out in the open. If and when he does do that, Queenslanders should ask themselves: why does the Queensland government want to go down that track when everywhere else it has proved to be a disaster? In fact, people are heading back in the other direction. But the shingle is up. The QIDC is opening branch offices in southern states. In those states it is seeking retail funds. It is competing in the retail sector for funds.

That is another fundamental objection Queenslanders ought to have: the QIDC is competing with the private sector on less than a level playing field. It has, by virtue of its government guaranteed status, a position of preference as far as credit rating is concerned. That it is competing in the private sector is of concern to me and should be of concern to Queensland.

We see with the Goss government's activities in this respect that it is no different from any of its relatives in the southern states. It is just a few years behind its southern and western counterparts, who have all since been thrown out of office, as they might well have been, for their ineptitude and the fact that they cost, by virtue of their entrepreneurial activities, ratepayers in their respective states thousands of millions of dollars.

The Treasurer in Queensland is entitled to rely on the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank. That is the peg upon which he hangs his hat in respect of this issue. That might be some comfort, but in the end that is not what this issue is about. There was unofficial supervision of the state banks of Victoria and South Australia, but that certainly did not save them. We know—it is on the public record—the Reserve Bank was well aware of the potential dangers faced by those institutions months in advance of those dangers becoming public. So prudential supervision is not in any sense a guarantee of performance.

As the Governor of the Reserve Bank admitted in a meeting of the committee of which I am deputy chairman, we cannot legislate or guarantee against incompetence. This bank will be operating as a business and taking risks in the high-end risk spectrum of the marketplace in Queensland. We hope it does well. It is performing well now, but it is venturing into a new and distinct area of operation, and Queenslanders should be warned about that.

To date our objection and that of the state opposition in Queensland has been that the Treasurer has failed to come clean and tell the people of Queensland the fact about this matter: he wants to get into the banking business. Why does he want to get into the banking business? We are not quite sure about that, but he still manages to maintain his position that this is an argument about semantics—about whether or not it is a bank. The point is that it is a bank and he ought to come out and tell the people of Queensland that it is a bank.

So far the Queensland government has had a very poor record for investment. I, frankly, do not trust it with a bank. As a Queenslander, I prefer the Queensland government—or any government when it comes down to it—not to be in the banking business. I certainly do not trust the Goss Labor government with a bank. The Goss Labor government invested $6 million in Compass Airlines. That was a brilliant investment! Most of us watching were quite aghast that a state government would want to get into that business at all, let alone so unadvisedly. It only had to look a little beyond its nose to realise what a high risk little venture that was. The government did its $6 million in a matter of hours. The money lasted hardly any time at all.

The Indy car race is another example. So far the Queensland government has endured an accumulated loss of around $80 million. We are not quite sure of the extent of the loss because the government has not told us the entire story. It has cost the Goss government, therefore the taxpayers of Queensland, between $8 million and $15 million a year. We are told the race has an economic impact of $30 million a year. By that I assume the government is telling us that the race cost X amount but the government is getting a return.

I happen to doubt the veracity of those figures. I am not casting aspersions so much on the accountants who prepared them but rather on the government that trotted them out as some justification for that particular investment. Those of us who live on the Gold Coast remain very sceptical. We are not sceptical of the event, except those in Surfers Paradise who are directly affected by the race either because of the noise or because of the effect it has on their businesses. More broadly, we are concerned about why the government should be subsidising it to the extent that it is. We also have some definite and understandable doubts as to whether the event is having that economic impact or how the economic impact is measured because it tends to be such an intangible thing.

The plain fact of the matter is that governments are not good at picking winners. I doubt that we ought to have any confidence in the capacity of the Goss government to operate a bank. I say that governments are not good at picking winners, but Labor governments in particular are very bad when it comes to picking winners. In the end they spend other people's money, and sooner or later they fail.

There could be no clearer example than this federal Labor government. It has irresponsibly punched this country headlong into an enormous debt burden that will not be repaid by our children or grandchildren. That is an example of how every Labor government in the history of this country, at both the state and federal level, has ultimately proved itself to be incapable of running the country's affairs on a responsible level. I believe this federal government is as culpable as any other has been.

The people of Queensland need to be warned about what the Queensland government is doing in respect of the QIDC. I would like to congratulate Mrs Sheldon, the state shadow Treasurer, who has taken up this issue publicly on a number of occasions in both the parliament and other places. She has taken a stand on this issue on behalf of the people of Queensland. She has asked questions that should be answered and have not been answered.

Perhaps in the course of the election campaign broader questions may arise about the future of Suncorp and the QIDC and whether in fact they might be sold for the benefit of Queensland. The Premier himself said in the Queensland parliament not so long ago:

SPEECH.PARA: State governments should not be in the banking and insurance business.

Yet, despite those words, the Queensland government is rushing headlong down the track of getting into the banking business. No doubt there will be some opposition in the Queensland Labor Party to the sale of those particular instrumentalities but that is the way the rest of Australia is moving. Even here there is a move to sell the Commonwealth Bank, and for very good reasons too. We support that sale but we do not support what will be done with the money. It will be a misuse of the money that will be raised.

PARA.TAB: In principle, governments do not need to be in the banking business. Even the federal Labor Party, for one reason or another, has come to that realisation. All the states except Queensland have certainly come to that realisation somewhat because they have had their fingers very badly burned. Apparently the Goss government has not learned any lessons at all from that and wants to get into the banking business.

If the Queensland government were to sell Suncorp and the QIDC, I am sure the money raised from their sale could be put to very good use in Queensland. I could suggest a number of very worthwhile ventures in my electorate that could benefit from the money. We really need some money spent on roads. I will not get too far off the track here, but if I were allowed to I would have prepared a wish list of things that we could put those proceeds towards.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—We will not allow that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know, and I am not going to tempt you, Mr Deputy Speaker. We want to make the point in this debate that the people of Queensland need to be warned. They need to be made aware of this fact because the Queensland government has failed to make them aware. The members of the Queensland opposition have attempted to do so, and we on this side of the House are helping them by making the people of Queensland aware that this should be an election issue. As I said at the outset, this will not be a first order issue. There are a lot more important concerns relating to the credibility of the Goss government—law and order, health and some of the other disasters that have befallen the people of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The sale of Suncorp and QIDC ought to be an election issue because it gets to the very fundamental issues and credibility about what governments ought to be about. The people of Queensland need to understand that, in terms of the banking business, their government is going in the opposite direction to every other government.

I believe that the Queensland Treasurer has been less than honest in his dealings with this matter. He should have come clean. He should have said, `Yes, we're getting into the banking business and this is why we're doing it.' He has not done that. I believe the people of Queensland need to be well aware that, with the passage of this legislation today, we are giving the Queensland government a blank cheque with regard to the banking industry. The people of Queensland should be very worried about this in view of what has happened in other states.
