SPEECH.PARA: It is important when considering initiatives in the portfolio of Regional and Rural Development—
that is an issue that is most important in relation to the QIDC—
to distinguish between those which are essentially beneficial to the development of Australian regions and those which will win the Coalition seats in regional Australia.
He went on to say in relation to infrastructure investment:

We need to set a figure ($1 billion, $3 billion—the actual number is insignificant) as an indication of our commitment to putting roads, dams, port, airports, bridges, whatever, into regional Australia.
He further stated:
A new road/bridge etc is a proven electoral winner.

That is what the member for Maranoa said when he was the opposition spokesperson on regional and rural development. How have those opposite moved on in the area of effective financial responsibility—an issue that they have made much of in this debate on the QIDC coming under the prudential supervision of RBA? The current spokesperson on this issue, Senator Macdonald, a Queensland senator, spends a lot of his time putting out press releases. He outlined his grand vision in this area to the shadow cabinet in Cairns recently. He stated:

The policy indicates that prior to the election we would be announcing a list of long term visionary projects we would specifically like the Council to investigate and prioritise, for example: Darwin to Alice Railway, turning coastal waters inland—
that is always a good policy for the National Party in Central Queensland; it always wants to turn the rivers around—
rejuvenating the Murray-Darling Basin, Adelaide Airport.
This gives us the flexibility of announcing a lot of major long term visionary matters but without committing ourselves to actually proceeding with them.

That is the sort of economic responsibility we can expect from the federal opposition. Those opposite are now engaging in a political point scoring exercise by having a crack at the Queensland government. Politics is the game we are in and I have no problem with those on either side of the House getting into the political debate, but I think it shows the opposition's lack of policy when the best the member for McPherson can say is that it wants the QIDC to be a bank.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear from the statements of the Queensland Treasurer that the government is trying to make sure that the financial status and independence of the QIDC are protected and that it has very high prudential standards. That is why it is entering into this technical arrangement as far as the QIDC is concerned. It is quite clear that what it is requesting of the Commonwealth government is that the QIDC be defined as a bank under section 5 of the Banking Act. That section requires it to be a bank in only a technical sense. The QIDC is not going to be competing with the private sector.

It is interesting that those opposite are from the so-called party of competition but, when you suggest a bit of real competition, they say, `We don't want that. We mustn't have a level playing field here.' The real intent of this legislation is to ensure that there is proper supervision of the QIDC. In doing this, the Queensland government is prepared to refer certain powers to the Commonwealth government. In addition to what the Reserve Bank of Australia will do, the Queensland government has in place very effective supervisory arrangements.

As my colleagues the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) have previously said, when the Goss government came to power in 1989 an independent report indicated that the QIDC's management had been very poor. There was political interference in commercial matters, cases of commercial conflict of interest with directors and staff, lack of board leadership, poor or no risk management systems in place, and instances of abuse of the schemes of assistance administered by the government schemes division of the QIDC. This effectively meant that the organisation of the QIDC was at very high risk of failure.

That had to be turned around, as did a lot of major difficulties that were the legacy of years of Joh's management of Queensland. The corporatisation of the QIDC under the government's own Corporations Act came into being on 1 October 1994. Its main purpose was to ensure that the taxpayers of Queensland received the full benefits while at the same time being exposed to minimum risk. What we have ensured not only in the Queensland parliament but also here as part of this bill is that those statutory arrangements are effective.

One of the important things that the government has done is to move community based facilities, such as the rural adjustment scheme, into an entirely separate organisation. I know this has been most important in the effective operation of the Rural Adjustment Authority and in getting Commonwealth government assistance to people who have been affected by drought. It also means that funds associated with the QIDC are now available to provide investment into core enterprise operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —You reckon the drought doesn't exist.

—We have the member for Kennedy interjecting as usual. I was quite prepared to listen in silence to the member for McPherson, but it is just too hard for the member for Kennedy to restrain himself. What we do not see from the member for Kennedy is restraint in any direction. After all, he was a member of the Bjelke-Petersen government. Therefore, he has a great deal of responsibility for the criticisms that those of us on this side of the House are making in this debate.

PARA.TAB: As we have moved a number of the community service obligations out of the QIDC, we have a much more effective operation. However, that does not mean that we, with the QIDC, are moving away from supporting rural investment. If you look at the loan book of the QIDC, you see that as recently as 1992 rural sector loans made up 67 per cent of the total loan book. So the QIDC is still very heavily supporting rural and regional development. However, the reliance on a one-industry sector approach constitutes a major commercial risk. It has diminished over time. It has achieved a much more balanced portfolio. Currently, the rural sector represents about 50 per cent of the QIDC's loan book. That indicates a very proper management of development in Queensland.

The one thing that is quite clear—I suspect we will not hear it from the member for Kennedy because I heard his contribution in a debate yesterday—is that, while beef and in particular coalmining are major industries for export not only for Queensland but for the country, the great challenge for Queensland is to diversify its industrial and manufacturing base and to bring on stream other competitive export enterprises. What we do know is that commodities are at the mercy of international trading cycles. It is very important to have an effective investment operation in Queensland to provide for that investment.

I think the Queensland government has been very successful in the turnaround of the QIDC, giving it a much more effective financial position. That also means that it is part of the achievement of the Queensland government not only to become the only state that is net debt free but also by June 1996 to have expected net assets of $1.6 billion. We are not servicing debt in Queensland because of the prudent financial management of the Goss government, including the Treasurer, Mr de Lacy.
My colleague the member for Leichhardt quoted the Natwest Capital Market's report State of the states. I think it is worth repeating. In October 1994, it reported:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it would be hard to find a national or sub-national government anywhere in the world that has a superior financial position to Queensland . . .

That is not a bad financial reference. It means that not only are we not servicing debt in Queensland but also we have more money to spend on infrastructure and community services. This equates to there being $2 billion more now available to not only keep taxes down but also provide quality infrastructure and community services.

PARA.TAB: A Queensland government report recently indicated massive infrastructure projects. I am particularly delighted to see that Central Queensland will be the recipient of those. This is going to mean investment into regional and rural areas of Queensland which will translate into jobs and support in areas where we need it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are those projects?

—In my own area, Central Queensland, the government will be providing increased dam infrastructure which is vital, particularly to the coal industry and to the agricultural industry—issues that I would have thought the member for Kennedy would be interested in. Effectively, that is about $9 billion worth of proposals.
—What are they?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The honourable member for Kennedy is listed to speak next. He will have his opportunity then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Effectively, this blueprint includes public sector reform, micro-economic reform, further tax concessions but $9 billion worth of infrastructure, programs for development of education and training, research and development, trade and investment. The problem with the National Party is that it can only think about dams and railways, but one of the most effective infrastructure developments is training and developing people skills, human resources, so they can make a contribution to the service sector, which is making a huge contribution to our export income. So we have $3.6 billion worth of capital expenditure already allocated in the budget.

PARA.TAB: Infrastructure spending has increased enormously under the Goss Labor government. For instance, I will mention the family services portfolio. In 1989-90 the budget for the Department of Family Services and Aboriginal and Islander Affairs was $159.57 million. Today, in the current budget, it is $500.9 million. So there has been an increase not only in family services but in police, education and hospitals. We had to turn around years and years of neglect.

What is happening to the QIDC's operations in Central Queensland? Just yesterday the official opening of the new premises in Emerald took place. At that opening the chairman stated that the loan book for the branch had gone past $100 million, which makes it one of the largest loan books of any branch of any financial institution in Queensland regional areas. There has been a necessity, both in Rockhampton and Emerald, to move to larger premises and put on more staff because of the development of business investment in those regions. This is also happening at the Mackay and Longreach branches.

QIDC's economics department has just completed a study of the beef cattle industry, with particular reference to Central Queensland, to assist with trade and finance for the export of live cattle. This is one of the key issues in my region of Central Queensland and is very important to our economy. The Queensland government is effectively providing support for the cattle industry.

That is all just too hard for members of the the National Party because they are still back in the bad old days of pork-barrelling and providing a bit of infrastructure here and there to win a few votes. Of course, at that time that was a lot easier because we had a gerrymander. The National Party could govern in its own right with 36 per cent of the vote. We have moved a long way from that period of corruption.

This bill is about finalising arrangements that have already been put in place by the state government, having learned from the mistakes made in other states about the support of various state banks. The kind of furphy the member for McPherson peddles is that state governments cannot be responsible in providing infrastructure investment. What is very clear from these arrangements is that the Reserve Bank will have very effective powers of supervision. The Queensland government itself has effective auditing requirements in place to make sure that not only will the QIDC work in the interests of investment in Queensland, but also taxpayers' money will be effectively looked after. In fact, it has already made a profit and will continue to make a profit and put money back into the Treasury for further infrastructure investment and for further services to the people of Queensland.

The problem for the opposition in the state campaign is that they have not got any policies. They have no track record of financial management on which they can build. Therefore, we are having particular debates in this House along the lines of the ones the opposition is running on this bill and ran yesterday in the MPI on the poverty issue. The opposition can run those arguments and can put that case, but the track record of the Goss government is that of a very effective financial manager.

What it is doing with the QIDC indicates its responsibility. Making the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority a separate organisation has meant effective Commonwealth support for primary producers in my electorate and in other parts of Queensland who are still suffering from drought. There is a lot of money available there. I am glad to see that the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority is advertising the fact that it would like to talk to primary producers who are in difficulty.

This is about efficient, effective and responsible management of the state finances of Queensland, and indeed it is about the Commonwealth government taking an appropriate role to provide a technical definition of banking. The QIDC will still be an investment mechanism for the benefit of the people of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to spend too much of my time commenting on the speeches of previous speakers, but their speeches have been so priceless that I really must make some comments. I will deal first with the previous speaker, the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell). She stated—and I noted it down—that the National Party in Queensland was used to ruling under a gerrymander. We have never had a minority government; we have had a majority of the vote in every election. The honourable member for Capricornia sits here as a member of a minority government. The Labor Party did not win a majority of the votes in the last election campaign. The honourable member should not come in here and talk about a gerrymander when the Labor Party is in that situation. She ought to check her facts before she starts shooting her mouth off. She is an intellectual lightweight with no substance at all behind her.

PARA.TAB: Let me move on. She said that the National Party only thinks of railways and dams. Mr Deputy Speaker, shame upon us to only think of railways and dams! But the reason she put that we only think of railways and dams, and that in a previous speech she commented on how they were building all these marvellous dams, is that in six years they have not built a single solitary weir in the state of Queensland. We were building one every two years.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—I take it that the honourable member is going to get to the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. But with all due respect, I would like to see her speech and discover how much she spoke about the QIDC.
—I was listening very carefully.
—It would be hard to find any references whatsoever. Mr Deputy Speaker, I take your point. Let me move on. She said, `We make investments in people.' Presumably, this was through—
—The honourable member keeps saying `she'. I take it you are referring to the honourable member for—
—The member for Capricornia, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—You might use those words.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, with all due respect, that is the fourth time you have interrupted me now.

—I have asked you to come to the bill. I am also reminding you that, according to the standards of the House, you will refer to members by their correct titles. The title of the honourable member to whom you are referring is the honourable member for Capricornia, not `she'.
—Is she not a she?
—If you are going to be smart, perhaps you can leave for a while.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to get on with the speech. The honourable member who spoke previously was talking about projects. I interrupted her three times because I was quite curious to know what the projects were. That was not a facetious comment—I was really interested in what the projects were. She stood up and said, `We had all these projects, $9 billion worth of them,' but there was no substance in her speech whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: In the state house in Queensland, my knees used to knock when Tom Burns got up to speak. Unlike all three of the ALP speakers whom I have heard previously in this debate today, when he stood up to speak he had substance. He never opened his mouth unless he had hard facts behind what he said. People used to tremble when he stood up. It was very hard for me to pin down a single solitary statistic or fact from the speeches of the three previous ALP speakers—and I have been taking notes on all three speeches.

Let me move on to the issue of corruption, which is very relevant to this debate. The state banks in Victoria and South Australia failed completely, losing thousands of millions of dollars for those states. All of the ALP speakers who have spoken prior to me have got stuck into the corruption of the Queensland government. It is really very good, in so far as we can objectively assess the relative corruption levels in Queensland and in the three ALP states by the royal commissions that were held in all four states.

The losses to the public purse in Queensland are fully documented; $26,000 was lost to the public purse. That was defined, firstly, as `the private usage of the government car'. Members in this place have access to a government car which they are allowed to use for private purposes—yet Brian Austin went to gaol for it. The second reason he went to gaol was that he used his plastic magic to take people out to dinner. His was the leading case. Everyone in line behind him just said, `They're going to throw us all in gaol' and they pleaded guilty. But on the record, the charges that were laid involved $26,000.

The losses to the public purse in Western Australia were $876 million. The losses to the public purse in Victoria were $3,000 million. The losses to the public purse in the South Australian State Bank collapse were $3,100 million. That puts this matter in perspective.

Mr Deputy Speaker, if you are looking for corruption, let me quote the famous old policeman—a legendary policeman in his lifetime—old Ben McNicoll in Brisbane, the great crime buster. Ben used to say, `Have a look at their houses, have a look at what they own, have a look at whether they have any wealth, and you will see who was corrupt and who wasn't.' I would simply point the attention of this House to the wealth of the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), to the wealth of the last Prime Minister and also to the wealth of our former leader in Queensland, Joh Bjelke-Petersen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also point your attention to the fact that you have yet to come to the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill. I have let you make a few points because you were saying you were answering previous speakers who spoke before I took the chair. But now I want you to come to the contents of the bill we are debating. If you continue as you have been, you will have to sit down. I have allowed you to have a fairly wide range. Now I want you to come to the bill we are actually debating. It has nothing to do with the wealth of Prime Ministers past or present.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I must make—
—Do not argue. I have given my ruling. If you cannot follow it, you can sit down.
—You have given your ruling; am I allowed to speak now?
—Go on. You can speak to the bill we are debating in this chamber.

—I would like to make the point that we are talking about corruption. Every speaker who has spoken so far has spoken about corruption. With the collapse of two banks in Australia, we lost $6,100 million. Corruption is at the very heart of the debate we are talking about, and that is why I am canvassing these issues. If three ALP speakers are allowed to get up here and absolutely vilify the National Party in Queensland and I am not allowed to reply or even defend the performance of those people with respect to a state bank that was set up by the Queensland government, I put it to you, Deputy Speaker, that my chances of getting a fair go here are very small. But you are the referee, so I will listen to your ruling.

—I will just answer that. The previous occupant of this chair, the member for Cook (Mr Dobie), did call members' attention at several times back to the bill. I am only following the rulings that he gave. I have allowed you to make fairly wide ranging comments because you did say you were responding to the comments of the honourable member for Capricornia, but I want you to come to the bill now. I see nothing in this very short bill about collapsing banks and corruption, and I have the bill here.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, you are taking my time. Please can I say what I have a right to say in this place?
—Stick to the bill.

—You have taken three minutes of my time. Let me talk about the Polichronis report on QIDC. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) was quite right in saying that I was very heavily involved. I was in fact the secretary of the review committee of QIDC.

PARA.TAB: I read the Polichronis report and analysed it in great detail. I found it absolutely staggering that the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), the member for Leichhardt and the member for Capricornia stood in this place and said that the report referred to corruption. There was not a single reference in the Polichronis report to corruption, from the first page to the last page. The report was highly technical and demonstrated classical economic rationalism throughout.

Clearly the three members who quoted extensively from the report had not read it. They had absolutely no idea what was in the Polichronis report. Polichronis recommended that QIDC stop being an agricultural bank or anything of that nature and become a purely commercial bank. The reason he recommended this is that he believed QIDC should offer purely commercial interest rates, not preferential interest rates. At that stage, all of QIDC's loans to the public were at two per cent less than those being offered by commercial banks in Queensland. He was reflecting the attitudes, philosophy and self-interest of the other banks in Queensland.

Our policy was completely opposite to that. In fact, Bill Gunn, the Deputy Premier of Queensland, and I served on the committee of review, and we said, `In a commercial field, we can borrow the money at two per cent less than the banks; therefore, we can loan it out at two per cent less. We can choose our blue chip lendings.' Quite frankly, we thought that, if that was going to be to the detriment of the private banks, that was a criticism we would have to bear.

I do not think anyone in Australia—even our harshest critics—ever accused us of incompetence when it came to financial administration. Heaven only knows how we left the state in such good order, but we did it with our policy and philosophy. Polichronis threw that out completely.

This is the staggering part of the report. Interest rates were 20 per cent at that time. Polichronis advocated that we abolish all of the special loan funding arrangements via the QIDC special lending arrangements to people in trouble in small business or the farming sector. He said that that should be abolished and the interest rates should become 20 per cent. He got his way, even though it was over the broken backs of tens of thousands of Queensland small businessmen on the land and in the cities. That is what happened as a result of the Polichronis report.

I wish to heaven that the members who spoke before me knew something about the report or had read the report's foreword. They made mention of the fact that the Queensland government is in a very strong and sound financial way and its resources are in a marvellous way and, therefore, it should be allowed to run the bank in a right and proper manner.

Previous speakers on our side pointed out the ALP's record in running state banks. The State Bank of Victoria fell over, with a loss of $3,000 million. The South Australian State Bank broke that record and fell over with a loss of $3,100 million. I would have thought it would be the last thing on the planet that an ALP government would want to become involved in. But that is what is happening here today. The Queensland government is going into the field of banking. If you looked at Rothwells as a state bank—if I could be facetious and say that Rothwells was a state bank—you would see that it fell over, with a loss of $1,000 million, as well.

We come to whether these people are capable of running the financial administration of Queensland. Quite rightly, the speakers from the government side said yesterday that the poverty report in Queensland was a 1990 report. It was a 1990 report. It would be very unfair to blame the present Queensland government for that 1990 report. So what did I do? I got the figures out and upgraded the report to find out whether or not the government in Queensland was culpable. I suspected that things were going all right in Queensland and the figures would not be as bad as the ones in the report.

The first statistics that I chose, naturally, were the figures for average weekly earnings. I found out that Queensland has by far and away the lowest average weekly earnings in the entire nation. In Queensland average weekly earnings are $496 a week, whereas for our two neighbours, the Northern Territory and New South Wales, average weekly earnings are $593 a week—almost $100 more in the Northern Territory, and almost $70 a week more in New South Wales, with $567. The only other state that was low was South Australia, with $522, which is still miles ahead of Queensland on $496 average weekly earnings.

Even more worrying for Queensland is that it is the only state in Australia where average weekly earnings have fallen since 1993. So if the situation was bad in 1990, it is a lot worse now. Yet these are the people who are saying to us that they should be running a state bank.

The previous speaker, the member for Capricornia, said that we on this side of the House do not take into account investment in people. That was the expression she used. It is very unfortunate that she used that expression because investment in people comes down to education, for example. In Queensland we have the lowest retention rate in Australia, with the exception of South Australia, for people between 15 and 24 years of age—which is the education age, if you like. We have the lowest TAFE participation rate in Australia. Those two things come under the auspices of the state government.

In Queensland gross state product per head of mean population is the lowest in Australia, household disposable income is the lowest in Australia and its main income source is government benefits. We are the second highest in Australia there. Only South Australia has more people on the public purse in Australia. It pips us out there, but then Mr Bannon gave South Australia a great head start on us. I have already mentioned the mean total weekly earnings of all employees.

So in every indicator that exists in Australian social trends, which one of the other ALP speakers was referring to as the social wage, Queensland is the worst in Australia bar two, and in both those cases we are slightly behind South Australia. In the other six we are well ahead of South Australia and are the worst in Australia.
As far as the retention rates in schools go, every one of the speakers has said, `Queensland has had a massive increase in spending on education.' It has massively increased spending on education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, they had to.

—You are dead right. But this is how effective it has been. The retention rates to grade 12 have fallen from 85 per cent to 78 per cent. There has been a massive increase in spending and it has a hell of a lot less people in schools. All I can say is, that demonstrates the state government's towering incompetence. Yet it is saying to us, `Give us control of the state bank.'

PARA.TAB: I did not use the arguments about the social wage; the other side used the arguments about the social wage. If we come to health, which is part of the social wage, the Queensland government says, `We're good managers, we're spending more on health.' Yes, it is. There has been a massive increase in spending on health. But what is happening on the ground? This is a staggering statistic. I had enormous difficulty believing it. The Queensland government has cut the number of beds at the Townsville General Hospital, which is the biggest hospital north of Brisbane, from 540 to 360. Of course, if you cut the number of beds, the queues extend right out into the street and people die because they simply cannot get attention fast enough.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they have. I cannot speak for other parts of the state, but all I keep hearing on the radio is that things are dreadful in other parts of the state. But I do know that over 1,000 people in Mareeba, almost one-seventh of its population, turned up for a mass meeting after beds were removed from the Mareeba hospital, and that 230 people in Tully, about 10 per cent of its population, and 500 people in Charters Towers turned out for mass meetings because health services were being cut right across the board in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The Queensland government massively increased spending on education, but there are 10 per cent fewer people in schools now than before. It massively increased spending on health, but fewer people now have beds than before. It has kicked all the people out into the streets. As for housing, each of the previous speakers said that there has been a massive increase in housing. But housing starts in Queensland are down 21 per cent. I would not trust Labor with a piggy bank, let alone a state bank.
Opposition members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just had some assistance from my very intelligent colleagues. This is not my chosen ground to fight on; the ALP chose to fight on its investment in people. Each of the speakers has said, `We've invested all this money.' They have, and they have invested it so toweringly incompetently that we have the lowest number of housing approvals in Australia. On the front page of the Courier-Mail, which is no great supporter of the government, it says `Lowest housing approvals in Australia: a dip of 21 per cent'. I agree with that. The government is spending more money on housing, education and health than it ever has before, and in each case it has a disastrous record.

PARA.TAB: I do not hesitate to say that we looked to QIDC taking $2,000 million in lendings in Queensland. We were after blue-chip because we could get it. We could lend the money out at two per cent less than the money coming in. We could choose the sorts of people we wanted to lend to, and obviously housing was a very attractive area to us. The profits we got from that area would have been repatriated to help small business, which is staggering under the load imposed by the federal government, which took interest rates up over 20 per cent for the first time in Australian history and which took bankruptcies from 4,000 a year to 17,000 a year. At that time we were desperately trying to help these people in small business, whether they were in a town or on a farm, and we thought we could do that by taking the profit from the $2,000 million and repatriating it into this other area.

Each of the previous speakers referred to the disastrous mess that QIDC was in. When we handed QIDC over to the incoming Goss government, it had the lowest delinquency rate of any bank in Australia—and that is in the Polichronis report. Those opposite not only have not read the report but also have come in here and told flagrant untruths. I do not think they were lying, because I do not think any of the three people, who are world champion lightweights, made any attempt to check the facts that were given to them by the state government in Queensland. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a delight to speak in the debate on the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill after the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), because all the misrepresentations made by government members, who were allowed to go on with them, have been adequately answered by a person who was there, in the Queensland government, at the time and who obviously participated. The suggestion about extensive corruption being endemic in the National Party time and the reference to the QIDC are obviously ploys by them for the coming election. Premier Goss may now have some regrets that he allowed himself to call an election before this matter was debated in this House, because it does give us a full range to go across.

PARA.TAB: The bill itself is a simple one. In fact, it is just a few pages in length. The most significant part of the bill is the proposed amendment to section 5(1) of the Banking Act to include the Queensland Industry Development Corporation. That is the nub of the whole bill. What will this give the QIDC that it does not have now? If you look at the Reserve Bank and its supervisory powers—for a large part of the last 13 years the Treasury has been the responsibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as the Treasurer—you will see that the protection offered under the Banking Act is not as great as it seems.

Mention has already been made of what happened to other state banks, in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, under supervision. The member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) was a member of the banking committee inquiry into the banking system following deregulation. The massive incompetence in the supervision of those three enterprises, particularly the South Australian bank, is on the record and is quite evident. We also found during that inquiry that, while the QIDC was being operated by the Labor Queensland government, there was a lot the QIDC had to answer and account for. That was at the time of those high interest rates imposed by the Treasurer of the day, the present Prime Minister.

I well recall going to Charleville at that time and having it explained to us what the QIDC administration was doing for those people with rural loans and the manner in which it was trying to collect debts from people who were suffering from the vicious droughts and under those high interest rates. It is no panacea for the QIDC to be included in this bill, particularly if the record of the South Australian and the Victorian state banks is anything to go by.

It was interesting to sit here and listen to the earlier comments of the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd). He obviously had not read the report that was referred to. I doubt whether he was in Queensland at the time. I have grave doubts as to whether the member for Leichhardt was a Queenslander at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he was not. You're right.

—That is right. If we go back to the start of the QIDC in Queensland, we see that the opposition supported its formation. It was obviously a transitional stage. It was formed out of the Rural Reconstruction Board, and it also took up the Agricultural Bank facilities. Let us not be embarrassed about what the Agricultural Bank and the QIDC were set up to do. They were set up so that higher risk loans could be made to the people on the land. Those loans were made for a purpose. They were made for the development of the farming and grazing sectors of Queensland. The farming and grazing sectors still help out to a large extent the balance of trade. Advantages were also being given by the Commonwealth. The bank was set up to make sure the resources of Australia were strengthened.

PARA.TAB: We have heard of the repayment of the debt that the Labor government has been able to effect over the last six years. I can recall that the day the Queensland Treasurer, Mr De Lacy, arrived on the treasury bench the headline in the Courier-Mail—not a friend of ours—was that the set of accounts handed over to the Labor government was the most competent of any legacy given to a Labor government in any state in Australia. That is on the record. It does not matter how much it is denied or how much that is corrupted by the government, that is a fact.

Since I have referred to the repayment of the debt, I should say that the debt was created by providing resources through the Agricultural Bank and others to make the farming sector strong, provide us with powerhouses, railway electrification, mining ventures, roads, dams, weirs and water conservation. It is all those sorts of things that have made Queensland great.

If we had a $4 billion dollar loan on that type of productive infrastructure, think in terms of what has happened since. We have a nil debt, apparently. But we do not have any major water conservation scheme. We have tolls being put on our roads. Our railways are to cease operating. Worst of all, we are now to buy power from New South Wales. We cannot produce enough power. Our resource is unemployed people. Our resource is a highly funded hospital system and education system and all the other systems catering to a lower degree of need or want than they were before. It seems strange to me that the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) comes in here to complain about these things when at the beginning of the year he was complaining about his own redistribution. If it looks as though things are not going his way he is the chief complainant. He said that Mr Longmans, the redistributor in Queensland, was biased and did not understand the principles of his act. So much for the member for Moreton.

The QIDC was established initially to provide rural loans at reasonable risk rates and reasonable interest rates. When people criticise the board they must remember that the initial chairman, Graham Tucker, was a very competent person. He never saw eye to eye all the time with the Premier of the day but he was able to bring a degree of integrity to that bank which I believe has survived to this day. It is still providing a larger range of activities to the industry of Queensland than it did before and certainly at a higher rate.

This brings me to the point: what are the activities of the bank? I want to mention, in particular, its activities in connection with rural reconstruction. Rural reconstruction was the activity of the old Agricultural Bank right back in the early days. It is important to understand that the bank will continue to be the distributor of these funds. While I have a lot of respect for some people working within the rural reconstruction area and the rural adjustment area, I believe that the QIDC and the government of Queensland are profiting by the fact that this money is not getting out as readily as it should to those people in grave need. Part of my electorate is now going through the fifth year of drought. I can speak for a lot of the rest of Queensland that is not getting the funds required to help these rural people, experienced people on the land with a future in front of them.

One aspect of the reconstruction where there seems to be a deficiency—and I have heard this right throughout Queensland—is that the amount of funds to reconstruct farmers off the land and give them a place in a town or somewhere are only available if arrangements are made with the rural reconstruction area of the QIDC before the event of reconstructing that debt with the major lenders. This has not always been the case. We have seen many people thrown off their property because of the lack of security, because of the high interest rates, with nothing to go to. Any application after that date is not a viable turnout.

I did mention that the incorporation in 1986 of the QIDC was a move designed to assist, in particular, those people in rural Queensland. Since that time it has picked up many other aspects of help to industry, as the title suggests. In that period it has had a chequered history. There have been loan write-offs. We have heard the member for Kennedy say that in the time of the National Party government the write-off was the lowest of any of the banks throughout Australia. Since that time it has had massive write-offs of debt, particularly on high risk ventures. I mention Compass Airlines. I believe it lost on that. I am not sure whether it is putting money into the Indy participation on the Gold Coast, but obviously that is money that has gone too.

So there has not been that same history of accountability, in spite of what the Labor government says. Perhaps the supervision to be given by the Reserve Bank will assist in some way in ensuring that that risk factor is not as high as before. But I say again: don't count on it too much because many banks in Australia have failed even with that supervision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Dawson will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—I table ministerial arrangements and the standing of the second Keating ministry. It will show that the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) has been elected by the parliamentary Labor Party as Deputy Prime Minister, which is a great honour for him. He was elected unanimously. Now when he speaks in the House he will speak with the added authority of being the Deputy Prime Minister of this government.

—I might say before I ask my question that the opposition had something to say yesterday about the Deputy Prime Minister's elevation. As with the French nuclear testing, this is a bit more catch-up politics by the Prime Minister. My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I remind him that after eight accords Australia now has the worst current account deficit in the industrialised world—worse even than Mexico. Prime Minister, what explanation can you offer for the disastrous slump in foreign investment in Australia other than your failure to tackle the current account deficit problem? Does the fact that foreign investment in Australian equity has fallen from $5,000 million in the March quarter of 1994 to just $20 million in the corresponding quarter this year not confirm the OECD's serious concerns that continuing high current account deficits threaten to drive foreign investors out of Australia?
—The member for Bennelong every now and again returns to the current account deficit.
—With good reason.

—Yes. He returns in essence to one of the country's remaining problems: the paucity of private savings, which is the underlying reason for the current account imbalance. In doing so, he returns to the scene of the crime. He returns to the fact that, during his stewardship of economic policy in Australia, with double digit inflation he destroyed the propensity of Australians to save. Australians, bitten and burnt once, were not about to come back and lend their money to people at less than the inflation rate, as happened in the 1970s. There were negative rates of interest at some point in the 1970s with the rates of return being less than the inflation rate.

PARA.TAB: Is it any wonder that we had a trend decline in private savings? After the former Labor government commissioned the Hancock committee to look at the introduction of a comprehensive superannuation scheme to approach the savings issue in a direct way, the member for Bennelong said—I quote from his press statement—`The government has decided not to introduce the scheme of national superannuation recommended by the majority of the committee.' Too hard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame on you.
—Order! The member for Calwell!

—We then had a quite disastrous trend decline in savings, which this government then sought to change by bringing the budget back into surplus in the 1980s from the massive levels of deficit left by the member for Bennelong.
—You didn't even know it was going to happen.
—Order! The member for O'Connor!

—Not only did he destroy the propensity to save privately but he also had the public sector dissaving by a massive amount with a budget deficit of over four per cent of GDP. So this Labor government had to bring the budget back into surplus. From memory, we have now produced four surpluses. As a consequence of those changes—
—What about Max Walsh?
—Order! I warn the member for Gippsland!

—Max is only a remnant from bygone days. He has been forgotten around here. He is still living off his 1970s information base. As a consequence, the member for Bennelong was quite happy to see the budgets heavily in deficit.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did ask the question. Do you want the answer or not?
—Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting.

—Not only did he see that paucity of private savings, but he also saw budget deficits under his stewardship go into a massive level of public sector dissaving. When he had the chance to do something about it with superannuation he did not. He said he wanted the freedom of choice individuals currently enjoyed in arranging their own affairs to be retained.

PARA.TAB: When he had a policy of zero tax on contribution, a zero tax on fund earnings and a five per cent tax on lump sums, we had less than 40 per cent of employees covered and only $40 billion in fund assets. We are heading now towards $1 trillion—that is, $1,000 billion—in fund assets and expect it to be $2 trillion by the year 2020. That is why and how the government has responded to this.
When Mr Howard was the Treasurer, he had an 18 per cent wages growth in 1980-81. In the Accord, which the government announced today with the ACTU—and I will come to that later—

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know you'll come to it later?
—Because I intend to.
—Because you have a dorothy dixer?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—As a consequence of that, we are actually targeting the economy to continue growing with its strong employment growth based on an underlying inflation rate over the period, on average, of two to three per cent. Could you imagine J.W. Howard, Treasurer, talking about a wages accord guaranteeing wage restraints to deliver a two to three per cent inflation rate? I-m-possible!

PARA.TAB: As a consequence we have seen this enormous change to the economy's competitiveness, which is best shown by these two statistics: two million jobs and a 40 per cent increase in household disposable incomes since 1983. Is it any wonder that whenever the Liberals hear the word `Accord' they start to say that they know in their hearts they could never deliver such a thing? They have no faith in the Australian people. Above all else, they have no imagination and definitely no integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My very important question is directed to the Prime Minister and concerns the outstanding achievements announced today of Accord Mark VIII. Can the Prime Minister outline to the House the benefits which the Accord system brings to Australia as an instrument of national policy making?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The eighth Accord comes after the successful seventh accord, which had an employment target of 500,000. We reached that target in two years and have now created 630,000 jobs since the time it was signed. This Accord shows that the Accord process of managing an economy—that is, not putting all the burden onto fiscal or monetary policy but having a third instrument such as wages—is the way that the Australian economy can best be operated and run in the context of a set of cooperative agreements between the government, the work force and the trade union movement of this country.

PARA.TAB: I am happy to advise the House that the government has today agreed to and entered into its eighth accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions entitled Sustaining growth, low inflation and fairness. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: This accord is based on and consistent with maintaining an underlying rate of inflation of 2 to 3 per cent on average over the cycle.

It talks about the prospect of creating 600,000 jobs over the cycle of the agreement. It talks about the further extension of enterprise bargaining and the provision of an award safety net. It refers very specifically to the importance of putting a safety net under those people who cannot access the enterprise bargaining system. It states:
The Accord parties will support an approach to the AIRC to deliver three further annual adjustments of $9 to $12 per week available at the award level.
For low paid workers, particularly those on award rates, this range will be $11 to $14 per week. This provides an element of redistributive support from the growth the economy is enjoying.

It is that very great change to a flexible enterprise bargaining based system of industrial relations underpinned by the equity of a safety net, which is the quite revolutionary way in which Australia has changed from a centralised wage fixing system to a system that guarantees economic efficiency and equity—and it guarantees it with low inflation.

PARA.TAB: Is it not a change to see the trade union movement of this country, under the Accord Mark VIII, committed to low inflation and sustaining economic growth? We should ponder for a moment the success of the accord. We had the original stabilisation of the economy in 1983 and its return to growth, the extension to superannuation and the productive and skills formation accords of the 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like your banana republic statement! What about the one that led to the recession?
—The member for Flinders will have his chance in the MPI.

—We have seen the change to the award system through award restructuring and a shift to productivity, the devolution of the wage system away from centralised wage fixing to an enterprise bargaining system, with the seventh accord, jobs being put first with employment and the 500,000 jobs target and, now with the eight accord, sustainable growth with low inflation and fairness and equity.

PARA.TAB: This is the model for running an OECD country with higher rates of growth than would normally be able to be obtained with low inflation and high productivity. We have developed skills changes in the labour market, coming under the accord, through productivity, award restructuring and the education and training system. We have come to the point where we can run a growth economy and can have a naturally contestable market producing volumes of productivity naturally from the system while holding the inflation rate down.

If you look at the production of a sustainable rate of economic growth with low inflation you would find that the government has engaged three policy instruments in the last 12 months: adjustments to monetary policy late last year, which were relatively small; adjustments to fiscal policy through a strong change to the budget balance, but one that protects the social wage through outlays; and, there is a lot of weight on the third instrument, the accord and wages. By spreading the weight over the three instruments and not over two we did not have to pull the monetary lever hard with a massive increase in interest rates and we did not have to cut government spending to pieces. We have seen the economy come back to 3.7 per cent economic growth and we have seen inflation remain at low levels. This accord says that we will have low inflation and good growth for the coming four-year period. Could you imagine the coalition being able to produce a document like this providing low inflation for four years?

Could you imagine those opposite having the wit or the courage or the faith in the Australian working person to actually enter into a real discussion of principle and integrity with them and producing in parliament a detailed document of commitments to a two to three per cent rate of inflation in this country and at the same time the equity under the safety nets, the equity of those people who cannot access the enterprise bargaining system? We saw in this parliament last week the sort of quality that we have coming from the opposition. The regional infrastructure policy document from the Liberal Party says:

ANSWER.PARA: This gives us the flexibility of announcing a lot of major long-term visionary matters but without committing ourselves to actually proceeding with them.
This is deceitful, unprincipled policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the TWU sign it?
—The member for O'Connor, resume your seat.
—What about the TWU?
—Order!

—Compare that unprincipled rubbish with the quality which the government has produced now in the Accord, following a budget which sees the budget go back into surplus, following the detail of all those changes and the accountability in the budget documents by the government. Now, point for point, all of these things have been articulated and committed to by the ACTU and the government. There is a stark contrast between the government, which has policies that actually work, that are thought through and that are articulated, and the unprincipled, irrelevant nonsense of the Howard-led opposition.

PARA.TAB: Is it any wonder they hate the Accord? Is it any wonder they hate the discussion with the trade union movement? We know what their policy is—to cut the wages of working people to pieces, to push them onto individual wage contracts, to turn them out of the award system, to not give them a share of the national economic cake and to not let them have part of the bounty which this country can afford.

This is another milestone document in Australian economic history. It is the eighth principled agreement between the government and the work force. It is in public. It is there for all to see. It explains every point. It does it with integrity. The commitments are made with integrity. It is in very stark contrast with the shabby anti-Australian, anti-working class policies of the Howard-led opposition which cannot produce a policy statement beyond two pages without cynical, unprincipled elements to it. When given the opportunity to produce the so-called headland speech, it looked like the work of a year 1 freshman backbencher.

At the end of question time, I will table a copy of the Accord Mark VIII document for all members to read and see that there is a better way of running Australia than simply constraining growth and crushing employment. Let me repeat what US Labour Secretary Robert Reich had to say. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The choice between an American style economy with high employment growth and low wages or a European economy with high wages and lousy employment is a fairly rotten choice.
Australia has come right up the middle, and it has come up the middle again with Accord Mark VIII.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the TWU sign it?
—I warn the member for O'Connor!
—That is all right; it is Thursday.
—I can assist you very easily.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In 1983 Australia's current account deficit was the fifth worst in the OECD; in 1984 our current account deficit was the fourth worst; in 1985 it was the third worst; by 1994 it was the worst, except for Mexico; and now it is the worst in the OECD—even worse than Mexico. Do you regard this as a result of policies that work? Do you regard this as a better way of running Australia or do you now concede your absolute failure on the current account deficit?
—In the years since the government has been in office—
—Yes?
—we have seen the export growth of Australia go from 13 to 22 per cent of GDP.
—What about imports?
—Order! The member for Mayo!
—That is nine per cent of GDP in exports. GDP this year is about $500 billion. That is $45 billion of exports extra—$45,000 million of extra exports.
—Answer the question.
—The member for Mackellar!
—We have also seen two million jobs created in the period. We have seen strong rates of economic growth and enormous restructuring of the Australian economy.
—Look at your record.
—Order! I warn the member for Mackellar!

—Now we have seen put into place a long-term savings plan which will add two to four percentage points of GDP in savings via superannuation and a four percentage point of GDP change by way of the change in the budget balance. This is to deal with the current account deficit which is running at about 2 1/2 per cent beyond the level which is sustainable over the long-term. I notice the deputy leader, in asking this question, failed to mention 1980-81 where at six per cent of GDP under Treasurer John Howard it was the highest, from memory, in the OECD at the time.
—No, it wasn't.
—Six per cent of GDP in 1980-81.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—No, no!

—Order! I remind members again of the provisions of standing order 55. The Prime Minister has been asked a question by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I think he is trying to listen. The Prime Minister has the call.

—At six per cent of GDP in 1980-81 the rot had set in. We had seen the terms of trade fall from the Menzies years when we saw those enormous prices for wheat and wool and asleep at the wheel was the member for Bennelong.
—Oh!

—No, he was not asleep at the wheel; he was watching the petrol on the fire of wages—18 per cent wages growth—he was watching the smashed profits, he was watching the smashed investments. As I said in this House, in 1983 when he walked out of the job he was so happy to be relieved of the responsibility, so happy that it had fallen on this government to carry the burden of his failure to deal with any fundamental change in economic policy. He was a complete flop in terms of the change—
—You should get a new line; this is boring.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
—You are completely boring everyone.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition knows better.
—But he is, Mr Speaker.
—The Leader of the Opposition is not helping to set the example.

—On inflation, on profits, on investment, on wages growth—on all of these things—Australia was in a vulnerable position by the early 1980s, so much so that the current account deficit was six per cent of GDP in 1980-81. Our debt had risen from about five or six per cent of GDP to 30 per cent in the three years after the government came to office; that is, the long-term rot had produced a change in just three years of 30 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In the period the government then substantially stabilised the growth of that debt, so today it is about 36 per cent or 37 per cent of GDP, from memory. That is with the placing offshore of $86 billion of Australian assets. In the imputation of the question from the deputy leader, he failed to mention the fact that we have offshore now $86 billion in private Australian assets, against $7 billion of private Australian assets in 1983-84.

So there is $80 billion of our national debt sitting out there, which has basically been accommodated by this shift in assets offshore by Australians. That is because we have made the judgment that it is better to be in these markets in western Europe, North America and the Asia Pacific than to have the choice of saying that we would basically not have these placements abroad but have a lower level of offshore Australian debt.

Obviously, in Australia's best interests it is better to have these assets offshore, but they must be part of the equation. They are part of the equation with the foreign exchange markets. They know this. That is why when they see the sorts of figures that the deputy leader is referring to they immediately put the other side of the ledger into the account—that is, $135 billion of offshore assets and the $86 billion of offshore private assets, of equity placements offshore. That is why the markets have a much better understanding of the quality of change in economic policy and the balance between the onshore debt and the offshore debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's why they are not investing in Australia.
—Order! The member for Mayo!

—Notice that today we will not get any questions from the opposition about wages policy or about inflation because they are embarrassed to hell about the Accord Mark VIII again, as they always are. As if they could deliver a document saying, `Here we are, we have sown up the work force to two per cent to three per cent inflation over the next four years!' Could you imagine the breast-beating from opposition members if they were able to stand up with any voracity and say, `We have come to an agreement with the work force to have two or three per cent inflation over the next four years; we have a commitment there to 600,000 jobs?' Could you imagine the breast-beating we would get from them?

PARA.TAB: What are they about today? They are not about wages and not about inflation. Today it is only about the current account deficit. It is not about employment. It is not about investment. It is not about growth. It is not about exports. It is not about training and the labour market. It is not about the skills base. It is only about the current account deficit, without even acknowledging these great changes which have taken place and even this great policy change of today and the changes we have seen in Australian assets abroad.

I am afraid the opposition is going to have to do much better. I repeat: the member for Bennelong will always return to the scene of the crime. He will always revisit his old work in the 1970s, or his lack of it, when the current account was at about six per cent of GDP in 1980-81 and former senator John Stone, as Secretary to the Treasury, said in that note to him in the last week of the 1983 election: `Treasurer Howard, this is the biggest fiscal deterioration since the Second World War.' And Treasurer Howard kept it quiet in the dying days of the 1983 election. He hid it—so-called transparency and honesty in economic policy making! A few of us around here have a good memory for J.W. Howard's tricks, or the absence of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and it also concerns Accord Mark VIII. Can the minister inform the House of the implications today's Accord agreement will have for employment growth? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

It is interesting to observe that in Monday's Sydney Morning Herald Ross Gittins, having talked about the things that are important to get unemployment down and also paying due regard to the initiatives under Working Nation, said:

ANSWER.PARA: So, if all these things come together . . . we may come a lot closer to 5 per cent unemployment in 2000 than many people dare to hope.

I think it is a very important recognition by a significant economics writer that these are policies that are working. Today, Accord Mark VIII is another one of those significant things coming together. What Accord Mark VIII does is commit the parties, and the trade union movement in particular, to working with the government to achieve a minimum 600,000 new jobs over the life of the agreement. Another important dimension of the Accord is the way in which it describes the significance of achieving that five per cent target. It says:

In other words, not only is it an Accord that is important for jobs growth and the jobs target, but it is an Accord that is important to sensible wage outcomes and to low inflation. This is an Accord that, in terms of its 600,000 jobs, builds on the commitment in the previous accord—Accord Mark VII and its commitment to 500,000 jobs over three years. As has already been noted, we have achieved in excess of 600,000 jobs in two years.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has indicated that we will not hear much from the opposition about the Accord in relation to wages and jobs, but let us just recall what the former opposition spokesman on industrial relations, now the Leader of the Opposition, had to say when Accord Mark VII was handed down.
Back on 20 February 1993 he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Accord mark 7 is, `an insult to the intelligence'. Its target of 500,000 jobs over the next three years is `unachievable'.
He said that on 20.2.93. Further, he went on—seeing he was so buoyed up by the fact that this was not only unachievable but it was an insult to the intelligence to say:
It insults the intelligence of the Australian people to suggest Accord Mark VII can help generate a half a million jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say that?

—None of the more than 600,000 people who have jobs feel insulted. Yours is the insult to the intelligence of the people by hiding your policies in terms of how you would produce job outcomes. But, in that same article, the Leader of the Opposition went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: We would not have an Accord approach.

So here is a document that is producing jobs growth, producing low inflation, producing a wages policy that underpins that low inflation, commitment to superannuation and building the national savings of the country—and you would reject it. The simple fact of the matter is: these are people bereft of ideas. The reason they are bereft of ideas is that they have no talent sitting on that side of the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I remind the member for Fisher about the provisions of standing order 58. I might say the same to the member for Maranoa.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it not true, Prime Minister, that, since the inception of the prices and incomes accords in 1983, real average weekly earnings have fallen by 0.4 per cent; the distribution of income, even allowing for the social wage, has become more unequal; Australia has suffered its worst recession in 60 years; unemployment went to more than a million Australians a few years ago; and the current account deficit has now become the worst in the industrialised world—worse even than Mexico's? With this record, is it any wonder that Australian workers have grown tired of your overblown and empty rhetoric?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave the answer before: two million jobs and a 40 per cent increase in household disposable income—

—No, not rhetoric. This is from the statisticians' records: two million jobs and a 40 per cent increase in household disposable income since 1983. But the import of the question is about the wages of Australians. The Leader of the Opposition has opposed every wage increase since 1981, bar two—the last two safety nets of this government. —Here is a headline in the Australian: `Howard calls for cuts in real wages and delay the wage indexation'. It goes on and on. Let me just repeat some of the things he himself said:

ANSWER.PARA: Wages policy was the Fraser government's weakest point in the economic area.

We did not really try decentralised wage fixing when we were in government . . . We had a schizophrenic approach to wages policy.

blew every recovery with a wage explosion. We did not really try decentralised wage fixing because we were in government.

He is engaged in conversation now. The quotes are a bit too hard for him. All of a sudden he gets interested and his puppeteer friends give him a question or have a conversation when the hard answers come back. He said, `We had a schizophrenic approach to wages policy.' PARA.TAB: Then he talks about the wages of Australians. He wants a system where the no disadvantage test does not apply. That is the system he wants. He wants to turn Australians out of the wages system to a system where their meal allowances, overtime and penalty rates are no longer part of their wages. He wants to drive them back to award minimums and award minimums only. If workers move out of the wages system—and 1.6 million Australians change jobs—they lose all the award protections. John Howard is out there to butcher working Australians on their wages, just as he has always done. He has been the complete tory on all this. He has opposed all the wage increases. He is basically about ripping the low paid down. As I have said in this House on a number of occasions, what an objective! Here is an economy with an enormous strength and wealth. What a philosophy! What a view of life! He is saying, `Here I am.
