But that is what he has always been about.

The member for Mayo has been interjecting. He was born with a silver cutlery set in his mouth. I can understand him taking these views. He has always held the working people in contempt. But the member for Bennelong was a bowser boy at Canterbury. What a bowser boy has against working people and what he can gain by trying to grind their wages down has got me beat. Let us understand this. Page 6 of the Accord states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Accord partners are opposed to any actions which seek to undermine: the efficiency and effectiveness of award protection; collective bargaining; the no disadvantage test—

The no disadvantage test will let people move out into the enterprise bargaining stream so that they are not disadvantaged. If they are disadvantaged, they get picked up under the safety net arrangements. Increases over the period will be $9 to $12 and, for those who are on award minimums, $11 to $14. What could be possibly wrong with it, other than an absolute cynical desire to rip away at the award protection and push wages down?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at you. You are all saying, `No. No. No.' You are mostly scrubbers. Most of you have not got any ability or two zacks to your name, but you still want to hop into working people, as if you were some sort of landed gentry. You are the remnants of Australia's failed upper class, the bunyip aristocracy hopping into working people and trying to cut their wages.

PARA.TAB: Let this House understand that this opposition has two key policies—to cut into the social wage of Australians and to rip the guts out of Medicare. They are the opposition's two policies to try to drive Australians back to the sort of jungle John Howard was talking about when he said, `We had no wages policy in the 1980s. That was our record.' The Liberals never change. The coalition and the tories never change.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Prime Minister, just one moment. Those on my left! Order! The Prime Minister has the call.

—I will finish on this point. They never change. It would not matter if it was Stanley Melbourne Bruce, Earle Page or John Howard, it is always the same message: hop into working people, give them a hiding, rip away at their wages, rip away at the safety net and—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Mitchell!
—if they have any decent social protection like Medicare, we will hop into that too. I know the tactic of the coalition is to disrupt the House—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister will just wait. I now issue a general warning in this place. The Prime Minister in conclusion.

—His tactic is to disrupt the parliament, to have his members behind him screech, roar and interject so that there is not a sensible debate and the House becomes disorderly as a result of his leadership. That is all that matters to him. The public opprobrium is for him to wear.

PARA.TAB: Let me say that we on this side of the House will always stand for the rights of working Australians for a decent wage, for a decent social wage and for decent protection via schemes like Medicare. These are the things that Australians expect from a government like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It also concerns Accord Mark VIII. What contribution will Accord Mark VIII make to maintaining fairness in Australia's industrial relations system? Will Accord Mark VIII ensure that those workers who need protection get it?

—I am delighted to answer the honourable member's question about Accord Mark VIII, the Accord that is so much in keeping with the totality of our IR reforms, and, I might say, the Accord that continues the process of encouraging federal award employees into the enterprise bargaining stream. In doing so, at the same time we maintain fairness and at the same time we maintain employee protection, the very hallmarks of our policies.

PARA.TAB: Already under the framework established by the Industrial Relations Reform Act, we have seen some 60 per cent of all federal award workers covered by enterprise bargains—a figure more than double that achieved by any state system. At the same time we have achieved high economic growth; we have achieved record jobs growth; and we have done so at a time of industrial harmony, low inflation and wages moderation. It has been a fantastic outcome. Accord Mark VIII released today will maintain that. It will do so while delivering responsible safety net wage increases to the low paid and to all employees unable to secure enterprise agreements.

For the benefit of the House, I will just outline the five or six key elements of that Accord announced today: firstly, a strong emphasis on workplace bargaining underpinned by a comprehensive award safety net—the sort of award safety net that you would rip away; secondly, safety net adjustments from $9 to $14 to protect those unable to benefit from bargaining, particularly the low paid; thirdly, the maintenance of an effective and comprehensive award safety net—the award safety net those opposite would destroy—but also making it more understandable, user-friendly and relevant to the needs of enterprises and individual workplaces; fourthly, support for phased-in employee contributions to superannuation to coincide with safety net wage increases supplemented by employer and government contributions; and, finally, assistance to families and the encouragement of work practices that better balance work and family responsibilities. These are the key elements of Accord Mark VIII.

In combination, this Accord and the Industrial Relations Reform Act guarantee Australia's industrial harmony. They guarantee the continuity of the processes of decentralising our labour market, but they do so while maintaining all the vital protections required to give employees confidence as they move into the bargaining process. Together they deliver workplace change and productivity increases, but they ensure that employees get a fair share of the dividend. Whether it is through bargaining or through safety net adjustments, no-one under this system is left behind.

The opposition can deliver no such promises at all. All it can promise is the end of industrial peace, the end of wage moderation and the end of worker protection. That is what its policies stand for. The anti-worker policies that have been advanced by the member for Flinders and the Leader of the Opposition can only return us to the industrial chaos, the high unemployment and the inflation that we saw from them in the early 1980s.

This week the member for Flinders spoke about safety net adjustments, but there is never any detail about safety nets or any mechanism for how the coalition would adjust its existing policy. The coalition can guarantee only that workers will be worse off—because, as the Prime Minister said today, it stands for the abolition of the no-disadvantage test. That is one of the great fundamentals underpinning our whole system. It is a fundamental that you would remove. The very cornerstone of your policy is to remove the no-disadvantage test and to replace the award system with four miserly minimums: four weeks annual leave, two weeks non-cumulative sick leave, 12 months unpaid maternity leave and a minimum hourly wage—not even a minimum weekly wage. That is all we get from the opposition.

When it comes to workers' penalty rates, their leave loadings, their shift allowances, their overtime and their family leave—all these things are on the chopping block under the opposition's policies. No contrast could be more stark: the opposition's recipe for industrial mayhem and for wage slashing, and the proud accord we have released today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to the statement he has repeated a couple of times today that real household disposable income increased by 40 per cent between 1983 and 1995. I ask the Prime Minister: will he confirm that the increase in the number of households between 1983 and 1995 means that real household disposable income has increased on average by less than one-third of one per cent per year per household?
—The increase per capita which I read out in this House in question time a few weeks ago was, from memory, 20 per cent. That is household disposable income, which is measured by—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have repeatedly reminded and warned members in this place of the provisions of standing order 55. The Prime Minister is entitled to be heard in silence and he will.

—Household disposable income measures wages, salaries, supplements, pensions and benefits, and the per capita measure is after tax. That has seen a per capita rise, I think, of 20 per cent. I need to go back and check that the number is 20 per cent. It is certainly 40 per cent for households over the period.
—No.

—I know you do not like the number, but that is the fact—because more households are in work. We have had two million jobs created. Do you think those two million people do not earn anything? What do you think they are doing? Do you think they are martians: they come and do the work and then disappear at night or something and are not paid at the end of the week? Of course there has been a massive improvement.

PARA.TAB: We have given you the numbers for the rate of employment growth. They have been three to four times the employment growth of the Fraser years. They are three times the OECD average. There is no economic mix in the OECD area that has been producing more employment with decent levels of remuneration. This is the point that Robert Reich, the US Labour Secretary, made.

TALK.START.PARA: —In New Zealand the rates have gone down.
—You are not running New Zealand.

—You always talk about an individual contract system. You talk about the US system, but when the United States Labour Secretary says, `We have had more employment growth than any other country, but we have had falling real wages for 14 years'—
—You should look at what is happening there.
—You are wrong when you talk about us. We are not worried about them.

—Order! The member for O'Connor and the member for Burke are again conducting an exchange across the chamber. I will give you the opportunity to do it outside. I invoke the provisions of standing order 304A against both of you.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The honourable members for O'Connor and Burke thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —With those most revealing remarks from someone with such standing in the system as the Secretary of Labour in the United States about the system that he presides over, I would have thought that at least some members of the coalition here would ask, `What sort of a system is that?' Enormous growth in American wealth and high levels of profitability but a continuing decline in the real wages of Americans over a sustained period of 14 years is an appalling outcome.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members would have seen references I have made in the House about a number of the European countries and the fact that they have high wages growth but very lousy work force growth. In Australia, we have come up the middle. We have strong employment growth and a sensible basis for remuneration. But we do want to look after the less advantaged with a safety net. It is a safety net that the opposition is opposed to. It wants flexibility. But it does not want flexibility upwards; it wants flexibility downwards.

I repeat the point: why anybody would want to hop into people on $20,000 a year and reduce their wages, or reduce the wages of people on average weekly earnings, those on $33,000 a year, is beyond me. I can see no economic point to it—not when the profit share in the economy now is so high. What are you arguing for—a higher level of profits to GDP? It knows no historic precedent. Why would you get it by tugging away at the people on the bottom? That is your vicious prejudicial position against working people. That has always been your vicious prejudicial position against working people. Even the people who run businesses do not have your position. It is just the snaky ideological position of your political party.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Order!

—The MTIA came to see me, the Treasurer and the Minister for Industrial Relations the other day. I did not hear from them any such claims for flexibility downwards. I did not hear them saying, `Take away the no disadvantage test.' I did not hear them saying that the safety net did not matter. I did not hear them say these things, because they do not hold those views. The only people who hold those views are those with the narrow, vicious, political interests of the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: The member's question is wrongly based because of the fact that we have had a two-million job growth. Can you imagine if the opposition had had two-million job growth? We would never hear the end of it. If you had two per cent to three per cent employment growth, we would never hear the end of it. Yet when we go through these things, it says, `What's next? What about the current account deficit?' Well, what about the growth in employment?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen reports that Australia is heading for an `economic apocalypse' and that `severe corrective measures' are required? What is the Treasurer's response to these reports?

—I thank the member for Werriwa for his question because it does raise an interesting issue. I have seen these reports. They relate to comments made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition yesterday following the release of the OECD half-yearly economic outlook. The sorts of things that he talked about, as the member for Werriwa said in his question, were `an economic apocalypse occurring unless drastic action is taken'—
—No, no, no; quote it correctly.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—He should not misquote.

—and `they, the government, ought to be announcing some severe corrective measures which they will take to fix things up', and `what is absolutely clear now is that the government has been running a fiscal policy which is too loose and the OECD has made that point'. The fact is that the OECD made no such point. What the OECD said in its half-yearly economic outlook was that the forecasts for Australia were very similar to those the government has. They were slightly different at the margin because it was talking about calendar years, not financial years.

PARA.TAB: But with that minor difference they essentially endorsed our forecast. What they said was that we would have economic growth in 1995 of 3.8 per cent and in 1996 of 3.5 per cent—no sign of an economic apocalypse there. What needs to be clearly understood is that those rates are quite high by the standards of other countries. In 1995 that rate of 3.8 per cent is the fifth highest of all Western developed countries, that is, there are only four other countries with a higher rate of growth expected in 1995. For 1996 we are the fourth highest, that is, there are only three others with a higher rate of growth forecast. So, far from saying this country is facing an economic apocalypse, the forecast of the OECD is that this country is going to grow with the very top rates of growth in the OECD this year and next year.

What about employment growth? The forecast by the OECD for this year, 1995, is 2.8 per cent employment growth and for 1996 2.6 per cent. Again, these are relatively very high rates of employment growth—the equal third highest rate of employment growth in the whole of the Western developed world in 1995 and in 1996 the third highest. No sign of economic apocalypse there. The OECD expects the continuance of very good outcomes with relatively high rates of economic and employment growth. What the deputy opposition leader said yesterday was based on the fact that we had a forecast for the current account deficit by the OECD in 1995 of six per cent. That reflects the six per cent figure that is in the budget for 1994-95. So there is nothing new in that figure; it is just endorsing the figure that we had in our budget. Like us, the OECD forecasts that that current account number is going to come down. They say that in 1996 it will be 5.3 per cent. They do not see it getting worse; they see it coming down with the breaking of the drought and reduced growth in imports.

The government cannot be accused of being complacent about the current account. We have taken very substantial steps in this budget, as everyone in this House knows, to address the need to reduce the current account. We have done that by reducing the public sector dissaving through moving to budget surpluses and by the very important additional development built up under the Accord process, which we have talked about a lot today, to develop the new superannuation initiative, which will be an enormous boost to household and national savings in years to come.

What is the opposition's position in respect of both of these major steps towards reducing the current account deficit? In relation to the budget opposition members are desperately trying to prevent the corrective measures that the government has announced and is trying to put in place being put through the parliament. They are opposing $1 1/2 billion worth of tax increases this year and $2.6 billion worth next year. So whilst we have the Deputy Leader of the Opposition parading around saying that what this country needs is severe corrective measures he is doing his very best to stop the corrective measures in the budget from being put into place. What abundant hypocrisy!

It does not stop at taxation, either. The opposition is also opposing expenditure cuts. We have already seen the opposition in this budget debate oppose the cuts in child care which limit the number of non-work related hours of child care to 12. They are saying that they will not support that; they are voting against that. That saves $150 million over the four years of the forward estimates. They are against expenditure cuts as well as increased taxes. So we have the broad `Oh, yes. Let us have severe corrective measures. There is a terrible problem.' But when it comes to dealing with individual measures, which this government has responsibly put before this parliament, to reduce the pressure on interest rates and to reduce the current account deficit, they are opposing them one by one. That is incredible hypocrisy and shows how shallow this opposition is.

The same goes for the superannuation initiatives. The opposition opposes them too. They are not in support of those initiatives to give a major boost to household and national savings. What we are seeing is an opposition opposing much of the measures that the government announced to ensure that the current account deficit is reduced and then calling for more severe corrective measures.

The fact is that this economy needs the budget measures to be passed. The forecasts that are made by the OECD are a follow-on from its spelling out in that document of the budget measures—that is, in the broad, the move to surplus. On the basis of that it says this country will grow by almost four per cent in 1995, will be at the top level of the OECD and will have similar results on employment with those measures.

If those opposite try to take away those measures, they are simply sabotaging our efforts to produce good economic outcomes in this country. That is what is being done. Doing that and at the same time saying this country needs more severe corrective measures is just an extraordinary amount of abundant hypocrisy and it shows how abysmally unsuitable the opposition is to govern this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister receive advance notice or an advance copy of the Governor-General's speech delivered last night in Queensland? What is the Prime Minister's position on the issues raised by the Governor-General—specifically the issue of full recognition of same sex couples, including the right to adopt children, and the issue of euthanasia?

So the whole basis of the question was wrong. That may be an inconvenient number for those opposite, but that is the progress which has been made by the government for Australians under the Accord process.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Telephone Services for Low Income Earners

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Can the minister advise the House about action being taken to improve access to home telephones for people on low incomes? Can he also advise the House about the outlook for other changes to telephone services?

—Given the alleged interest of the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Kooyong in the interests of low income earners, let us see what they have to say about the new service which the honourable member for Chifley was kind enough to ask me about. Last November I advised the House that Telecom would be trialling a new service to make it easier for low income earners to get a telephone on at home. It is the government's view that, with telephone carriers investing billions of dollars in cable and with telephone companies investing large sums of money in improving the mobile telephone service around the country, we think the least they can do is also make it easier for the one million Australians who do not have a phone on at home by bringing in this service as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday the chief executive of Telstra, Frank Blount, and I launched this new service, which is called InContact. It will allow households to receive calls and to ring the 000 emergency number. InContact will be provided with no rental, connection or service charges. However, where there is not an existing telephone line there will be a connection fee. But the good news is that, in the 20 of per cent of cases where Telecom estimates there will be a need for some cabling to be done, people will have that credited against the normal connection fee if customers subsequently upgrade to the standard telephone service.

Mr Speaker, as you would know, this service has been trialled in Wollongong. The feedback suggests people who are looking for work find it easier because they can leave a contact number with prospective employers, and people believed they were safer and more secure knowing they could contact the emergency services number, especially those with young children and especially the elderly and retirees. Also, families and friends were more confident that they could ring to check people were safe, and children found it easier to ring their parents to let them know where they were or that they were safe.

At the launch yesterday, Gwen George from the Older Women's Network made a point about how important the telephone service is for elderly Australians in particular. She gave examples of where people do not buy food because they know how important it is to maintain that telephone contact. We have had support from the Telecom Australia Consumer Council including the Smith Family and ACOSS, and The Pensioner and Superannuation Federation; who said that this is a great new initiative.

There was one lone voice across the Commonwealth saying he was against this new service. It was the voice of the spokesman for the Liberal Party on communications, Senator Alston. In Senator Alston's press release yesterday he said that `this new service was a limited and short-term solution'. So it is the view of the Liberal Party that it is a limited and short-term option to help people who are looking for work be able to leave a contact number with prospective employers.

It is the view of the Liberal Party that it is a limited and short-term solution to let pensioners and isolated families be able to ring the 000 emergency services number. It is the view of the official Liberal Party spokesman that it is a limited and short-term solution to allow families and friends to be able to contact relatives at night; they would rather force them out of their homes to use the public telephone boxes. That being the official view, which was expressed by the Liberal Party spokesman on communications, I think we are entitled to know: is that also the view of the Leader of the Opposition? Does the Leader of the Opposition think that the InContact service is a limited and short-term solution? Do you agree with Senator Alston? There is no answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Could you rule whether it is proper for ministers to ask us questions? If it is, may we answer them?
—I am quite happy to answer him.
—Order! Resume your seat. I am not into that.
—I will be pleased to answer. May I, Mr Speaker?
—Order! Just contain yourself for a minute. I remind all members, including ministers, that they must respond through the chair.

—Does that mean that they can ask us questions, Mr Speaker? Through you, Mr Speaker, I say that we are entitled to ask: does the Leader of the Opposition support Senator Alston? Does he think that the InContact service is a limited and short-term solution that should not be made available to the one million Australians out there who do not have a home telephone? I can certainly tell this House that all of the feedback from the people in Wollongong has been that they think it is a great service for them. In three states alone, Telecom has had more than 1,000 calls to the inquiry number from people saying that they are interested in this new service.

PARA.TAB: Is it any wonder that we have the support of the welfare organisations and the people who have trialled the product in Wollongong? The only one who is saying he is against it is the Leader of the Opposition.

The other comment Senator Alston made yesterday was that he believed this new service was creating a two-tier phone system and an information underclass, especially for rural and regional Australia. Those of us on this side of the House know that the quickest way to get a two-tier phone system and an information underclass, especially in rural and regional Australia, is to sell Telecom, which is what those opposite want to do.

No doubt, if the Leader of the Opposition had his way and the new owners of Telecom included substantial shareholdings by foreign telephone companies, we would then be entitled to ask: how would the Leader of the Opposition guarantee that those foreign telephone companies would maintain the services in rural and regional Australia? How could the Leader of the Opposition assure the member for Parkes that the foreign telephone companies would not cut back the services in Broken Hill? How could he assure people that services would not be cut back in Mackay or in other National Party electorates? When you look at the opposition spokesman's briefing papers for the opposition shadow cabinet, you can see there are no policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on another point of order. This really is going on for far too long. As you know, questions have to be short and to the point so those opposite can answer them. I suggest that you instruct the minister to wind up because this call really is taking a long time.
—Put with all the sincerity that a fop could put it.
—Order! The minister in conclusion.

—I agree with the Prime Minister. Let me also say that is why when you look at Senator Alston's submissions to shadow cabinet it is like a headline clipping service rather than a development of policy. That is because he is afraid to say what it means for the National Party if he sells Telecom.

—You have not heard of the CSOs, obviously. My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister again: do you support the full recognition of same sex couples, including the right to adopt children?
—I have my own personal and social views on these things, but these are not a matter for government policy. We do not make laws governing these things in Australia.
—You don't have a policy.
—You will never see the day when I shimmy shammy like you on the republic—four positions in three days.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left.
—That is a day you will never see! You stand for nothing. You are out of your age and out of your depth. You are a remnant from days gone by.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will just wait. Order! The Prime Minister will be heard in silence.
—I have not seen the content of the Governor-General's speech.
—No, but answer the question.
—Order!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my left.
—I could ask the Leader of the National Party about his attitude towards the Jewish community. It would be just as relevant.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training.
—He doesn't have the guts to express a view.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right. It is getting a bit late in the afternoon. Let us get this wrapped up. The member for Leichhardt has the call.
—Has the minister's attention been drawn to claims by the United Graziers Association of Queensland that students of farm families do not qualify for Austudy? Are these claims accurate?

—I thank the member for Leichhardt for his question. I am aware that the United Graziers Association of Queensland has written to a number of provincial and rural newspapers on this matter. Its claim is that `the government has consistently maintained that unless a farm is in exceptional circumstances, students from farm families do not qualify for Austudy'. This is untrue, but, worse than that, these allegations have the effect of deterring farming families with student dependents from applying for Austudy when they may be eligible.

PARA.TAB: Austudy is a financial grant to help students from less well off families. It is income and assets tested. If a family operates a farm or a business in which the owner works for more than 17 1/2 hours a week—and we are not talking about Pitt Street farmers, obviously—Austudy grants a generous discount on the business or farm assets. For Austudy purposes, only 50 per cent of the net worth of the farm assets is counted. Net means the value after subtracting any debt owed on the assets. A family can have a business, such as a farm, under these rules valued at around $750,000 net—that is, three-quarters of a million dollars—and still get Austudy.

TALK.START.PARA: —But a Prime Minister can have a $2.5 million home.
—The member for Maranoa constantly interjects. I have rebuked him this afternoon. I now invoke standing order 304A in respect of him as well. The honourable member is suspended for one hour.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The honourable member for Maranoa thereupon withdrew from the chamber—

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that the member for Maranoa is an accomplice in this. It is a pity he will not be here to hear the rest of the answer. For farmers, the value of the home and curtilage of up to two hectares is also a deductible item. The United Grazier Association refers in its letter to exceptional circumstances. What it is talking about are areas declared as drought affected special circumstances. In those areas no assets test applies at all.

PARA.TAB: According to the latest ABARE statistics, the average net equity which the owner holds in broadacre farms in Australia, given over to mixtures of livestock and crops, is $663,630. That is below the Austudy assets test threshold, even without deducting the value of the house and the surrounding land. For wheat and for other crop farms the ABARE figures show the average net value of about $790,000, which is about $40,000 over the assets limit. But, when you deduct the value of the house and curtilage, again it comes below the threshold. For sheep and beef farms pretty much the same applies. The average equity is $790,000. For sheep properties the average net value is $707,000, which is again within the assets test.

In other words, the average farming family is not disqualified under the Austudy assets test. Of the 208 farms valued by the Australian Valuation Office in New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia for Austudy purposes in 1993-94, only 33 were over the limit in gross value. More than five farm families in six had no difficulty qualifying under the assets test. Apart from that, there is the drought assistance package which I mentioned which provides a safety net for those in special circumstances. The Australian Valuation Office will provide valuations where weather or market conditions have forced the value of a property down.

I should point out that farming families can apply for Austudy at any time during the year if their assets fall below the threshold. I would ask all honourable members, particularly those members of the National Party, including the member for Maranoa, to disown the claims of the UGA. Telling farmers that they should not apply for assistance is quite wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that earlier today Senator Evans told the Senate that he had written to French Prime Minister Juppe after the election of President Chirac indicating Australia's opposition to nuclear testing but that Senator Evans refused to table the letter? Is the Prime Minister aware that subsequently today Senator Evans has revealed that in his letter to Prime Minister Juppe he did not make any direct representation whatsoever concerning French nuclear testing but simply congratulated him on his appointment? Is it not now obvious that the government wanted to hide Senator Evans's letter to the French Prime Minister because that letter is proof that from the time of the election of President Chirac the government has taken a soft and weak stand on the issue of French nuclear testing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The adolescent fantasies about gunboat diplomacy from the member for Mayo are just too much. This is somebody who a few years ago was saying that the nuclear-free zone treaty was basically an anti-French treaty and little else. He said that it would swamp ultimately the Western alliance in the Pacific. That was the sort of thing you were saying at the time of the last test.
—You are too weak to answer Tim Fischer's question.
—Order! The member for Mayo!

—Let me make very clear that this government has expressed in very strong terms its objection, its condemnation and its contempt for this decision by the government of France to test these weapons again. I wrote to President Chirac urging him not to take up a weapons testing program—
—Will you table the letter?
—Order! The member for Mayo!
—When the member for Mayo keeps this attack up on Senator Evans, I remind him of the Leader of the Opposition's response. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . what the Government has done is appropriate. I think it's one of those situations that you've got to keep under review and . . . the response today is not necessarily the final response . . . it's never smart in those situations to fire all your shots at once.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was before.
—Order! Just relax.

—As a consequence of the government's view—it was annoyed, angry, disappointed about what had been decided by the government of France—of the very wilful decision that that country had taken, I wrote, after a cabinet discussion of the issue—
—Table the letter.
—Order! The member for Mayo, on the last warning!
—On 8 June, I wrote to President Chirac urging the continuation of France's moratorium on nuclear testing—
—Table the letter.

—I will table the letter if it suits me to table the letter. You don't get letters between governments. You lost the last election. You came second, mate. On polling night, you came in second. As a consequence, the government met as a cabinet to consider the position in detail and I wrote to the President, as I say, on 8 June.

PARA.TAB: The moment the announcement was made by President Chirac on 14 June I immediately issued a statement deploring the decision. Defence activities were frozen until the cessation of French testing, visits by French military aircraft or vessels, except those relating to humanitarian or surveillance activities which benefit South Pacific countries, were denied and the transits which, in any way, supported the testing program were forbidden. I foreshadowed contact with Pacific leaders. On the same day, the acting foreign minister, Senator McMullan, called in the French ambassador and issued a formal protest. Our ambassador made similar protests in Paris.

On 15 June, I issued a statement on behalf of my South Pacific colleagues condemning the French decision and announcing that a delegation from the forum would go immediately to France. On 15 and 16 June, Australian representatives at the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva and the UN in New York took action to protest the French decision.

On 19 June, I moved a motion in this House condemning the decision. On 20 June, Australian time, the foreign minister, acting as leader of the forum delegation, conveyed to French foreign minister de Charette the strong opposition of forum countries to the decision. On the same day, I sent an immediate report on the results of the delegation meeting to other forum heads of government and asked them to consider what further steps the region might take to reinforce our concern about the French decision.

Senator Evans returned to Australia last night. He and I had a discussion upon his return. The government, as we have said all along, will now consider the report from Senator Evans and what further steps might be taken to register our opposition. We have begun receiving responses from our partners in the South Pacific. We look forward to their replies and being in a position to announce some coordinated regional responses.

I think that on those issues the government's position has been a very strong one. Let me say this also the government of France: the decision taken by the government of France is no deterrent against the greatest nuclear threats now facing Europe and the world—that is, the emergence of new nuclear weapon states, the rotting carcasses of old Soviet reactors in eastern Europe, stockpiles of degrading nuclear weapons and weapons systems and contaminated nuclear sites.

It is worth reminding the House there are 21 Chernobyl type RBMK reactors, which are considered to have an inherent design fault, operating in Russia, Lithuania and the Ukraine. When I saw Prime Minister Balladur in France over a year or so ago, he said to me that one of the great concerns facing his government and Europe is the state of the 21 Chernobyl type reactors that are sitting in Russia, Lithuania and the Ukraine. We have seen already the damage that came from Chernobyl.

Could you imagine if there were any further reactor failures of the kind we saw spread across 21 reactors which have to be, over time, replaced? If the government of France wants to worry about the protection of its people, it needs to worry about a nuclear cloud over Europe, threatening a civilisation of people, which can come in a very real way from the design fault and collapse of this reactor system in Russia, Lithuania and the Ukraine. There are also 100 nuclear reactors from an estimated 50 idle Soviet submarines—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the Prime Minister may well be giving us some interesting statistics but, pursuant to standing order 145, he ought to reply to the very specific question from the honourable member for Mayo, which related to a letter Senator Evans allegedly wrote to the French Prime Minister.
—Order! The Prime Minister is responding to what I thought this House considered to be a very serious issue, and the Prime Minister has the call.

—As I said, there are around 100 nuclear reactors from an estimated 50 idle Soviet submarines, which will need to be dismantled and the spent nuclear fuel treated and safely stored. They are laying around Vladivostok. They are laying around in the other eastern ports of the former Soviet Union. They are laying around the Black Sea. They are laying off continental Europe. These are the real threats to France and to the other countries of western Europe and not some imagined threat, now that the cold war has finished, needing to calibrate the capacity of their weapons in the stockpile of the variety they are testing at Mururoa.
—What about the letter to the French Prime Minister?
—They are the real things.
—What about the letter to the French Prime Minister?
—I name the member for Fisher.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) put:
That the member for Fisher be suspended from the service of the House.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This being the honourable member's second suspension during this year, the suspension is for the remainder of this sitting and the next three consecutive sittings.

—Mr Speaker, I conclude on these points. I would have thought that opposition members would be concerned about the state of Western Europe in terms of these reactors and not have interjected in the way in which they did.

PARA.TAB: Let me make it very clear: as far as the government is concerned, we will keep focusing on the nuclear weapons proliferation issue. We will keep Australia's best endeavours going towards these things, such as chemical weapons and the comprehensive test ban treaty. We will be doing all in our power to basically stop the spread of these weapons to non-weapon states. We will try to stop the diversion of these materials and we will keep reminding the French, amongst others, of the imminent prospect of some catastrophic failure to their north in those programs which do genuinely put the French population at some severe risk—but, unfortunately, as well, not just the French population but the population of Western Europe.
Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister table the notes he was reading from earlier and the letter that he sent to President Chirac?
—Order! Resume your seat.
—If not, what are you trying—
—Resume your seat; do not push it.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—Twice during question time, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) misrepresented my position in personal references to me. He claimed that, during the period of the Fraser government, Australia had the worst current account deficit in the OECD. That is completely wrong. The worst current account deficit recorded during that period was minus 4.8 per cent of GDP. During that year, five other nations in the OECD area recorded worse current account deficits. That was the first piece of deception on the part of the Prime Minister. The second was when he quoted from the doorstop I gave in Queensland last week regarding French nuclear tests. He omitted to inform the House that that doorstop was given before the pusillanimous response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans).
—As an addition to that, I table a set of statistics which show that the current account deficit reached six per cent when the current Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer.
—That is not the argument.
—That is not the argument.
