INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The continuing failure of the Government to deliver higher living standards as a result of its inability and unwillingness to provide the necessary leadership to introduce genuine labour market reform.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —When I put the MPI in at quarter to 12, little did I know that I would be starting so late and little did I know that we would have just enjoyed a classic, cameo performance from the government during question time. In a way, that demonstrates all I want to say about the failures of the accord during the last 12 or 13 years.

PARA.TAB: Not only were we entertained by the inferences of the non-answer of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the social policy question when he said, `That is a matter for the states'—a novel position for him!—not only were we subjected to the usual personal abuse when he was asked reasonable questions about the conduct of the government; not only did we have diatribe references to the coalition as offering `snaky ideology'; and not only did we have claims that the coalition would `cut the wages of Australians', `cut the guts out of Medicare' and `hop into working people', which is the usual performance recipe—

TALK.START.PARA: —The tired old rhetoric.

—That is the usual performance, with the tired, old, worn out rhetoric, as the member for Goldstein so properly reminds us. The Prime Minister even went back to my predecessor in the seat of Flinders, Stanley Melbourne Bruce. For heaven's sake, he used to get around the electorate with polo ponies and spats. How desperate would you have to be to make such a reference? In a sense—
—Do you have polo ponies?

—I am out of horses. Whilst the Prime Minister's performance has its usual entertainment value, you would have to say that, in a way, it is a very sad reflection on the state of public debate in Australia.

PARA.TAB: When you think about it, the history of economic management in recent years for a lot of Australians has been no laughing matter. It was again a classic, I thought, that the two principal operators for the labour movement in this country—the Prime Minister of a Labor government and the head of the ACTU—should appear on television to announce the latest political deal that they have done. The perception they were creating was one of Moses coming down from Mount Sinai with the word in tablets of stone. Yet the reality is a very different one for many Australians.

The truth is that the accord is not an instrument for constructive economic reform to provide benefits to the average working Australians, but a political deal to foster the political position of this government and to keep this government in office. It would be a good thing if an accord were directed to genuine economic reforms but, sadly, after 12 years of this government that has not been the case.

Let us look at the history of a few of the accords. The accord arose out of Bob Hawke's win back in 1983 when Labor came into office. That accord saw the government go on a spending spree, the like of which we had not seen since Whitlam. It led to massive demand pressures in the Australian economy and, as has happened on so many occasions in Australian economic history, it basically blew out the current account deficit and led to the current Prime Minister announcing that Australia was on the path to a banana republic and to the economic policy of the following few years.

That is not the only example of the accord I would remind the House of. The 1989 accord was a classic in itself. The 1989 accord included some significant tax increases. That fed into demand. Again, as has so often happened, that led to a blow-out of the current account deficit. Whilst promising as the government went into the 1990 election that we were going to have a soft landing, the government so jacked up interest rates that it brought on the worst recession in this country's history since the Great Depression of the 1930s. So much for the accord.

All through this period we have had promises of better economic management but in reality a different picture. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) said, as Australia attempts to go past a growth rate of about three per cent, we always, given the current structure of this economy, blow the current account deficit. In 1983, ours was the fifth worst in the OECD; in 1984, it was the fourth worst in the OECD; in 1985, it was the third worst in the OECD; by 1994, it was the worst in the OECD except for Mexico; and, in 1995, we finally get to the top of the tree—we are worse than all in the OECD, including Mexico.

It is an interesting reflection to go back to one of the few times the Prime Minister has ever really told the Australian public the truth about the Australian economy. It was on 14 May 1986 that he said that we were heading towards a banana republic. If we are to give those many hundreds of thousands of Australians who today are unemployed the real chance of a job as we go through to the year 2000, we will have to do a hell of a lot better than three per cent.

Only last year the Prime Minister said that if you could not do four per cent then you ought to get out of the business. When he is asked that question, he always fudges the answer. People say to him, `We are not at four per cent now. So are we not matching your own criteria for your continued stay as Prime Minister?' He says, `Oh, well, we are near four per cent: we are 3.25; we are 3.75.' The fact is that we are nowhere near four per cent. We are moving away from four per cent. The prospect is not of more jobs in the future but of fewer jobs, particularly of full-time jobs.

If you look not only at the current account deficit situation, you see that the underlying nub of this debate is whether or not Australia can achieve the gains in efficiency in the way in which we run our economy so that the average Australian family can enjoy a higher standard of living. If you look at labour productivity in Australia—I do not have the figures for the last two or three years—the labour productivity figures have picked up during the recession, which is a cyclical effect. But, if you take the figures from 1985 to 1991, the latest OECD figures which are available—
Mr Brereton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to that if you like, if time permits. Give me an extension of time, Minister, and I will give you a real burst and give you something to answer, instead of the usual rhetoric we have from you. Over that six-year period on only one occasion did Australia do better on labour productivity than our OECD trading partners. People should ask themselves: after 12 years of Labor, am I any better off? The answer is no. They are not better off because those opposite oppose the sorts of changes that would make our economy a far more efficient place and that would give people real prospects for increases in the future.

PARA.TAB: People should ask themselves: why it is that we have a poor productivity result? They do not have to take the opposition's view on this; they can take the latest OECD economic survey on Australia. The language the OECD uses is sort of Byzantine, polite, indirect and very often constrained, but its message on the labour market is crystal clear. The OECD report says that the industrial relations system still remains very complex and highly prescriptive. It says that our industrial relations reforms generated considerable confusion about the role of the commission and unions, and that, as a result, the negotiation of enterprise agreements is time consuming and costly. The OECD report says that it was questionable `whether awards are best suited to perform a safety net function' and that the complexity of the safety net structure constrains `the capacity of the labour force to adjust to change'.

It is the change we want, Minister. You stand here and say you are moving us in the direction of that change, but the OECD report—it is very informative; only a short read, but well worth reading—notes that the government's rhetoric on enterprise bargaining goes back to 1987 and that even the changes made in 1988-89 were cumbersome, too complex and unable to achieve the productivity benefits that we need. So you have been talking about these things for years and years, but the Australian people have suffered as a result of your failure to get the productivity gains.

The impact of the accord process on individuals again is not a happy picture. Real average weekly earnings, for example, have fallen by 0.4 per cent. If you look at the nature of our society—whether it is a fairer and a better place—you will see that the distribution of income, even allowing for the social wage, has become less equal. Basically, the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer under you.

We have suffered the worst recession for 60 years. Our current account deficit, as I have mentioned, is now worse even than Mexico's and worse than those of the OECD. We have had record numbers of bankruptcies and small business failures. There are also the social implications, including the impact on Australian marriages and the impact on young people—the high suicide rates and the absolutely disgraceful high youth unemployment rate we have in this country. It is a disgrace, Minister. We have a society with all the riches and a good democracy, but 25 per cent of our young people cannot get a job. Why is that? It is because of the constraining, rigid, inflexible policy that you have.

The accord process over the last 12 years has a very poor record at the economy level, the macro level and with its impact on individuals. I ask anybody listening to this: how have the accord and the government's economic policy affected you in the last 12 years? After the last 12 or 13 years of Labor, are you and your family better off? It is not a politically generated question. I think most people would say they are not better off. The truth is that in that time a lot of people have lost their businesses and the opportunities they otherwise would have been provided.

Then those opposite have the gall to front up, as they did to the Australian people, and attempt to be the incarnation of traditional Australian values. We had plausible Martin Ferguson saying he represents workers. He does not represent workers; he represents a minority of workers and, furthermore, the minority of workers he has are deserting him in droves.

They are so desperate for members that one union in Sydney last year advertised discount strippers to attract more members. That is how low your union mates have gone. Instead of fronting up with Martin Ferguson, the Prime Minister would have presented a more accurate picture if he had turned up with his shadowy troika including George Campbell. He is the one with 100,000 scalps on his belt from the 1980-81 gross campaign they waged, which cost a lot of people their jobs. George Campbell is the bloke who knocked off Bruce Childs to come in here and be the Prime Minister's lackey in the upper house.

The troika would include that bloke Coombs from the Maritime Union, the doyen of the aristocracy of the working class—the bloke whose members, generally speaking, earn three times what the average Australian earns and the bloke who has done more to retard, with your acquiescence, Minister, decent workplace reform on our waterfront.

The last one I would throw in would be Bill Ludwig—your mate from Queensland—who is the man who provides the factional clout to keep Wayne Goss in power, and Keating and Brereton, with their numbers in Queensland. When you look behind these operators, he is the man, far from supporting the average battler, who is actually raiding the battlers in his own organisation because he has a request out to his own organisers that they surrender their long service leave entitlements—a pool of funds of about $3 million—to the union to pay for the mismanagement of the AWU by Bill Ludwig and people.

So, far from representing decent Australian values, when you look behind some of the powerbrokers and the crude factional dealing and operations of some of these people, you see not Australian values but in fact the grubby, political, cynical deal playing which is so much part and parcel of the way in which you people operate.

The accord is a con. If people think they are going to get something out of the latest deal, the truth of the matter is, based on what has happened in the last 12 years, they will not get anything out of it. We would like to see people get real wage increases. Under us, of course, application could be made for a safety net increase. And we will genuinely look after those low paid workers who have had such a rough time under the Labor Party.

Until we have real productivity gains in this country, the accord is a mirage. It is simply a deal, as you always do, with your union mates, with the union bosses—not to the advantage of Australian workers but to the disadvantage of Australian workers. You are not the champion of workers; you are the champion of low wage rights. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —What a welcome surprise. What an absolute little gift from the new shadow minister, the member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who has just returned to industrial relations. And what a day to do it on. What a wonderful day to contrast our industrial relations policies with theirs—on the very day that Accord Mark VIII has been released. I have looked over at the embarrassed faces behind the member for Flinders. You would really think the member would know better. You would have thought by now that he would have worded it better and that he would understand that this is the last day he calls on the debate the opposition can never win.

PARA.TAB: What is even stranger is that he has called it on on the very day we have released the details of Accord Mark VIII, the very day we indicated to the House that we have tied up this wonderful package—a fantastic package—of expanded enterprise bargaining, of safety net increases, of industrial protection, of commitments to low inflation and of commitments to employment growth. Yet the member for Flinders has walked into the House and said, `Oh, no, the Accord is not an instrument of constructive economic reform.' This is the Accord that gave us Medicare. This is the Accord that stabilised the economy. This is the Accord that repaired the social wage. This is the Accord that gave the Australian economy productivity, that gave us skill enhancement. This is the accord process that gave us worker superannuation. This is the last in the line of accords after the one that gave us the concept of the trade union movement committing itself to putting jobs first.

The Accord is committed to low inflation at two per cent to three per cent, to high growth and to sharing the benefits of that in a way that is absolutely fair. Yet the honourable member comes in here and says that it is not an instrument for constructive economic reform.

What does he come armed with? He comes armed with Jobsback, the document that has persistently been on the nose with the electorate, his IR policy, a document which earlier this week he tried to apply a bit of perfume to, it is fair to say, by talking about safety net rises. You try to deceive the public by pinching a little of the government's rhetoric and pretending that your safety net is a real safety net, as we provide under the Industrial Relations Reform Act.
The fact is that there is no mechanism in Jobsback for any safety net rises and for the honourable member to change his leader's views. We all know his leader's views.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are shadow boxing.

—I am not shadow boxing. I am indicating to the House the absolute paucity of your performance in coming in here and raising this matter of public importance in the House. At the last election the member for Flinders was trying to have the debate on the GST wrapped right around his neck. Now he has Jobsback. He has a document that has about as much credibility as the Hitler diaries. Jobsback was drafted by a man whose record is irrevocably tarnished by the wages blowout of the early 1980s. It is a rerun of the Victorian model that has led to the great exodus of workers from the Victorian IR system. More than half a million workers have flooded into the Commonwealth system, the national system. That has left its architect, Phil Gude, a national IR joke. That is Jobsback. That is what you will do to the whole of Australia—industrial relations Victorian style, the industrial relations that you champion.

PARA.TAB: Having been given the job of arguing the policy, the honourable member has probably got a bit of a reason to be bitter. He has probably got every reason to be a bit bitter. This is not the choicest of jobs. Why does he keep bashing his head against the wall, arguing that Jobsback is some decent alternative to our policy? Jobsback is now in its fourth run. It has been rejected thrice already. Within the next 12 months it will be rejected for the fourth time.

Whom does the honourable member think he is going to convince? How is he going to convince people that tearing away the award safety net is going to be good for them? What chance have you got? You have no chance at all. How does he think he can rationalise this while his leader is out there saying, `I'm for the battler. I'm for the families,' when he wants to tear away the award system that is so central to protecting the very interests of families and so absolutely fundamental to protecting the interests of the battlers in the community? Yet the member for Flinders and his leader know that their policy would tear away penalty rates, shift rates, loadings, award based superannuation, family leave and a multitude of award conditions that battlers and families depend upon.

Why is he bringing himself forward in this debate? Why does he do it today? The member is just playing into our hands. With the Accord and the success of the reform act behind us, all we have to do is point out to the people of Australia that the opposition's policy will only guarantee them those poor miserly, Dickensian conditions. That is all they will get.

We all remember that the opposition was going to release its draft bill two days after the last federal election. Remember that? It was going to be ready beforehand, but then they said, No, it won't be ready, but we guarantee—

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard said that.

—That is right; the now Leader of the Opposition. The opposition guaranteed that it would release the draft bill two days after the last election. Have we seen it yet? Not on your Nellie. We are still waiting. All we have is four Dickensian conditions. Sure, there will be plenty of obfuscation and plenty of pinching of rhetoric, but no-one will be conned by that because we know those opposite hate the award system and the idea of a comprehensive safety net and they are revolted by the very concept of a compulsory application of a no disadvantage test—all the things that fundamentally underpin a Labor style IR system. The very conditions that workers won over the last century would be—
—They would be swept away! Decimated!

—They would be swept away. Workers would be left with four Dickensian conditions. What sort of a policy is that for families? What sort of a policy is that for battlers? I will tell you what it is: a disastrous policy. We have told people this before. Every time we tell them, they believe us. All the surveys show, at a rate of five to one, that people believe we are better at handling IR—not those opposite.

PARA.TAB: The conservative governments have at every turn helped us underline this very reality. There they are, the Victorian IR system and now the Western Australian IR system, like big beacons. People only have to read this morning's West Australian to see an editorial openly and very comprehensively criticise the model being pursued by Graham Kierath. The Western Australians are flat out going down the Victorian path. They are flat out being trailblazers for the policies of Jobsback. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have really thought they would have learned by now that while they have Howard they will have Jobsback and while they have Jobsback they will have one great big dud.

No matter what Mr Representation over there, the member for Flinders, says, he will be able to put no decent light on Jobsback at all because it will get the thumbs down, as it has every time it has been tried out in the past. Yet he comes into the House and misrepresents the success of our system. The success has been outlined—seven accords now and the latest one done today. Success is guaranteed under Accord Mark VIII.

Those opposite will not be able to deny the statistics, and nor will they be able to babble on about unfair dismissals. Both employers and unions have today very warmly welcomed the amendments that we announced yesterday. Opposition members will not be able to obfuscate any longer. They will have to produce their own policies. They will find them standing up very badly against ours, the achievements of the accord process and the benefits that will flow from Accord Mark VIII. Just look at the success we have achieved. It puts the very real lie to what has been said in the chamber today by the member for Flinders. Since 1991, 4,500 agreements have been completed, with 2,300 of them since the IR Reform Act came into effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many have expired?

—They have all been rolled over. Sixty per cent of all federal award employees are in the enterprise bargaining stream. How many do you have in Victoria? Three per cent, is it, in your discredited system? Seventy-five agreements have already been ratified in areas where no unions are available, the non-unions areas, to provide the benefits of representing employees.

PARA.TAB: Look at the performance of inflation against the backdrop of the accord process and the Industrial Relations Reform Act. It is sitting on two per cent to three per cent at an advanced stage of the recovery, with economic growth of up to five per cent. Since the last election, 640,000 jobs have been created—320,000 of them since the new IR act was put into place. We have an average wages growth of four per cent to five per cent for people under agreements.

Inflation is down at two per cent to three per cent and we have four per cent to five per cent average wages growth as a result of the productivity that has flown from the enterprise bargaining process. Of course, there have also been three $8 safety net adjustments for those who have not been able to get agreements. Under this new Accord, there will be safety net adjustments of up to $14 for those who are least well off in the community.

All of this was achieved under the accord process against the backdrop of the lowest level of industrial disputes for 50 years. This is an unparalleled success story. It is going to be mighty hard to rationalise those statistics with your allegation that we have in some way failed in the area of labour market reform. It is going to be even harder to rationalise it when your Jobsback policies have failed so dismally in so many of your own conservative states. It will be harder still with people who remember the wages break-outs, your miserable performance, the high inflation, the high unemployment and the industrial mayhem that you gave us in the early 1980s, particularly now when the man responsible is your leader today.

The opposition will not be able to deny history or the statistics. It will not be able to convince people that Labor has failed them when they have enjoyed industrial stability, improvements in the social wage, low inflation and rapid employment growth for almost a decade. Whilst the opposition has Jobsback, you can bet your life on one thing: the public will not support it. The public knows, we know and you know that your policies are, and always have been, anti-worker. They are anti-worker policies from an anti-worker party led by two of Australia's most anti-worker politicians—the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard); and the member for Higgins (Mr Costello).

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Higgins has a big record in industrial relations.

—He has a huge record of being one of the most anti-worker politicians ever to sit in the House of Representatives of this country. We will keep reminding the electorate of this fact right up to polling day. Come polling day, the result will be the same as it has been for the last five elections. Once again, Jobsback will be one of the major reasons for that result. So please do us a favour: keep sticking to it. We think it is terrific.

PARA.TAB: On every point we know that the facts favour the government. Those facts counter everything that the member for Flinders says, everything his leader says and everything ACCI says. We know we have the balance of policy right, and we know that our policies are working. Over the last 12 years we have got the results, and that is why people still support us. I repeat: every issues survey on IR shows very comprehensively that we have the results.

You will not listen to the people in IR, will you? You cannot listen to them. You are determined not to listen to them. You are determined to punish them on IR. No-one will believe your rhetoric about being pro-family or having pro-battler policies. No-one will care about whether it is opt in or opt out because it is still anti-worker Jobsback.
We will be delighted if you go on with all the humbug you have trotted out today. But the facts, and the people of Australia, will support the current federal system—the one we are so proud of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's Accord Mark VIII is the eighth accord since 1983 and should be seen for what it is. It has more to do with providing the government with an election platform than improving the real conditions of ordinary workers.

PARA.TAB: Today's statement is full of rhetoric, like the fatuous rhetoric we have just heard from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). But, like the previous accords, it will deliver very little to Australian workers. One has only to look over the government's record of the last 12 years to see how this is true.

We have had the worst recession for 60 years. Let me stress to the minister that, during that recessional period, we had four of those eight accords. So they were not very successful and I doubt whether this eighth one will be any better. We had record bankruptcies among small business. We had unemployment rocket to one million people out of work—800,000 of whom are still out of work—the highest in the nation's history. Now we have a massive balance of payments crisis which, according to reports this week, puts us in the same league as Mexico.

Is it any wonder that the workers themselves do not have any confidence in the government? Is it any wonder that the workers doubt the credibility of the ACTU? One has only to look at the dramatic fall in trade union membership for evidence of this loss of faith. ABS statistics between August 1988 and August 1994 show that trade union membership dropped seven per cent to 35 per cent of Australia's 6.5 million employees.

Today's Accord Mark VIII agreement has been framed with tomorrow morning's newspaper headlines in mind. But the hundreds of thousands of ordinary workers around the country will be saying tomorrow morning, `Here we go again.' It is more smooth talk from Keating and Ferguson.

The question they are asking is: what is it going to do for me? This is the sort of question I get asked every day as I move around my electorate and talk to small business operators, shop keepers, factory employees, trades people and young people. I get asked: why can I not get a job; why am I not getting ahead; and why am I little better off than being on the dole? If they are in small business they ask: why is government taking more and more off me the harder I work? These questions are not being addressed by this government.

I will refer to the case of Mr Peter Hajenko who is a public servant in my electorate. He is a very focused and hardworking man with four teenage children. He is married and his wife does not work. Mr Hajenko's gross income is $34,600 a year. One of his teenagers has reduced Austudy and another is on an unemployment benefit.

After allowing for the basic family payment, the home child-care allowance and deductions for superannuation, the family nets $1,146 per fortnight. If he had exactly the same family circumstances but was unemployed—and I am assuming $100 per week in casual employment—the family would earn $1,272 per fortnight. That is a difference of $126 per fortnight. Where is the equity? Where is the incentive for battling Australian families to get ahead?

It is ironic that on the day of this new Accord, in the local Bundaberg newspaper, the News Mail, Mr Hajenko's story has been told under the headline, `Average working families ignored'. Mr Hajenko is quoted in that article as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I am just very concerned that the government is not honouring its commitments to the working families of the country and I was under a false impression that those who work get some reward for their labour.

He obviously thinks they do not. It is obvious from true stories like this that workers are concerned about their job security and standard of living, yet this government's roller-coaster approach to economic policy has served to create uncertainty and division in the workplace.

PARA.TAB: I will now deal with the issue of unemployment. Today's Accord claims to create 600,000 new jobs by the end of the decade. Yet unemployment remains a critical issue in regional Australia. I will take you on a trip up the Queensland coast. In my electorate of Hinkler in Central Queensland, one in every three teenagers looking for work cannot get a job. That situation extends from the Sunshine Coast to Ingham. In the Wide Bay-Burnett region, the southern part of my electorate, the figure is closer to 40 per cent.

The general unemployment rate, according to the DEET small area labour statistics, is 9.9 per cent in Gladstone, 10.5 per cent in Rockhampton and 12.4 per cent in Bundaberg. They are all well above the Queensland and national unemployment averages. The facts are that this government does not have the answers and its inability to perform even permeates Working Nation—the government's big attack on unemployment—which is clearly faltering.

The statistical decline in long-term unemployment since Working Nation is largely a government inspired mirage. It has more to do with the government redefining 70,000 long-term unemployed as short-term unemployed after putting them through a labour market program. In other words, if you keep them going through labour market programs, you can say that they are no longer long-term unemployed. What a hopeless fraud. Commencements in jobstart, the government's most successful labour market program—I do not knock it, but those opposite boom it up with rhetoric—in the first six months of Working Nation collapsed to 30,000 fewer than in the same period the previous year. Commencements in other programs have also fallen well behind.

The unemployment figures are further fudged by redefining certain groups of unemployed. For instance, the Department of Social Security figures now exclude those previously unemployed people who receive the mature age allowance and the widows allowance. Last month these redefined unemployed represented a total of 46,000 people.

Last week in some 48 hours I was confronted with three gut tearing cases of hardworking small business people—a nursery proprietor, a stainless steel fabricator and a locksmith. The nursery, the Pennyroyal Herb Farm, is a marvellous tourist attraction and production nursery. It was a state finalist in the Queensland tourism awards and a finalist in the business executive of the year awards in Queensland. This nursery has reached a level of exasperation with the market, the economy, raising finances and government regulations.

All of this was heightened by the fatuous statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Brisbane on 11 May this year that `this is as good as it ever gets' for small business and that, if they cannot hack it, they should `get out'. The nursery proprietor in a letter to the Prime Minister—a copy of which she gave me—asked rhetorically:

SPEECH.PARA: Please tell me how to tell my 15 staff that we are closing down—if that is what you suggest and that they should join the unemployed—as we will have to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Labor laughs.

—Yes. I am not a bit surprised that those opposite laugh about the fate of these 15 employees in a provincial city. But we will see what happens to them in the upcoming state and federal elections. The other two small businesses have been through the ringer with the recent unfair dismissal actions. This is the area of the minister's responsibility on which he has been forced to back down ignominiously this week. One of these small businesses is also having trouble with inconsistencies between state and federal superannuation regulations. The other is having a horrendous paperwork war over sales tax, which has been exacerbated by the proposed 12 per cent sales tax on certain building materials.

PARA.TAB: These are just three small businesses in my electorate that have come to my office in 48 hours. If you multiply that by 800,000 small businesses in Australia, who I remind this House are the nation's biggest employers, you have the formula for a disaster in a sector which could offer considerable hope for our unemployed.

I would have liked to touch on a recent report on poverty in Queensland but time prevents me from doing so. It is an outrage that in Bundaberg, which is in my electorate of Hinkler, 46 per cent of all households are living on an income of less than $25,000 per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—Indeed, it is shameful. One of the key provisions of today's accord agreement relates to the government's backdown this week on the unfair dismissal provisions of the current Industrial Relations Act. It was just three weeks ago in this House that the Minister for Industrial Relations defended these provisions. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we have got the balance of policy right and our policies are working.
Those policies are not working and neither will Accord Mark VIII.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every member of this House would know that the member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has had some pretty low moments in his political career. You only need to go back to the night of the last election to understand how his baby, Fightback, blew the coalition right out of the water. He must have had that same sinking feeling this afternoon when, after having lodged this MPI at the Speaker's office before midday, he came to read the text of Accord Mark VIII, which has quality, reform and improvements written all over it. The blood must have drained right out of his face as it did on the night of the last election.

PARA.TAB: What the member for Flinders and the opposition are saying through this matter of public importance is that they do not believe in cooperation with the Australian trade union movement, Australian workers and the Australian work force. They do not believe in the accord process which has created over 600,000 new jobs since March 1993. They do not believe in the target that has been established in accord mark 8 of another 600,000 new jobs over the next four years. Just as the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was wrong two years ago when he said that could not be achieved, the opposition is wrong again in 1995 in saying that the target set by the government and the ACTU will not be achieved.

This MPI is proof positive of how the opposition does not believe in an accord process which can produce sustainable low inflation for Australia through cooperation with the trade union movement. The opposition does not believe in a process which provides an achievable target of underlying inflation in Australia of being between two and three per cent. This MPI is proof positive of how the member for Flinders and the opposition do not believe in a system which has lowered industrial disputes in Australia since 1983 by 66 per cent.

They do not believe in a system which has the sophistication, the guile and wit to link industrial relations to rates of money wages in Australia, to the fabric of the social wage. They do not believe in a sophisticated safety net in Australia, how a government can put together a package of flexible industrial relations, skill development and training in Australia, employment growth and a strong social wage and do it in consultation and cooperation with the trade union movement. The proof is there again today. The union movement in Australia is leading the cheer squad for low inflation in a manner that could never be achieved by the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) or a coalition government.

Quite simply, the trade union movement in Australia in 1995 has the sophistication, experience and good sense of national interest to know that there is no point pursuing aggressive money wage increases if that produces undesirable economic outcomes. The sophisticated model is to understand that a dollar in the hand from the social wage is worth just as much as a dollar in the hand from the money wage. The union movement can cooperate with the government to coordinate those two aspects of economic policy—wage claims and the social wage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Battlers are not impressed by sophisticated models.

—That happens in this country because of the purpose and unity of political and industrial labour. The member for Goldstein, with his jackboots on, might scoff but the truth is it can only happen in Australia under a Labor government through the purpose and unity of political and industrial labour. This MPI today is proof positive of how the coalition does not believe in an award safety net through cooperation with Australian trade unions and how it does not believe in enterprise bargaining and the growth of enterprise agreements through cooperation with workers.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day, the coalition does not like the accord. It hates the idea that it has been successfully renewed seven times, including today's historic Accord Mark VIII. At the end of the day, the coalition does not like trade unions. It does not like talking to trade unionists. It does not like consulting with Australian working people. It does not like the idea of the Australian work force having a legitimate say in the way in which this nation and its economy are managed.

Only Labor has demonstrated the unity and purpose of political and industrial labour to put together a sophisticated economic and industrial model. This has been the historic transformation. The MPI seeks to talk about industrial relations reform. There has been a bucket load of it in the last decade. Only under Labor has the nation made the historic transformation—80 years of centralised industrial relations out of the court in Melbourne—to a flexible, workable, cooperative industrial relations environment.

If it had been the Liberal Party and the National Party, spearheaded by the member for Goldstein, attempting that task over the last 10 years, what would have happened? We would have had the jackboots style of the H.R. Nicholls Society. We would have had legislation drafted by the wordsmiths at the H.R. Nicholls Society with the member for Goldstein scribbling away. He would not be able to scribble the words down fast enough, as John Stone, Judith Sloan and the member for Higgins (Mr Costello) put the jackboots on and try to deregulate the Australian industrial relations system through confrontation and disputation. That would have been the inevitable result. There would not have been a single productivity improvement. We would have seen the closing down of Australian industry through confrontation and disputation—strike after strike after strike.

Only under Labor have we seen 4,500 enterprise agreements formalised by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—60 per cent of federal award workers under an enterprise bargain. This applies not just for big business but also for small business—70 per cent of the agreements cover enterprises with fewer than 100 employees.

The member for Goldstein asked about productivity. There is a bucket load of productivity out of these enterprise agreements because 75 per cent of them address specific productivity measures, with a positive flow-on impact for standards of living in this nation.

The member for Goldstein should forget about all the neanderthals and jackboots at the H.R. Nicholls Society. He should just start writing down the notes of the Labor government. He should write down the sophisticated model for a small trading nation. He should get his pen out and write it down—industrial relations flexibility in cooperation with the trade union movement, genuine enterprise bargain.
Mr Cleary interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr 45 per cent wants to join the debate. We are talking about productivity. Mr 45 per cent, the member for Wills, has joined the debate. He is the sort of person who would drive productivity down. If we took him as the model worker, productivity in Australia would be halved. We would go back to the centralised industrial relations system in Melbourne with the member for Wills out there writing out productivity agreements for every workplace in the country—not 100 per cent under Labor, but 45 per cent. It would be half rates under the member for Wills. So he has no right whatsoever to be interjecting in this debate. He is the least distinguished worker in this place.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the sophisticated model, I will round out the model for the extreme Left and the extreme Right. One thing about politics is that, if you come around far enough, you reach a point of consensus. The extreme Left and the extreme Right in the end agree with an authoritarian approach to public policy—that is, bash people. That is the style from both the extreme Right and the extreme Left.

The truth is that only Labor knows the middle way. Only Labor has the sophisticated model of IR flexibility, the genuine enterprise bargaining, the productivity focus, the low disputation and low strike rate around Australia and, in the end, low inflation and wage restraint because workers know the relationship between wages and productivity. It is not 45 per cent productivity with the member for Wills and that authoritarian, extreme Left, Albanian style of industrial relations. Instead, it is the sort of approach that produces gains in cooperation with the trade union movement and produces employment growth. There have been 600,000 new jobs since the last election. With the new accord comes the promise of another 600,000 jobs in the next four years.

This is a beautiful, sophisticated model for a small, successful trading nation. It all adds up and the bottom line is higher standards of living. That is the point of the historic Accord Mark VIII. It shows that in the food chain of public policy it is an advanced species. While the Liberal Party and the member for Wills are still dragging their knuckles with an old authoritarian style of industrial relations—

TALK.START.PARA: —Albania.
—He is interjecting that he has been to Albania. He comes from Albania. He wants an Albanian industrial system. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Housing and Regional Development: Retirement

TALK.START.PARA: —Brian Howe's departure from the deputy prime ministership calls for some reflection on the nature of politics, particularly as his seat of Batman, adjoining my electorate of Wills, is now being targeted—as is my electorate and the electorate of Maribyrnong—by a trinity of retreating state Labor MLAs.

PARA.TAB: Brian Howe's departure has opened the way for yet another state Labor MP to run up the white flag and lay down arms in the battle against Kennett. These are the same characters who run around the northern suburbs telling us how devastating life is becoming because of Kennett. All the while they deceive people about their own intentions and the complicity of the federal government in the privatisation, freeway-widening juggernaut that is consuming Victoria.

I did not agree with the member for Batman's position on the Medicare surcharge, and I think he should have been a stronger critic of Kennett and the state ALP's freeway-widening agenda. Nevertheless, I acknowledge several of the initiatives which he has taken, particularly in urban policy and the needs of the inner city residents of Melbourne. The electorates of Wills and Batman—and indeed Maribyrnong—share distinctive qualities.

All three electorates are situated in the northern suburbs of Melbourne—areas where free market policies of the kind that the Whippet from Werriwa endorses have destroyed manufacturing industry and created rising rates of unemployment. And hardly a person has taken up the Whippet's offer to fly to or ring Sydney to escape their own social reality. The Whippet's hero, Margaret Thatcher, had a simpler solution. She just told displaced workers to get on their bikes.

The better cities program facilitated by Brian Howe goes some way to fostering a distinctive inner urban culture. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), by contrast, is more interested in his grand vision for waterfront Sydney, the restoration of 18th century Paris and the redesign of Berlin—all of which show that he is a cultural aficionado but none of which will enhance the lives of the battlers, which both sides of the parliament claim to be so concerned about.

In the northern suburbs of Melbourne, the future of the material resources of the locality is open to question. Sydney Road, the spine of the suburbs of Brunswick and Coburg, has in the past been a vital and lively urban environment. Along the street are a number of heritage listed buildings, including the Presbyterian church in Sydney Road, Coburg; St Ambrose church and school; Cumberland Arms Hotel; Duke of Edinburgh Hotel; and the Mechanics Institute—all, excluding the first mentioned, of Sydney Road, Brunswick.

Only a Francophile or a textbook architect would be oblivious to the grand Victorian streetscape of Brunswick. Around these buildings are rows of two-storey shops which locals claim make Sydney Road the longest shopping street in Australia. Many of these buildings still support a rich cultural life. The Brunswick Mechanics Institute, the Retreat Hotel and the Duke of Edinburgh Hotel, for example, are favourite places for regular music concerts, drawing on all of the rich multicultural traditions of these suburbs.

I may not hear Mahler in Sydney Road but come the Brunswick Music Festival you will hear some of the best and most diverse traditional music in the world. It is buildings such as these in Sydney Road which need funds for recycling so that the whole street, rather than merely a handful of buildings, can once again play a part in the community life of the northern suburbs. We need to extend the better cities program into new areas of social need in inner city areas, especially areas ravaged by the free market policies of the last 15 years.

I know that this government has set up REDOs to promote local investment. These, I believe, are too broad in their geographical reach and so ALP driven that they cannot truly reflect the political and cultural aspirations of local communities. We do not want `yes men' and `yes women' on REDOs. We want people with independence and vision.

While the opposition's recent briefing paper on regional development alludes to this problem, it is based on the assumption that regions do not exist in the city. Looking at the list of ALP candidates lined up to run for inner city seats in Melbourne at the next federal election, we have to wonder whether Brian Howe's vision is about to be passed on. Why do Bob Sercombe, Kelvin Thomson and Theo Theophanous want to run away from state parliament? Where do they really stand on the widening of the Tullamarine Freeway, the privatisation of public assets beyond the ones targeted by Kennett—the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom and Australia Post—and the rejuvenation of the northern suburbs?

It is a sad fact that the Brian Howes of the world are not being replaced in the parliament; they are being replaced by the likes of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham)—devotees of free market policies. This is a bloke who wants to point the finger arrogantly at people and who really gets about one point out of 10 for substance and about 3 1/2 points for gall.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the adjournment debate this evening, honourable members may be surprised that I will speak not on Jeffrey Kennett but on a constituent of mine, Mr Maurice Brumer. Maurice is a qualified second generation optometrist who has had continuous sole practice in Frankston for over 25 years. He is actively campaigning on behalf of children who, through no fault of their own, are condemned to a life of reading difficulties and early departure from the education system.

PARA.TAB: Maurice has been punished for raising concerns about current standards of optometrical practice and the need to better incorporate findings of research into current modes of practice. In a paper entitled `Optometry: light of a perverted science', he initiated a discussion on the issue of spectacles being a harmful drug when not prescribed properly. He canvassed a number of matters relating to prolonged and intensive near-seeing, which he believes is not good for our eyes and our health. He firmly stated that the public has a right to know how glasses may adversely affect good health. Maurice made the point that he did not think this would happen while the optometry profession put the public interest in second place to its own self-interests.

For his efforts, Maurice Brumer was expelled from the Victorian division of the Australian Optometrical Association, a first in history. He dared challenge the cabal that rules optometry in Victoria when he spoke out at a 1992 annual meeting of the Victoria AOA and the national AOA.

An extensive body of theoretical and clinical evidence already exists to show the harmful effects of current optometrical practices. The analogy could be made to tobacco companies, where no amount of research and evidence will convince them of the health related problems of smoking and to the scandal it would be if they could successfully suppress such evidence.

In the belief that the burden of proof lies with the profession to show that its current standards of practices are in the best interests of its patients, Maurice presented a paper before 400 optometrists. The only response since was for the Australian Optometrical Association to make him the first member ever expelled from the association. The Australian Optometrical Association rigidly enforces the code that the first obligation of the optometrist is to his professional colleagues. Maurice insists it is to his patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have a question—in fact it is almost a riddle that my little girls would ask. It goes like this: what do the following all have in common—the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission now located in Sydney, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal now located in Brisbane, the Industry Commission now located in Melbourne, Australian Defence Industries now located in Sydney, the Australia Post national stamp collection now located in Melbourne and the CSIRO headquarters now located in Melbourne?

PARA.TAB: They all used to be Public Service bodies located in Canberra, and it is this Labor government that has moved these bodies and staff out of Canberra. If the government had had its way, it would have done more. It would have moved the Maritime Safety Authority to Newcastle, but it backed down under intense pressure. It was the federal Labor government that voted for the Australian National Training Authority to go to Brisbane rather than to the ACT. It was this government that suggested the transfer of the Australian Broadcasting Authority to Sydney.

Yet it is this government, through Senator McMullan, that is attempting to ridicule the coalition and wrongly and incorrectly say that the coalition will move departments and public servants out of the Australian Capital Territory, when it is those members opposite who have been doing the moving. They are hypocrites. There must be an election in the air!

What is more, the Labor Party trots out the old chestnut that it is the coalition that slashes the Public Service. Let us look at the government's recent record. The front page of the Canberra Times on 11 May 1995 says `Budget `95: The Aftermath: Many to be out of job, says Johns'. The government should come clean. When will it say how many jobs will be lost in the federal Public Service through its budget? What hypocrites and deceivers government members are.

Let us look at some of the figures for last year. In 1993 there were 143,100 permanent public servants employed under the Public Service Act. A year later, in December 1994, there were only 132,500 left. If it is not the Labor Party slashing the Public Service, then who is it? Admittedly, some of those public servants moved across to the Australian Capital Territory health department, but it is about time Senator McMullan came clean on what his party is doing to the Public Service instead of trotting out old lies and deceptions.

Senator McMullan said in a press release that I should stand up for Canberra. Perhaps he should have listened to my maiden speech. Perhaps he should practise what he preaches. I have written to the responsible minister, the foot-in-mouth member for Petrie (Mr Johns), and asked about his comment that large numbers of public servants would be out of a job after the 9 May budget. I am yet to get an answer. Perhaps Senator McMullan, as a representative in Canberra, could hurry him up and get an answer for all Canberrans and all Australians about their Public Service. While he is at it, he might ask the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) when the promised Lake George upgrade will begin.

Let us go a step further. What about the jewel in the crown of the government's cultural policy in the lead-up to the 1993 election? `We will build a National Museum of Australia,' it said. Here we are in 1995, another election in the air, and do the people of Australia have a museum? No. Are the numbers of public servants who will be employed at the National Museum of Australia growing? No.

Here is a promise, which has been made several times, that the coalition will fulfil: we will build a National Museum of Australia at Yarramundi Reach here in the ACT and there will be public servants employed at it. Unlike the Labor Party, which is full of deceivers and tellers of half-truths who pull out chestnuts before every election just to bolster their own aims and to scare ordinary Australians, the coalition, when we are elected, will build the National Museum of Australia and we will staff it with public servants.

It is about time the old myth that the Public Service and the Liberal Party have no affinity with each other is put to rest. I am proud to say that during the Canberra by-election—a by-election at which I must admit John Howard was more than welcome to attend, unlike the Prime Minister who will not be going to Queensland—John Howard made it abundantly clear that the Liberal Party has never been philosophically anti-Public Service. Indeed, we will have an effective and efficient Public Service—unlike under the Labor government—that will allow us to put in place our party's policies and to build a better Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past few days there have been a lot of words said, both inside and outside this House, about the issue of resumption of nuclear testing by the French. There have been a lot of words spoken by members of the opposition who have suddenly newly discovered this issue after having ignored it for some 20-odd years.

PARA.TAB: I want to welcome the support of the opposition on this question. I am pleased to see that the opposition has discovered the fact that nuclear testing in the South Pacific is a risk to all the peoples who live in the South Pacific. I welcome the fact that the opposition has finally, after some 20 years, decided to support the peace movement in Australia in its continuous campaign against nuclear testing.

I hope this means that the opposition will support motions in this place which condemn the development of nuclear weapons, in any country. I hope it means that the opposition will become a strong supporter of the peace movement around Australia. I hope that, in the next couple of weeks when rallies are held in various capital cities around this country campaigning against the nuclear testing by the French, we will see opposition members at those rallies. It will be a new experience for them because they have never been to a peace rally in their lives. They do not even understand what a peace rally is. They have usually bagged the peace rallies and called them all sorts of names. But I am delighted that they have now joined the peace movement and that they are prepared to support the campaign to end nuclear weapons throughout the world and to end nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

I would also welcome the support of the opposition for a petition that I have distributed. Mr Speaker, you will be aware that I have sent a petition to every member of the parliament—all members of the House of Representatives and of the Senate—because I believe this issue is one that is above politics. This is an issue that affects all Australians. All Australian members of parliament should be behind the campaign to stop testing in the South Pacific.

I have sent a copy of my petition to every member of the federal parliament, both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. I hope that they will do as I am doing. I am distributing it to every community group, sports club, senior citizens group and pensioner group in my electorate. I hope they will distribute it throughout their electorates as well.

What we need to do is to mobilise the people of Australia in this campaign. A lot of words have been spoken about what the government should have done, who should have said this and who should have said that; but what we are here to do is to represent the people of Australia. The people of Australia are outraged at this decision of the French government. It is something that we all condemn. We need to give the people of Australia a clear opportunity to voice their concerns.

The petition I have distributed throughout this country is one way that the Australian people can have their voice heard. It is not the only way and it is not by itself going to change the French government's decision. I know that, but I am optimistic enough to believe that, if the people of Australia can gather together a loud enough voice to tell the people of France that we do not like what they have done in deciding to resume testing and that we are opposed to the dangers and the risks that this will pose to the health not only of our people but of people throughout the South Pacific, then maybe they will start telling their government that they disagree with that decision.

This petition is one more way that we can join together to add our voice to this campaign. It is a way that we can have millions of Australians supporting our government in our campaign to end testing in the South Pacific. We need to gather the voice of all Australian people and tell the people of France that they need to tell their government to stop testing.

I hope that all members of parliament will distribute the petition entitled `Stop French nuclear tests in the Pacific'. It is a petition to the French ambassador to Australia, His Excellency Dominique Girard. I hope that all members will distribute the petition around their electorates, get lots of signatures and send it back to me by 10 July, so that I can deliver to the French ambassador on Bastille Day, 14 July, hundreds of thousands of signatures on behalf of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't be drinking any water.
—I certainly will not be going to any celebrations at the embassy, nor will I be drinking any wine to celebrate French national day, unless France reverses its decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple in my electorate run a highly successful training and rehabilitation program for young Aboriginals who are trying to give up petrol sniffing. The young people are trained to be stockmen and stockwomen at a station in the remote north of Grey. Petrol sniffing is a major concern in the community. It kills; it causes lifelong diseases; and, like most destructive addictions, it tears families apart and ruins young lives.

PARA.TAB: DEET has supported this training and rehabilitation program for some time because of its success. Late last year, an officer of the Department of Human Services and Health met with the couple who run the program. The officer was impressed and suggested that, because the program dealt with petrol sniffers, perhaps funding applications should be directed to the Department of Human Services and Health; after all, petrol sniffing is a health issue and the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) had been telling all of us in this House that she wanted to include Aboriginal health in her portfolio.

Given such encouragement, the couple running the stockman program wrote to the department in October 1994 asking for funding assistance. November and December ticked by without a response. It was the new year and still the minister had not responded to the funding application. The couple obtained letters of support from the South Australian minister and they also obtained a recommendation from the Catholic archbishop, but still no word from the minister.

The couple learned that the minister was going to be in Adelaide. They asked to meet with her and—lo!—they finally received a letter from her. She wrote to inform them she was not available to meet them. When do you think these people, who work very hard and run this great program in the middle of Australia for young Aboriginal people who desperately need a new start in life, heard from the minister? The couple received a letter from the department's alcohol workplace unit on 11 May 1995. I suppose it was only seven months after the initial inquiry. You cannot complain about that, I guess. You are probably lucky to get a response from this minister at all.

It was an enormous slap in the face when we look at the minister's rhetoric on Aboriginal health during her time in the federal parliament. In February this year during a debate on Aboriginal health the minister said:
It is very important indeed . . . that we do make progress in this area and I for one am determined to do so . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is from Hansard of 28 February 1995. It is very important to make progress? She is determined to do so? She cannot even answer a letter about Aboriginal health in the same year as she received it. The minister also admitted in February this year that `funds that we have applied in Aboriginal affairs have not had the desired effect that we would all wish'. She went on to say:
I want to point out that this serious matter requires cooperation; it requires bipartisan support.

Minister, I think it requires you answering your correspondence. As for bipartisan support, the minister has received a wealth of it. The coalition supported the national Aboriginal health strategy, the Aboriginal education strategy and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, just to name a few.

PARA.TAB: I am a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and have worked on the issues for many hours. My electorate takes in many traditional Aboriginal communities, including Pitjantjatjara lands and Maralinga-Tjarutja lands—in fact about 30 per cent of Grey is Aboriginal lands.

The case I have just outlined shows that we have a health minister who cannot cope with Aboriginal health. Her treatment of this issue has been totally incompetent. She cannot even answer correspondence. I despair for the direction of Aboriginal health under this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the last speaker, the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), has worked for hours on Aboriginal health. My father has been working in that area since 1949 and so have a lot of other people. I think a few hours by the member, as opposed to what has been put in by our Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), leaves his comments where they need to be left.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, I wish to speak about something positive in my electorate. You will recall that I have stood up in this House on a number of occasions and given the House and the parliament progress in the building, timber and forestry industries in my area. It is a subject that many walk away from because they find the difficulties in the industry beyond their comprehension or because their ability to do something is limited.

In my electorate, you will remember, I became involved virtually the week after I was elected because there was a resource called water being pushed out into the ocean in ocean outfalls. In fact, there was a rather outrageous proposal being put forward by the local council, the Shoalhaven City Council, to try to propagate ocean outfalls. After a long time, and after a number of public debates with the mayor and others, it was resolved that, with the help of DEET, we would go through and have a look at ways employment might be generated by the use of that water.

Surprise, surprise! The Shoalhaven City Council is now having problems allocating the water equitably among farmers. My dreams of it being used in the forestry industry will not come to fruition. That is not because of my lack of trying, but because more profitable uses for that water have come to the surface. In fact, there have been people who have contacted the council and said, `If you drought-proof us, we will bring large amounts of money to your area and spend it.'

I did not give up. Over the last two years, we have been looking at other ways we can go about it. True, the corporate structure I had envisaged, of the council, the landowner and the timber industry components putting in an effluent management scheme which had a capital component built in behind it, may not eventuate in the near future. However, there is a team from the government working in my electorate, headed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall), Senator Faulkner and Senator Cook. Because of that team effort I am in a position where I have agreement, in principle, from a number of business people in the timber industry to form a holding company, which will aim to bring together production from some 30,000 hectares of plantations over the next few years.

These people joining with the landowners will benefit the forestry industry, which was once the backbone of the industry along our section of the coast, Mr Speaker, stretching from your beautiful electorate of Cunningham down to the electorate of the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). You would recall the red cedar from Kiama that adorns the Sydney Town Hall. That timber, the internals of Kiama, is spread out in those benches. Much of the timber from the Wollongong and Illawarra areas adorns Parliament House in Macquarie Street in Sydney.

Many of us have looked at the industry. We have seen the cleared lands. We have seen that the agricultural use after clearing is not outstandingly successful in terms of profits and attractions of the area. However, the dairy industry is one of those industries which are an exception. It has brought great wealth to our area and has been the mainstay of our area for a large number of years. It will continue to be so, despite the efforts of some, such as my former aldermanic opponent, Neville Fredericks, to try to urbanise those areas.

The dairy industry will survive because it is able to diversify. The timber industry offers the dairy industry a way of keeping its lifestyle and a way of keeping its land together, and, by doing that, a way of improving the agricultural output of the dairy industry and its own productive units.

What I say to you, Mr Speaker, is that with continued prescience in this place I believe we can achieve goals. Agribusiness will develop in a big way in our area. As you understand, Mr Speaker, coming from the region, we are taking it very seriously. We will provide, where the National Party and the Liberal Party have not, not just rhetoric but results. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House a situation that I find quite extraordinary and a matter that must be addressed by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) as a matter of urgency. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee has made a decision that pethidine for long-term use is no longer available under the national health scheme and, despite the matter being reviewed some two weeks ago, the decision has been confirmed. The PBAC has displayed what I would consider to be a mixture of gross ignorance and unsubstantiated assumption that cannot in any way be condoned by the Australian community or many of Australia's doctors.

PARA.TAB: By way of background: this situation came to my attention via a local constituent and her doctor. If the opportunity presents itself I will read the letter from the doctor which clearly sets out the position and shows the advisory committee's total lack of compassion. It seems extraordinary to both me and my patient's treating doctor that he can prescribe morphine or methadone for long-term use and this apparently is condoned by the PBAC as acceptable, but not so for pethidine. There is absolutely no reason why pethidine should be treated any differently, and I find it absolutely galling that the committee can make a unilateral decision without having any awareness of the likely impact of that decision on the individual patient.

The simple fact is that my constituent has undergone specialist examination, has attended pain clinics and has done everything that would reasonably be expected of someone in her position suffering from chronic pain. It is about time that the committee accepted that there will be people severely affected by its decision.

What is equally galling is that the basis for the committee's decision is that it believes the use of pethidine long term is `inappropriate treatment'. As far as my constituent and her doctor are concerned, the treatment by way of long-term pethidine prescription is totally appropriate treatment and I fail to see how the committee can make such a widespread value judgment without in any way taking into account individual circumstances. The other galling aspect is that, relative to other drugs, pethidine is extremely cheap and, therefore, there can be no financial reason for the advisory committee's decision.

I am angry about this decision. My constituent and her doctor are angry about this decision. I understand that many doctors throughout Australia are angered by this decision. If, as I believe may be the situation, the committee has made this decision on the views of one member of the committee, can I respectfully suggest that all committee members take a long, hard look at that advice.

Prior to reading out that letter from my constituent's treating doctor, I would like to make a final comment, and that is: how dare the advisory committee presume to know more about a patient's appropriate treatment than the patient's treating doctor. The letter from my constituent's treating doctor reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This pleasant woman suffers chronic pain due to having developed an arachnoiditis, i.e. inflammation surrounding the spinal cord. There is no cure and essentially she will probably become paralysed.
Unfortunately she has a very low tolerance to opiates, i.e. morphine and methadone. These cause her severe nausea.
The one drug that did assist her was pethidine in injectable form and used once daily in combination with other therapeutic agents.
Unfortunately pethidine (injectable) is no longer available for long term use on the N.H.S. Scheme, and any attempt to prescribe them in this manner would be questioned by the Health Department.
She does use pethidine tablets but these are largely ineffectual and of course she has to pay for these at the rate of $36.00 per hundred tablets.
She requires a minimum of six fifty mgm tablets daily which really do not give her effective relief. Apart from this there is the cost to her as a Pensioner.
Is it possible to get through you permission to prescribe pethidine injectable for this woman.
For the life of me, I cannot see why pethidine is only allowed for short term use only, when I can prescribe other opiates freely!

This is an extraordinary situation. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is denying my constituent and many other constituents the ability to obtain relief from chronic pain. How dare the committee have the gall to tell my constituent and my constituent's doctor that it knows more about appropriate treatment for her than her treating doctor does!

Debate resumed from 19 June, on motion by Mr Robert Brown:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Procedure Committee's report, entitled Time for review: Bills, questions and working hours, was tabled in the main chamber on Monday of this week. The very fact that we now have, within that same week, the opportunity in this chamber to consider some of the elements of that report in greater detail than would have been available to us in the main chamber attests, probably as well as anything, to the very effective way in which the Main Committee has operated since its introduction last year. That was one of the main changes which came about in the procedures of the House of Representatives, following the Procedure Committee's About time report, which was tabled by Dr Blewett, my predecessor as the chair of this committee, in October 1993.

PARA.TAB: The present report which the Procedure Committee has had tabled in the House of Representatives is the third report of the Procedure Committee to the 37th parliament. In view of the wide ranging nature of the proposals in the first report, the committee felt very strongly that, after a settling-in period, the new procedures should be reviewed to see how they were working and whether any modifications needed to be built into them, whether any of them should have in effect been withdrawn from operation, and whether they should have been supplemented in any way. In November last year, the Procedure Committee wrote to all members and to anyone who was involved in the About time inquiry, seeking their comments on the new procedures, and the committee is very much indebted to all of those who made submissions. The Time for review report follows a similar structure to the About time report, to enable readers to refer from one report to the other more easily.

I want to pay a special compliment and provide special thanks to Robyn Webber and James Rees. Robyn acted as the secretary of the committee, and James assisted her and assisted the committee, and they both continue to do that. I not only want to refer especially to the professional interest which both Robyn and James have in questions of procedure because of their vocational involvement in those areas, but I also want to emphasise the personal interest which they have, quite apart from their professional responsibilities. Their knowledge of some of the more technical intricacies of procedures was of great value to the committee in advising us, and their drafting skills were of exceptional importance and of very great value to the committee in being able to bring forward this report. So I proffer thanks to both Robyn and James for their assistance, cooperation and contribution.

Unquestionably, the introduction of the Main Committee would have been the most important consideration in that initial report, and it has been outstandingly successful. Members have related to it very well, as it is a much more intimate chamber than the main chamber. There probably would have been value in having this place referred to not as the Main Committee but as the Second Chamber. It was an objective of the Procedure Committee to seek to establish an alternative debating forum which would have a status equal, as closely as possible, to that of the main chamber. It has been called the Main Committee, and that title is almost certain to persist, but we should, as often as we can, think in terms of its being a second chamber to the main chamber, with a status as close as possible to the status of the main chamber.

I also want to emphasise that the report is truly a bipartisan effort as far as the committee is concerned. I particularly want to thank the deputy chair of the committee, the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who will be participating in this debate. When we are dealing with procedures of the parliament, which are obviously of great importance to how governments and oppositions perform in the parliament and how their performance is perceived—not only within this institution but in that wider institution the national community—it is often very difficult to come to a common position on some of the issues. In fact, that was often the case in reviewing that report and the new procedures. But I say to members of the opposition, and to my own colleagues, that the goodwill which they brought to that process reflected very great credit on their commitment to this institution and the important role they saw it fulfilling. It really was a very great pleasure to be involved in that exercise.

As the statistics in the report indicate, the Main Committee has made it possible for the House of Representatives to consider legislation, reports and issues of various kinds in much more detail, and with much more time, so that members have had a significantly expanded opportunity to speak and to examine legislation and issues. The committee was also pleased with the level of support for the practice of referring bills to standing committees for inquiry and report. That process of having committees examine legislation and other important issues is one which has been very finely developed and very finely tuned as far as the Senate is concerned. But this has been the first occasion when a significant initiative of that kind has been undertaken in the House of Representatives. I believe it will develop and I think it should develop.

We also gave consideration to the minister's second reading speech.
