One of the provisions of that earlier report was that instead of the second reading speech being made at the time the bill was introduced and the explanatory memorandum was tabled, it would be made immediately preceding the second reading debate. That had some values, but the disadvantages vastly outweighed them. It was done for the following reason. The explanatory memorandum is essentially a bureaucratic statement which summarises the legislation for members of parliament, who are not necessarily experts on the legal way in which legislation is often expressed. So the explanatory memorandum is essentially a product of the bureaucracy. The minister's second reading speech is a political product of the government and of the minister, and while ministers undoubtedly do depend upon their bureaucratic advisers to assist them in the construction of those second reading speeches, those speeches are theirs. They can introduce any sort of political comment that they want to—and they often do, and should be expected to. But then that speech is not there at the time the explanatory memorandum is tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —But do the courts have regard to the explanatory memorandum in interpreting legislation?

—Yes, they do, of course—and not only the explanatory memorandum, but also the minister's second reading speech. The Acts Interpretation Act has made that perfectly clear, so the explanatory memorandum also fulfils that legal purpose as well. The minister's second reading speech, in expressing the government's purposes behind the legislation as well, is an important matter as far as the courts are concerned. But, as I emphasise, the minister's second reading speech is a political statement, so the opposition should have access to the text of the second reading speech in advance of its leading speaker being expected to respond to it.

PARA.TAB: There could be new elements introduced which are not necessarily reflected in the text of the bill or in the explanatory memorandum to which the shadow minister or the person leading for the opposition would need to respond. And since they need to respond, under these current new arrangements, immediately following the minister's second reading speech, they are often placed at a disadvantage. I do not believe that should be allowed to persist and we have suggested that we revert to the previous arrangement.

We have also made reference to the consideration in detail stage. That is vastly superior to the situation which prevailed before—the old committee stage—which, to a large extent, not only in the way in which it was conducted but in the physical actions associated with it, was largely a historical anachronism.

I understand that the origin of the old committee stage rested with the fact that the old House of Commons would traditionally refer legislation to expert groups which were not necessarily committees of the whole of the House of Commons and, in that context, the speaker of the House of Commons had a special responsibility to the Crown, not so much to the chamber.

As the committee consideration stage of the House of Commons developed, the speaker would vacate the chair, the chairman would sit in the chairman's seat, the symbol of the speaker's authority—the mace—would be taken off the table, placed under the table, and a committee of the whole House of Commons would then consider the legislation. We do not do that. The fact that those traditions have persisted, I suppose, reflects well on the traditionalists but is probably under attack by the iconoclasts, of which I am one.

The committee has suggested that the consideration in detail stage be continued as it is at the present time. It has assisted a much more even, continuing flow of debate. The interchange in that consideration in detail stage has been much more effective in scrutinising, in detail, elements of the legislation. Each member now has an unlimited number of five-minute grabs during that consideration in detail stage, and I am not aware of any occasion when that opportunity provided for members has been abused—that is, where they have taken advantage of successive five minutes to make a second speech.

I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if you were in the chamber and if you and your colleagues, including the speaker himself, were occupying the chair, you would not allow that to happen anyway. I have to pay credit as well to those people who have occupied the chair in order to ensure that those arrangements serve the purposes and serve the purposes in the way that they were intended.

There is an expectation, as we have indicated as well, that ministers should attend the House and the Main Committee to oversee the passage of their legislation. I think generally that ministers have been very responsive to their responsibilities in connection with not only their portfolio responsibilities to the chamber but also their legislation, to members on both sides of the chamber and to this parliament as an institution. This was just a little, gentle and courteous reminder to ministers that they do have a responsibility to oversee their legislation and to ensure the passage of their legislation. They should be there to present the second reading speech; they should be there to hear as much of the debate as they can; and they should be there to respond at the end in order to give the appropriate courtesies to those members on both sides of the House who participate.

Question time is, and will continue to be, a very difficult area. It is not a question time. It is a gladiatorial time, an adversarial time and a theatrical time, but it is not a question time in which members of the opposition seek information. When members of the opposition ask a question they do not want an answer; their purpose in asking the question is to put the government under pressure and then, frequently, when the answer is given, the members of the opposition quite understandably complain because they say that answer is not relevant. On most occasions the claim that the answer is not relevant is based on their perception that the answer is not the answer they wanted their question to elicit.

I would like members of the House of Representatives generally to give consideration to the nature of question time, to the purpose of question time. Questions on notice allow a minister to get expert advice from the bureaucracy and to have the answers prepared. Senior advisers to the ministers and the ministers themselves will vet the answers before those answers go out. That is when members genuinely want information. Question time is not serving that purpose.

Unlike the questions on notice procedure, which tends to deal with matters of detail and can be a lengthy process, there is a need for members of parliament to get answers to questions about current things, things that are happening today or things that happened yesterday. We need something like a question time. But we should have a question time which is a genuine question time where genuine issues are raised. We also need a true gladiatorial time. We need an opportunity for the government to be placed under pressure by the opposition, not by some artificial device of asking the question—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ministerial statements.

—The deputy chair suggests some type of statement. Yes, I think so; exactly. Perhaps we need something where the opposition person has, say, two minutes to make a statement and the minister has, say, four minutes to respond to it. That would provide the government and the opposition with a formal, identifiable opportunity to deal with those issues as they wish to. We, the government members, would then place the opposition under pressure because during our four minutes we would respond. With varying degrees of enthusiasm, we would respond.

PARA.TAB: I hope that there is some creative thought about the whole nature of the adversarial role. I do not say that in a deprecating way: that role is an essential element of this institution. We have a government and we have an opposition, and the more vigorous, effective, competent, searching, scrutinising and challenging it is, the better this institution operates.

This institution, above all others, is of fundamental importance to the whole nature of our democratic system. It has got to be made to operate. If there is something for which provision should be made, we should make provision for it in a formal, identifiable way. That provision is for a procedure where we can confront one another—government and opposition. That is what members of the community expect. That is why they come to question time. They do not come along to hear information being given; they come along to see gladiatorial combat.

We even construct the House of Representatives like a Roman arena. Have you been to the Colosseum? Go and have a look at that chamber. That is what it is. It is not a source of information, it is not a place within which people seek information; it is a place where blood is flowing. And that is what it should be. Political blood should be flowing. And we want opportunities for those people in the galleries to be able to applaud or give the thumbs down. Use the spear. We might even bring the mace back into operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish you wouldn't clench your fist!

—The member for Moncrieff and I would be able to use that mace with enthusiasm and expertise. Consideration was given to the question of the 8 p.m. adjournment. That is a civilised time for the parliament to finish. I know there are some younger members who come from long distances. They say, `Look, if I am in Canberra, let's sit during the night and then we will sit for fewer days and I can get back home with my spouse and my kids.' I understand that. They have said that to me.

PARA.TAB: If I were a young fellow with a young family, I would want to spend more time at home as well. But I am an old fellow with kids who are off my hands and Joy does not worry very much where I am or for how long. It does not worry me very much and it does not worry Joy very much but it worries those members with young families. I understand that and I sympathise with it. If we are going to retain civilised hours, I do not know that there is any other alternative. I know that my colleague the deputy chair will be referring to those matters and I know that the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) later on will be referring to them as well.

All honourable members would have a vested interest in the fair and efficient working of the House, which this report honestly attempts to promote. The recommendations are designed to refine the operation of procedure which the House has already adopted. The committee has attempted to balance the interests of government, opposition and private members as best it can, in a bipartisan way. I do not expect that all recommendations will find favour with all honourable members but I hope to have the opportunity to hear their considered views today and in future debates on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit divided in my feelings at the moment. As was mentioned by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown)—who is also the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure—the Main Committee has been a success in terms of expanding the amount of time available for debate. However, I still feel some regret that this report is not being debated in the main chamber.

PARA.TAB: Whilst in no way would I denigrate this chamber, the simple fact is that most honourable members have their television tuned to the main chamber, it is the chamber they will drop into in order to listen to speeches for a while, it is the one they tend to be more focused on. I suspect we would have more people involved in this debate today if it were taking place in the main chamber.

Having said that, I would just like to refer, for the assistance of the honourable member for Charlton—who was not a member of the committee that did the About time report—to the reason this was called the Main Committee. It was because it was envisaged that it would meet in the main committee room, and that is actually stated in that report. That suggestion ran into difficulties because the main committee room is not the property of the House of Representatives. It is a part of Parliament House that is shared by the House of Representatives and the Senate. To set it up permanently as a chamber of the House of Representatives would have created difficulties.

As the honourable member spoke I had the thought, which I just float here for the first time, that perhaps we might consult with our colleagues and see whether there is an alternative name that they would like given to this chamber that might be a bit more appropriate. Given that we have done away with the committee stages of bills, I find it now rather confusing when I see on the House of Representatives blue that we are going to have a Main Committee report. This is not a committee, it does not in any way resemble a committee: it is part of the House of Representatives. Perhaps we ought to think, before we go very much further, about getting a more appropriate name for this chamber.

However, I am limited to 15 minutes today—now 13 minutes—so I have to confine the subjects I am going to cover. The subjects I would like to touch on, if I get time, are question time, second reading speeches and cognate debates.

The Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure has already referred to the fact that question time is a thorny issue. In this report, at paragraph 6.4.4, there is some further discussion of this issue. It ought to be put on the record that when the committee invited all the members of the House of Representatives to comment on the changes to procedures that had followed the About time report, overwhelmingly their comments were concerned with question time. The committee did not actually invite the sorts of comments they made, which were recommendations about relevance, content of questions and answers and so on. These aspects were not touched on in the About time report and were therefore not really affected by the changes that the government ultimately made.

As is pointed out in this report, the committee has taken on board this clear concern of honourable members of both sides and will be pursuing the issue. There are always difficulties on this subject and heaven knows the Procedure Committee has reported on it enough times, but the chairman and I are going to try to find a way around that so that we can get some better discussion of question time and a better resolution than we have to date.

It has to be placed on the record, as the report does, that the changes that were made to question time following the About time report were not the changes that that report recommended. From time to time government ministers—particularly the new Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley), as Leader of the Government in the House—have said, `But the Procedures Committee recommended changes to question time.' And indeed we did.

We recommended that there be an experiment with the roster on Mondays only, but that in no way resembles what the government ended up doing. The roster issue has to be addressed. It is noted in the report that the recommendation of the committee that there be consultation between government and opposition as to the composition of the roster has not been observed. This has been raised by the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Reith)—it appeared to me at the time to be to the great surprise of the Leader of the House, who seemed to be oblivious to the fact that he ought to be consulting. I do not think that the situation has much improved, but if we are to get a better feeling in the chamber and a better handling of business, it is important that consultation takes place.

I do not agree with the member for Charlton that the House of Representatives ought to be an adversarial place. It will naturally be an adversarial place on occasions, but there has to be room for consensus too. The simple fact is that a lot of things are done by consensus, and we get unnecessary conflict because we approach the chamber in an adversarial way.

If I may be so bold—I know a number of my sisters would agree with me—there is a feeling that the nature of doing business here is excessively masculine. The ideas of combat, adversaries and `blood flowing', as the member for Charlton said, are now a little outdated. There is room for a more mature, and better rounded, human approach to the way governments and oppositions do their business. As I have said, the adversarial nature will express itself naturally from time to time; that is to be expected.

I refer particularly to paragraphs 6.1.7, 6.2.10, 6.2.12 and 6.2.16 of the report, where it is pointed out that a stated aim of the roster, when it was introduced by the government and when it was considered by the committee—albeit the committee made a different recommendation—was to involve more ministers. We have in the report some tables which show questions without notice to ministers, from 1992 to 1994. There is some consideration given to the fact that more junior ministers are being asked questions than previously. It might have been instructive if we had asked for one further table: a breakdown of the questions from government members to junior ministers, as opposed to questions from opposition members to junior ministers.

The simple fact is that question time has, on occasions, been turned into a platform for ministerial statements, particularly by junior ministers. A breakdown of the questions asked of junior ministers would show that government members are far more likely to be asking the dorothy dixer of the junior minister. It is the junior minister who gets frustrated because he or she does not get the opportunity to speak very often. The junior minister gets up and gives a dorothy dix answer, which is really a ministerial statement.

In our report, we tried to come to grips with the issue of ministerial statements, and we make some suggestions. I draw particular attention to paragraph 4.4.6, some subsequent paragraphs and the accompanying table 3. The question of the government moving away from giving ministerial statements has been debated in the House, particularly when we have debated Procedure Committee reports.

I put on the record that in 1982—the last year of a Liberal government—there were 80 ministerial statements. In 1994, the most recent full parliamentary year, there were 16. The drop since 1983 has been very marked. A comparison of that figure with the increase in the length of time that individual answers have taken, together with the table showing the decline in the number of questions without notice, gives the story. Question time has been turned into a pseudo ministerial statement time.

I am sure that the member for Charlton, as a former minister, has some sympathy for the problems of ministers. I do remember some of the answers he gave to questions even to this day; I cannot remember whether they were dorothy dixers—

TALK.START.PARA: —They must have been; I can remember them very well!
—They were more entertaining than most of his colleagues' answers.
—He has a very shrewd wit.

—Turgid is not a word one would have applied to the answers he gave to questions. His suggestion—which is not a suggestion of the committee and not one which it debated—is a good one. We ought to have a time when members can make brief statements addressed to a minister and when a minister can have a brief time for reply.

PARA.TAB: Far be it from me to refer to the other chamber, but I have been removed from it for 10 1/2 years now, so I feel a little safer in referring to it these days than I did when I first transferred to the House of Representatives. The Senate has, over time, evolved a system of a better use of supplementary questions and also a system of taking note of answers.

This latter system gives an opposition member—or a government member—the opportunity to make a comment on an answer to a question, but does not exclude the minister from making further comment himself or herself. I know that the House of Representatives never wants to look like it is taking any hints from the Senate, but the fact that that system has worked shows that the type of suggestion that the member for Charlton made might have some merit and might be quite workable.

The other point I wanted to make in this context is that, whilst there is a stated desire by the government to involve ministers more in the chamber, when you look at their conduct when it comes to their bills, the direct opposite is happening. If ministers really wanted to be more involved in the chamber, they would involve themselves at the obvious stage—and that is the consideration of bills stage.

The committee's report does address this subject. I refer members to page 4 and onwards and, in particular, to table 2 on page 11, which shows government bills introduced in 1994. It refers to participation of ministers and, in particular, to the second reading debate summing up. There are some ministers who give their own second reading speeches, who are there for at least some part of the debate and who reply to the debate. As a member, I appreciate that very much. However, those ministers—unfortunately—are very few in number.

I have referred in the past to the fact that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is probably the worst example in this area that the parliament has. She comes into question time when she is on the roster and gives a long answer to a dorothy dixer—but gives very brief answers to opposition questions—and then she does not appear again all week. For her first few months here, she was only appearing to answer dorothy dixers. I think she thought it was actually bad luck if anybody else dared to ask her a question while she was there on the roster.

After I had remarked on this a few times, she came in once and read a second reading speech. I remind you that this Minister for Human Services and Health is also the minister who is responsible for the status of women. She is yet to participate in a debate on any child-care bills which are introduced in her name in the House. That is left to her parliamentary secretary. That is disgraceful. Ministers cannot say they want a roster so that they can get a guernsey in question time and then not attend for their bills—something which is just as important as answering questions.

There are three columns in table 2. One shows who presented the bills: the `Minister from the responsible portfolio'; the `Parliamentary Secretary from the responsible portfolio'; a `Minister from another portfolio'; a `Parliamentary Secretary from another portfolio'; or `No Minister or Parliamentary Secretary'.

Naturally, there is a blank in the column that is headed `Second reading speech delivered by' under that last section called `No minister or parliamentary secretary'. This is because second reading speeches on government bills cannot be given any way other than by a minister or parliamentary secretary. However, out of the 192 bills, 32 have been read by a parliamentary secretary who is not even in that portfolio. I do not mean to put them down, but parliamentary secretaries are very junior people in the hierarchy in terms of answerability to the public or to the government or to the parliament.

What is even worse is that the second reading debate is summed up on only 43 occasions out of 192 by a minister from the responsible portfolio. That does not mean the debate has been summed up by the minister responsible for that bill. It just means that it has been summed up by one of the ministers in that portfolio grouping. If one calculated the number of times the second reading speech was replied to by the minister who was actually responsible for that bill and its administration, the number would be found to be significantly lower than 43.

The column which indicates that 24 second reading debates were summed up by a parliamentary secretary from another portfolio shows us that the person who answers a debate in summary has no status at all. Worst is that 65 second reading debates were not replied to or summed up by any minister or parliamentary secretary. They are issues that should concern us all, both government and opposition. Whilst I have run out of time to talk about the other issues, I appreciate this opportunity. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am overwhelmed, thank you.
—Not like you!

—No; not like last night: I have actually got the call.This report Time for review follows on from About time. I am not sure what the third report is going to be: maybe `A Time to ponder'. It is true that the first report made quite a number of radical changes. The chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has acknowledged the secretariat's contribution and I would like to add my acknowledgment to his. I would like to acknowledge the honourable member's own contribution because these things can sometimes be intensely felt and debated and it could be said that we do not have wimps on the committee. I also acknowledge the contributions of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan).

PARA.TAB: One of the problems for procedure committees, particularly when the government has a majority in the House, as it is required to do to form a government, is that recommendations need to be made with a mind's eye actually intent on getting them through. Procedure committees do not serve parliamentarians, the people or the parliament as well as they might if their reports languish and gather dust. That has not happened. Although About Time was not implemented in the way the committee recommended, we should not necessarily see that as a failure. We should rather welcome the fact that the government has responded positively.

I would like to talk about some of the changes in the review. I want to say that I have always been a keen advocate of the rostering of ministers. I know the opposition members, not necessarily members of the committee, make great capital of rostering because they say we have a part-time Prime Minister. My area of disappointment, I suppose, is that I always believe that rostering ministers would open up the ministerial ranks to some opposition fast bowling. Whilst the opposition actually got the scalp of the former honourable member for Canberra Ros Kelly, it has not subsequently demonstrated an understanding of tactics in question time to take advantage of it. I am not trying to score points. From my own perspective, I think the opposition has failed to realise the potential opportunities that I always believe rostering provided. As the honourable member for Charlton said, I think we should not shrink from the fact that question time is always going to be robust. It is going to be the gladiatorial contest.

We also need to note some changes about question time. Before the prominence of TV, the press media, by and large, dictated the flavour of what occurred at question time. Radio sometimes broadcast it but to very limited audiences. TV now provides the 10-second or 60-second grab. That is used as much to its advantage by the opposition as it is by the government.

The point I am trying to make is a fairly simple one. As a traditionalist, I like to think that we are essentially parliamentarians in this place, as I know the member for Charlton and others do. We have to make the parliament relevant and we have to keep it current. We should value our traditions and nurture them but make them relevant to the current age. And that is why it is impossible to suggest that we can turn back the clock as far as the impact of TV on question time is concerned, and I would not seek to do it.

I know the member for Moncrieff made a point about the limitations of ministerial statements. Let me say that I, for one, would welcome far more ministerial statements by the government. I do not think any government should shrink from being in a position to put its point of view to the people and to the parliament. But, if there has been a diminution of ministerial statements, I have to say that these things are often being done now outside the parliament to gain maximum impact, to make sure as many as possible of our fellow Australians come to understand what the statement is all about. A good example of that, which we discussed in the committee, was the Justice Statement, something delivered in Queensland. I am sure that, if the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) had delivered that statement in the House, it would not have made the same impact, and I commend the committee for recommending that, although a statement may have been made outside the parliament, we should have an opportunity to discuss it and dissect it. That is one of the areas where I suggest we should be more relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —That actually happened with the Justice Statement.
—Was that Sackville or the Justice Statement?
—The Justice Statement. It was tabled.

—That is good, and I would like to see more of that. I want to refer to question time in the Senate. The Senate has introduced something that we all thought would be absolutely ludicrous and unworkable and would completely limit ministers, and that was time limits on the questions being asked and time limits on the answers. If Senate ministers were sent a questionnaire, I think they would say that the system is working pretty well and in fact it has probably sharpened up ministerial answers. I wish I could say that I could imagine this happening in the lower house. I cannot envisage it at this time, but I do think it is something that we should keep in mind.

PARA.TAB: The member for Moore (Mr Filing) had a particular interest in questions on notice and brought forward the suggestion of having a time limit on responses. The committee developed a method whereby members could rise in their places if questions had not been answered after 90 days and raise the matter with the Speaker and the Speaker would write to the relevant minister. I am very pleased to see that the committee has now recommended that that be brought back to 60 days. This is still a very generous period of time. I do not think it is at all arduous for ministers or departments. Ironically, Mr Deputy Speaker—I see that an interchange is going to take place here—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—I will still listen with intent interest to your comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg your pardon. Now I have forgotten what I am talking about.
—Do not let it concern you, Roger.

—That is right. On the hours of sitting, I must say that I was very much an enthusiast for reducing the hours of sitting. As the chairman of the committee has accurately reported, we are leading much more sensible lives, finishing as we do at 8 o'clock instead of 11 o'clock or even much later, but I would like to make the observation that in the period of time that we are here we are much more frenetic about what we are doing. We seem to be going to more and more committee meetings at a greater pace, and perhaps missing some of them. I do not know about my colleagues, but I certainly confess that. So, if we are to take full advantage of these reduced sitting hours, it seems to me that we really need to look at our committee system.

PARA.TAB: If there were one area that I would invite the Procedure Committee to look at, it would be the area of committees of the House. That is not because I think they are bad—I think we were behind the times in moving to a committee system and the committee system has accomplished a lot—but because I think that there are far too many committees. We run the risk of drowning or diminishing or executing our committees by overload. However, there are still areas where I would like to see the committee system taken to. For example, I still remain very much in favour of having joint House and Senate committees. Once again, I welcome the hours of sitting. Unfortunately, the Procedure Committee cannot deal with party committees, and there are obviously party committees that opposition members go to and government members go to. I make the plea that both are in need of reform and adjusting, in the way we have adjusted the hours of sitting.

I also draw to the attention of the House, and particularly of my good friend the member for Charlton, the issue of legislation that goes into the House. Firstly, there is a lot of criticism. I know that the member for Moncrieff is saying, `Isn't it dreadful that ministers aren't in the chamber all the time, looking to their business.' It remains a fact that much more legislation goes through the House of Representatives because the Senate does not agree to delegated legislation to the same extent as, say, the English system does. In other words, what is legislation in Australia would often be delegated legislation in England. So we have a much higher bill load than anywhere else.

I think the key issue here is whether, on the important bills rather than the omnibus bills, the House and the Senate are giving legislation adequate consideration. Again in terms of keeping relevant with the times, the introduction of this Main Committee chamber is a bit of parliamentary microeconomic reform. It means that we do not have to have extra members or extra anything but this second chamber allows more people to participate than would otherwise be the case and it allows more legislation to go through than would otherwise be the case.

I have always thought that you cannot inculcate the urgency or necessity for ministers to steer through their own legislation, and it is not always possible. Whilst legislation is an important aspect of their work, as the honourable member for Charlton will tell us, there are many other competing aspects that can prevent ministers being there. However, I think there is an element of pride in a minister taking an important bill through the House and I would be disappointed if that tradition was ever lost.

It is also important to address the role of parliamentary secretaries. When they were first appointed under this government, similar to the earlier Fraser appointments, they were more like secretaries—answering bag loads of correspondence and attending functions—but I am pleased to say that their role has now evolved to much more than that. Parliamentary secretaries still deal with a lot of the administrative matters but, by and large, most of them have a discrete portfolio area. Whilst that may be minor in the mainstream of the portfolio, it is still a portfolio area. In that regard, it is very hard to detect the difference between junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries other than that the parliamentary secretary must report to the cabinet minister, whereas junior ministers often do not have that same diligent requirement.

Again, in a small way, I am pleased to be associated with what is a good report which will bring important reforms to the parliament. I am sure my colleagues are going to receive the report well, as they did the initial report. I commend those associated with it and particularly encourage our chairman to take on new and even bolder tasks for the Standing Committee on Procedure in the interests of the parliament and parliamentary reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the tabling of the report entitled Time for review: Bills, questions and working hours, which resulted from an earlier report of the committee dealing with reforms that were considered to be important in trying to make the House work in a more effective way, and, in particular, ensuring that individual members have a better opportunity to represent their constituents and that, with the opening of the second chamber, the Main Committee, there are more opportunities than there have been in the past for members to participate in debate and make contributions.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members may be aware that in the original report, which was tabled back in February 1994, the primary criticism made by a number of us was in relation to the Main Committee. We were concerned that the Main Committee would somehow be seen as causing a decline in respect for some of the debates. We had a feeling that we ought to have taken care in dealing with or bringing in a new committee that was going to be dealing with second reading debates on legislation, that this may cause those debates to be seen as second class because they were away from the main chamber.

We were concerned, as I am sure the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) will agree, that there ought to be more sitting days to facilitate greater and lengthier debate, giving more opportunities for members to participate in debates on legislation. However, having been a critic in the first instance and having made a number of observations at the time of the tabling of the first report, I must say that I am now a fan of the Main Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very gracious acknowledgment.

—It is. I have made it on a number of occasions. The Main Committee has facilitated the workings of parliament and has become part of the institution. There would be a number of us who feel that it has enhanced the workings of the House of Representatives, in particular, by allowing members, including independent members—as members would know, I am now an independent member—the opportunity to have a more detailed say and to more frequently voice their views.
—Could I say a very good independent member.

—That is very kind of you. I was going on to say—and this is not following on from the member's statement; I am not merely trying to replicate his compliments—that I congratulate the chairman of the committee, the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), on the publication of the report. Both he and the previous chairman have been very good chairmen of the committee. I have only been on the committee for a short time. In fact, this is my swan song because I am going to be resigning from the committee, as I am now an independent member, and that position will go back to the coalition member who will be taking my place.
—Who is present.

—Who is present here today, that is, the member for Wentworth (Mr Thomson). I commend the member for Wentworth on his interest in the procedures of the House and I look forward to hearing and reading his contributions to the workings of the committee. I am sure he will make a great contribution, obviously bringing from his background a new perspective to the workings of the House, not the least of which will be his great interest in the workings of similar legislatures around the region, of which he has great knowledge.

PARA.TAB: I once again commend the staff of the secretariat of the committee because they have also been responsible for helping us to prepare what I consider to be an important and useful report that will assist in compelling, or perhaps influencing, the government to make the changes necessary to allow this process in the House of Representatives and the Main Chamber to evolve in a way that is going to allow for a greater movement of power back to the parliament—in the case of the workings of the House of Representatives—vis-a-vis the executive. I can see the member for Charlton nodding.

I think we would all agree that in many ways the recent history of the House of Representatives has seen a decline in the authority of the relative standings between the Executive and the parliament that needs to be stopped. The process needs to be reversed to allow the people's representatives to properly bring forward the views of their constituents and make sure they have an opportunity to influence the day-to-day events of the House of Representatives and indeed the parliament.

There are a few observations I would like to make in relation to the workings of the House. The first is in relation to the explanatory memorandum, which was the subject of the recommendation that departments should take steps to improve the usefulness of explanatory memoranda to members and others seeking clarification on the nature, purpose and effect of legislation. We also recommended that, whenever possible, in the case of government bills, ministers should make an explanation to the House of any amendments or requests for amendments made by the Senate on which the Senate is seeking agreement of the House.

In our deliberations I cited the case of the Training Guarantee Levy Bill where there was a conflict between the explanatory memorandum and the actual bill. That was very confusing for those people who are responsible in their own businesses or elsewhere for the administration of—or response to—the legislation. In this particular case, there was a difference in the way in which one calculated the training guarantee liability on the part of a business. In fact, the explanatory memorandum allowed for the inclusion of sick leave and long service leave whereas the actual bill excluded it.

When the people at the particular business that contacted me about the matter made inquiries of the Taxation Office, which had the responsibility for administering the act, they were informed that the bill was right and the explanatory memorandum was wrong. Clearly, people relying on the explanatory memorandum for guidance as to how the act was supposed to work would have been thoroughly confused about the difference in the amounts applicable to employing more people. In this particular case, they told me that in their business they could have employed an extra person on the difference between the two interpretations of the explanatory memorandum and the bill itself. That is a very important point.

The second important matter was raised by the member for Moncrieff. I commend her for her contribution as deputy chair. She has always taken a strong interest in the workings of parliament in the Senate and continues that role in the House of Representatives. She has been instrumental in making the recommendation that the standing orders be amended to enable a minister to move the second reading of a government bill immediately following the first reading and for debate then to be adjourned to a future day. The recommendation also seeks to make the second reading speech available for members so that they can not only interpret the legislation but also make their own contributions to the debate. It is thoroughly confusing if the second reading speech is not available, particularly if interpretations of legislation have already been made by the minister or if there is a policy, for example, on the interpretation of legislation which would cause debate or questions that would need to be clarified as to exactly how legislation would work.

The member who spoke previously mentioned my own particular interest in questions on notice. As I am now an independent member I am more conscious of the fact that there are limited opportunities for ministers to be questioned by members of the House. I am particularly concerned that the questions on notice that are placed on the Notice Paper should be accorded the seriousness they deserve by those responsible for answering them. In previous times there have been extraordinary delays in the responses made by ministers to questions placed on the Notice Paper, to the extent that the process has been undermined. At the end of each question time, as we know, the minister, the Leader of the House or the Prime Minister—whoever is responsible—moves that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper, signifying how important as part of the process of questioning the questions on notice actually are.

I think that we on the committee unanimously felt that it was absurd that often, in the case of questions on notice, not only were ministers not responding to them for up to years in the sitting of a particular parliament but, in some instances, never answered the questions before the parliament concluded. Therefore those questions fell over the end of the cliff.

In the workings of the changes to the sessional orders that were recommended and introduced as a consequence of our previous report About time, we have seen a process whereby at the conclusion, where 90 days has passed and the question has not been responded to by a minister, members can stand up and ask the Speaker to write to the minister concerned requesting that an answer be given. I think that is a perfectly reasonable process. The difficulty is, of course, that 90 days is a long time and I am very pleased that the committee has decided to change that to 60 days. That will put additional pressure on to ministers to gee up their process of answering questions. As we all know, sometimes questions have an immediate effect or immediate importance and, after 90 days, they disappear into what the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) often calls `the ether'.

That is a part of the process that individual members want to see reinforced and buttressed. Therefore, our recommendation that the 90 days be reduced to 60 days is a thoroughly useful one. In fact, at the conclusion of the question period on each sitting Thursday, it is recommended that the Speaker should make a report to the House listing those ministers to whom he or she has written pursuant to the standing order, any responses received, and those ministers who were reported in a previous report as having been written to and who have not responded, giving the date of the original letter. That report would be recorded in Hansard.

That is a very important part of our processes. After all, in the final analysis, the only opportunity for members really to question the workings of government in a direct way is in the question time period. I know that there is a recommendation there to bring question time to 2.30—another important move. I was a critic of the move to 3 o'clock in the first instance, because I believed that it would make it extraordinarily difficult for the media, particularly the electronic media on which the public relies so heavily for information, to actually report in a proper way, in a fair way, the question time period. Of course, because of the concertina effect between 3 o'clock and the ending of question time at half past four, the electronic media in particular often found it extraordinarily difficult to be able to deal with the tape and all the other video arrangements so that the public could be properly informed of what had gone on that day in question time.

We obviously are concerned about the rostering system because the rostering system has led to instances where ministers are not present on particular days and a line of questioning has not been able to be followed by the opposition. If one were to see the parliamentary process as an adversarial one, then the question time period is the grinding edge of our democratic system. Clearly, if the members of the public are to retain any vestiges of confidence in their political system, then they need to know that that particular process works. I know that many probably view it with some jaundice in that they see on television the noise, the commotion and the dynamics of it, but nonetheless that is the grinding edge of our political democratic system. As a consequence, it is important that it works properly.

In the final analysis, it is important that the public see it working properly. Therefore, it is absolutely critical that the starting time of question time be moved to 2.30. If that is not the case, then we are going to see the continuation of the problem that question time will not be properly reported to the public because, as I said, it is so close to the deadlines for the electronic media on which most people rely for their daily information.

The other aspect on question time is that members of the opposition and other members of the House who are wanting to question ministers about particular aspects of their portfolio are in a position to request the presence of a minister so that they can answer questions that happen to be pertinent to that particular day's events.

In conclusion, the report is not everything we would like to see, and not everything I would like to see. There are a number of things that we have obviously had to compromise on to come to a determination in the committee. Nonetheless, I think this is an important adjunct to the About time report from last year from which those important changes were made. We would like to see enhanced opportunities for members to use the questioning process in a more incisive way.

I am looking forward to seeing how the recommendations affect the government's view and whether in fact it responds in a way that is going to allow us to have that opportunity. As an independent member, I am anxious to see that the House works in a way that allows the people's representatives to be able to represent the views of the community, and to make sure that ministers are properly accountable for the administration of taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to restrict my comments on the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure, Time for review: Bills, questions and working hours, to chapter 9.2 on sitting hours, which is in the report on pages 31, 32 and 33.

PARA.TAB: Mr Filing interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —In that respect, I appear on behalf of Western Australian members, their spouses and their families.
—We acknowledge the Smith amendment.

—That is right. I would like to start by thanking the chairman, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), and the committee for giving me the opportunity to have informal discussions with the committee in the course of its deliberations. I will make the point that none of the suggestions I made were taken up—
—We tried.

—I will repeat them for the benefit of the chairman, who is here, and for the benefit of the committee. I must say that I have had the fullest and most complete cooperation of the chairman and I have found him to be amenable to all my suggestions—
—Always.

—In that respect, he is much more amenable than his predecessor was; although, as history shows, I had a little bit more success with the committee than I did with the chairman. I prefer the chairman on this occasion but not the committee.

PARA.TAB: Let me make a point about the difficulties which the chairman has in respect of sitting hours. The chairman sits on a massively malapportioned committee. This is a committee which is massively malapportioned in terms of New South Wales, length of service of members and safety of seats. In other words, the views and the deliberations of this committee do not reflect those people throughout the parliament who live in outlying states, who occupy marginal seats and who are the newer or younger members of this parliament who are more likely to have families with young children.

I appear on behalf of my wife, my 3 1/2-year-old son and my 18-month-old daughter, and the other family members from Western Australia. I know that all my comments will be joined by my friend and colleague the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser). With all the difficulties that Western Australian metropolitan members have, at least when we touch down at the airport we have a short drive home; when he touches down at the airport, he has an additional two hours drive to get to Bunbury.

Let me look at the massively malapportioned committee in terms of safety of seats. I will not go through all the individual seat holders. The chairman, of course, has a margin of 17.2 per cent. I will not get down to the fine analysis as to how much of that is his personal vote and standing, but the average safety of the seats of the members is over 12 per cent. In terms of the membership of the committee, five members come from New South Wales, two from Queensland and one from Western Australia.

I note the comments of the independent member for Moore (Mr Filing)—the very fine independent member for Moore—that he has been obliged to retire from the committee to be replaced by another safe seat New South Wales member. I can understand the chairman's difficulties here. The massive malapportionment of seniority, safe seats and New South Wales is only going to be enhanced, although the member for Wentworth (Mr Thomson) will, of course, bring some youthful aspirations and vigour to the deliberations of this committee.

When one looks at length of service, the average tenure of committee members is over 10 years. This does not include the service which the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) had previously in the Senate. So this is a committee which does not have as part of its full focus a view for the difficulties caused to outlying state members, to marginal seat holders or to those members likely to have young families.

What is the starting point? It is prospective changes to sitting hours. As I have said, these are in section 9.2 of the committee's report. What brought about the current system? It was brought about by a view that the parliament was sitting too late into the night. When I first arrived in this place in May 1993, the schedule of sitting patterns and hours for the House was that we sat Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, then Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday. Invariably, we sat until 11.30 at night and, from memory, on Wednesday we got up at 8 o'clock.

That was changed—I think sensibly—to the 8 o'clock close from Monday through to Wednesday, and a 6 o'clock close on Thursday. The rationale for that was that it was not sensible to sit those late hours. That was right. The price that was paid for that was that we sat Monday to Thursday, Monday to Thursday, on a fortnightly cycle. In other words, we sat an additional Monday throughout our entire sitting pattern.

What effect did that have on Western Australian members? The effect was that they lost 10 Sundays per year in their electorate or with their families. Why is that the case? If members are required to arrive at the parliament on Monday, then they must leave Perth on a Sunday. The latest that members can leave Perth on a Sunday is effectively 5 o'clock, on a flight to Melbourne. That flight arrives in Melbourne at about 11 o'clock and then, courtesy of ministerial arrangements, the members catch a RAAF VIP flight to Canberra. They arrive in Canberra in theory at 12.30. Life being what it is, that is usually any time between 12.30 and 1.30 a.m. The consequence for the electorate and the families of those members from Western Australia is that they effectively lose 10 Sunday afternoons per year.

The original recommendation which saw those changes had the close of sitting at 8 o'clock on a Thursday. I made Neal Blewett's life such a misery that in the end the committee recommended that the parliament close at 6 o'clock on Thursday to at least give members from outlying states the chance to get home on a Thursday night. In that respect, I was grateful for the strong support I received from the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) and the member for Banks (Mr Melham).

Let us look at how that change has worked in practice. It has been the case—but more often not—that the 6 o'clock close enables members from Western Australia to get on a 6.30 plane to arrive in Western Australia at 11.30. From time to time, the 6 o'clock close on Thursday becomes an 8 o'clock close. In the course of recent months, that has occurred more often than not, either for the budget reply of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), or for his reply on the republican issue. So that opportunity is sometimes lost. If the parliament does not get up until 8 o'clock on a Thursday night, members from Western Australia cannot get home on Thursday night, and so they lose that opportunity.

In the course of my suggestions to the committee at our informal session, I elaborated on my formal written submission which suggested that the parliament should close earlier on the Thursday evening. My basic submission was that modest adjustments to our closing time on Thursday, coupled with modest adjustments to airline schedules, would guarantee that members from Western Australia, if they so desired—which I invariably do, and the member for Forrest shares my passionate obsession—would have the opportunity to return home on a Thursday night.

That suggestion was not taken up by the committee. The most weighty point that was made in response to my suggestion was that, with parliament question time starting at 3 o'clock, and with the MPI on a Thursday, to close the House at 5.00 or 5.30 would leave no time for other matters and would not take into account things that might develop out of question time, such as censures and the like. I think that is a sensible point.

My fallback position was: `Why don't we suggest some modest changes to the airline arrangement?' So I took the opportunity of getting hold of the submissions by Qantas and Ansett. I will read them into the record because they make patently clear that neither of the airlines has any understanding of what we do. That reflects as badly on us as it does on them, because it makes crystal clear the point that we have not bothered to take up the changes in our sitting patterns with the airlines in any forceful, constructive or detailed way. The Qantas submission says:

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas in providing travel management services to Members of Parliament and their staff have found the new procedures require more flexibility in arranging departure times. The previous Friday morning departure enable configuration changes to our aircraft in order to facilitate greater premium seat availability.
I read that twice and I asked the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) to explain to me what it meant. He said what it meant was that they had no understanding of what was going on.

PARA.TAB: I think that is right, and that is reflected by a notice from Qantas that I tabled at my informal session with the committee. It is headed `Qantas, the Australian airline, budget week special' and then tells us what a fantastic deal we get: we can depart Canberra and arrive in Perth on a new configurated jet on Thursday night, leaving at 7.40. The only problem is that no-one bothered to tell the people from Qantas, and they never bothered to check, that 7.40 happened to be 10 minutes into the reply by Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). That is not a plane that any person who has any respect for the courtesies of this parliament could catch. I happen to believe it is important to listen to the Leader of the Opposition's budget reply, whatever side of the House you are on. This reflected their ignorance, and our lack of effort, in seeking to make some sensible arrangements.
The Ansett airline reply is just as bad. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The key area affecting the airline is obviously the change in sitting hours, which has been brought forward on a Thursday. Essentially this factor has enabled Ansett Australia to provide a greater availability of our premium seating and relieved pressure on all associated Friday morning services.
So they are pleased that we are not there, en bloc, on Friday. It goes on to say:
From the traveller point of view, it also enables far better through service connections to ports further afield, such as Perth.
Well, I must confess I have dozed off and missed that bit! It further says:
Our increases in direct services to both Brisbane and Adelaide have also provided further flexibility in travel options around sitting arrivals and departure times.

In general terms a continuation of both the change in sitting times and improvements in our schedule ex Canberra has eased congestion on key flights and improved the ability for us to accommodate travellers.

That is, because all the politicians are not flying home on a Friday morning, things are easier for other people. But not one thought, not one jot, not one iota of effort—either by us or by them—has been put to the configurations which apply on a Thursday.

PARA.TAB: Here are the Thursday flight options which applied on the night of the Leader of the Opposition's budget reply and which apply tonight. There are five departures from Ansett between 4.30 and 7.40 p.m. and three departures from Qantas between 6.45 and 9.40 p.m. Five leave just before anyone would have the chance of even sneaking out the door once the adjournment started. Modest changes to the airlines' timetable and modest changes to our timetable would have the effect of ensuring that some people, if they wanted to—and this is entirely a matter of choice—would get home on Thursday night. Others might prefer to spend the entire week here. This was a point made to me by the member for Moncrieff in the course of the informal discussions. Other people would prefer to spend the four days here and then get back to home, family, electorate and constituents as quickly as humanly possible. That is my preference and I would like to try to guarantee that.
The other submission which I thought was worth quickly referring to was that by the Clerk of the House of Representatives, Mr Lyn Barlin. At page 6 of his submission he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The only additional comment I would make in relation to sitting hours is that there is very little effective government business time available on Thursday afternoons after 3.00 pm. There is frequently great pressure on available time before 5.30 pm once question time begins if any complication occurs (keeping in mind that there is usually a matter of public importance proposed for discussion as well.)

On a Thursday afternoon, once question time begins, you are never going to have any effective chance for government business. Why? Because Thursday afternoon is precisely the time that any opposition—worth its salt or not worth its salt—will raise censures, will cause disruption, for maximum political effect. The members opposite would do it, and we would do it if the roles were, however so disastrously or inelegantly, reversed. So any sensible management of government business requires that whatever business has to get done is done before question time on Thursday. After that, you are at the mercy of the political motivations of the opposition—which I respect and acknowledge.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the committee did not take up my suggestion that we close the parliament half an hour or an hour earlier on a Thursday. Its formal recommendation 9.3.6 recommended that question time should commence at 2.30 p.m. each sitting day. Game, set and match: 6-4, 6-4, 5-3; new balls; the member for Perth is serving. If question time is at 2.30 p.m., not one moment is lost by starting the House on Thursday morning at 9.00 and starting the adjournment at 5 o'clock rather than at 5.30. It is a modest half-hour adjustment and, with a bit of detailed vigorous application to the airlines, we might actually achieve some sensible configurations which would make life better for those honourable members from Western Australia and other outlying states who happen to have marginal seats and young families. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) for his contribution to the debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure. I also thank the chair and the deputy chair of the committee for their contribution not only to the debate but also to the committee report.

PARA.TAB: I want to take up some points made by the honourable member for Perth. His point about an earlier start on Thursday is something that ought to be seriously considered. It is only half an hour, as he said. However, as a member of the public works committee, I point out to him, in a marginally mischievous way, that it would require some negotiation with the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). This honourable member currently convenes a public works meeting at 8.30 in the morning and he might feel that 9.00 was a little intrusive. But that is relatively incidental. I would take up—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the honourable member for Throsby?

—Well, I must note that aside came from the honourable member for Perth and not from the honourable member for Wakefield. I would take up, however, the honourable member for Perth's rightful indignation at what he saw as a malapportionment of the committee. There was a heavy representation from the eastern states and a lack of representation from the western states. Therefore, as a South Australian, I have even more reason to be indignant, given that there are no South Australian representatives on the committee at all. I point out to the honourable member for Perth that, in the case of the opposition, appointment to the committee is largely by nomination through the whip's office. I am not sure what arrangements the government has for representation on the committee. If the honourable member for Perth is particularly anxious to have this malapportionment corrected, it is very much more in his hands than in the hands of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: All of us who come from states not as distant as Western Australia are sympathetic to the difficulty that the Western Australians allude to—to the pressure that sitting in the federal parliament places on young families and with the distances travelled. As a South Australian, I am very conscious of the fact that it is possible for me to be home in South Australia frequently before colleagues in Queensland or Tasmania are able to be home. In that sense, South Australia enjoys an advantage that is geographically denied to Western Australia.

I want to make a few comments about the report, and I want to make them in the context of this Parliament House. I share with both the chair and the deputy chair the reality of having worked in this Parliament House and in the former Parliament House building. I am one of those people who thought that the former Parliament House ought to have been remodelled and ought to have remained the home of the federal parliament. It is not a view that I would still maintain because I think this is a building in which it is a great privilege to work and the architecture and facility of the building is something of which we all should be proud. I do recognise that the building has inevitably two problems, and those of us who have worked in both buildings are more conscious of these problems than are those who have worked only in this building.

The two problems are that parliament is more polarised in this building and that it is easier for members of parliament to become isolated in this building. I lay the blame for the first problem, that of polarisation, largely at the feet of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and I do this in an uncharacteristically uncharitable way. The Prime Minister's style is to polarise the parliament. I respect his capacity to do this, but his style is to treat the opposition as if it were some lesser form of life.

That is something about which I am quite indignant. We need constantly to remind ourselves, as parliamentarians, that everyone in the parliament not only has a right to be there, by dint of having been elected, but also has a right to an opinion, whether in government or in opposition. The opposition, regardless of which party is in opposition, has an obligation to speak for all of those people who did not vote for the government. I am charitable enough to recognise that even the Prime Minister may be prepared to concede that in a private moment, but certainly none of his mannerisms in the House would attest to that approach. So I find existence in this house much more polarised than it was in the other house, with the same party in power but with a different person as the Prime Minister.

Having largely placed blame for the polarisation at the feet of the Prime Minister, I now address the question of isolation. This parliament building, by very reason of its extent, is a place in which people easily become isolated. As I look at the way in which the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure addresses the whole question of the structure and sitting times of the House, I think we have an obligation to ensure that we do all we can to break down any sense of individual isolation. Part of the isolation is inevitable because of the architecture of the building. Part of it is inevitable because of the extensive facilities that we all have in our own offices, which allow us to be individuals and, if we choose, not to mix extensively with our colleagues. But part of it is broken down, I think, by a structuring of the sitting hours to ensure that people have maximum contact with each other if they choose so to do.

One of the things that the Standing Committee on Procedure, when contemplating sitting hours, might care to take up is a proposal that we sit once again on Monday and Tuesday evenings; that there be a scheduled dining room time, as there once used to be, from 6.30 to eight; and that the parliament then sit from eight until 9.30, with a 9.30 adjournment. This would still allow the parliament to rise at a very respectable hour and it would still leave Wednesday evenings free for the sort of interaction that has become characteristic of Wednesday evenings, but it would mean that the total sitting time was extended and that the dining room became once again the focus for most honourable members who were in the parliament on a Monday and Tuesday evening.

I have not had an opportunity to discuss with the caterers, or with the Speaker's office, just what the impact on the dining room of our decision to rise at eight has been, but I suspect from what I have observed that it has been chaotic. I suspect that the caterers have no idea from one evening to another how many honourable members are likely to be dining in or dining out. It has also broken down the dining room fraternity that was built up, that was particularly significant in the old Parliament House and to a lesser degree extended into this Parliament House, but that now scarcely exists because at 8 p.m. people make a decision either to dine in or to dine out. I respect their right to do that, but the opportunity for some sort of parliamentary fraternity, by reason of the fact that we are all going to the dining room between 6.30 and eight, has been broken down.

So I would like the committee to consider taking Monday and Tuesday evenings and extending briefly the sitting time by, I am suggesting, not more than two hours—that may be a matter for negotiation—to ensure that the House still rose at a very civilised hour but that we remained more of a unit and that we broke down some of the isolation that I think unintentionally, but unfortunately, has come to characterise the parliament.

I would like to compliment the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) on the work that she has done on this committee and to acknowledge the role of the chairman and the role that the committee has played in endeavouring both to listen to the opinion of a wide range of people in the parliament and to incorporate, as far as they are able, that opinion in the report.

The suggestion by the honourable member for Moncrieff that, on the tabling of the first reading of a bill, the second reading speech ought to be made available is one that I would also like to endorse. Much is to be said for the capacity of the opposition to have at its fingertips, as early as possible, the information that the minister presents in the second reading speech so that informed debate can be a characteristic of the second reading of the bill.

I would like also to compliment the committee and give my support to the suggestion that question time ought to commence at 2.30. That has a great deal to commend it, not only from the point of view of ensuring that the media have a more comfortable opportunity to observe question time but also because one of the things that, incredibly, have characterised question time is that electors now find themselves less able to access question time on television than was the case, because of the congestion of television time beyond 3 p.m.

This led to an extraordinary reaction in my electorate—and I am being kind to the Leader of the House and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) in acknowledging this—in that one of my constituents, indignant at what was happening, sent a letter to the Deputy Prime Minister, with a copy to myself, saying that he was unhappy with the 3 p.m. question time and asking the Deputy Prime Minister why it was that the House had chosen to move to that time.

The Deputy Prime Minister—well intentioned, I am sure—replied, saying that one of the reasons that we had moved to 3 p.m. was that if there were visiting delegations it meant a very congested lunchtime, and the 3 p.m. question time allowed us to appropriately extend the lunchtime. That is perfectly true. But, constituents being what they are, and the image of parliamentarians being what it is, my constituent instantly translated that to mean that every lunchtime was extended from 12.30 until 3.00, that every lunchtime involved visiting delegations and that this was an indication of just how cavalier we, as a parliament, happen to be in the way in which we deal with the affairs of the state.

I know that was not the intention of the Leader of the House and Deputy Prime Minister, but I do think that, in a small way, the decision to go to 2.30 helped to break down that impression. Incidentally, I believe that the 2.30 question time has a great deal to commend it.

I also happen to find, along with other opposition members, that the present question time roster is a source of a frustration to us. The recommendation of the committee that would allow ministers to be brought in more frequently is one that ought to be endorsed by the parliament. I say to the member for Charlton that he may well recall—though it is now longer ago than I would care to admit—the frustration of being an opposition backbencher in question time, and the difficulty of getting opposition backbench questions up. That is frustrating enough, without having it complicated and compounded by the absence of ministers whom the opposition particularly wishes to question.

I also commend the committee on the decision to extend the grievance debate. That is entirely appropriate. Grievance ought to occupy the minimum of one hour and 20 minutes, and it has frequently been unintentionally compressed. I point out to the committee that the grievance debate is very important to all members, particularly to backbenchers. It does provide a unique opportunity, in that it allows backbenchers to participate during a broadcast time.

No-one should make any comparison between the grievance debate and the adjournment debate. The adjournment debate is seen as a relatively unimportant instrument in comparison with grievance. The decision to ensure that grievance no longer ends at 5.15, but becomes an obligatory one hour and 20 minutes, is one I would like to endorse.

I again thank the committee for their deliberations and their consideration. As I have indicated, I am largely happy with the recommendations outlined in the report. I would however ask the committee at some future date to consider the wisdom of extending Monday and Tuesday evening sittings, not only to extend the business of the House, but to in some small way break down the isolation which is an unintended consequence of working in this building. This is largely in the hands of us as individuals, but it would be facilitated if we were to spend more time in dining in the same place at the same time. That was certainly our experience in the old house—and such a change would be a relief to the caterers, who must find the present provisions quite unpredictable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure. He has done a very good job. I must say that the member for Moncrieff (Ms Sullivan) and I enjoy being members of the Procedure Committee. It allows us to hone our forensic skills and—

PARA.TAB: Mr Nehl interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —And of course we both have to put up with the bullfrog over there—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N. B. Reid)—Order! The honourable member should withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard a noise from the other side.
—Order! The honourable member should contain his remarks to the report.

—I would not have thought it was someone interjecting, because that would have been disorderly, and I doubt whether a member of the Procedure Committee would have been wanting to be disorderly; so I was responding to an echo from the corner, Mr Deputy Speaker. The member for Moncrieff and I enjoy our membership, particularly with the chairmanship of the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) who allows us to go on.

PARA.TAB: Mr Nehl interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There goes the echo again. It must be the high ceiling or the fact that the ponds are starting to empty out and the bullfrogs are coming back into the chamber. The member for Charlton sometimes let the member for Moncrieff and me have our long discussions, and he could go out and have a coffee and come back, and not much would have changed. I tried to have a deal with the member for Moncrieff at one stage such that, if she and I both did not go to the meetings, they would probably get them over with pretty quickly. But, as both of us would miss that so much, we decided that an arrangement like that would not be terrific for parliamentary democracy, let alone for our own particular interests.

PARA.TAB: Procedure Committee meetings are very interesting, and I think the committee has, over the period since its inception, done a lot to change the way in which the culture of this place works. Those members who have been here for a while might remember that, prior to the Procedure Committee, we used to have a standing orders committee, which used meet on a very irregular basis. In the main, the government would say no to anything the opposition said, and the opposition would come away unhappy. Now we have the Procedure Committee being very generous, and the government being exceptionally generous in accepting recommendations, and the opposition members still are not happy, but they have probably now got more reason to be less unhappy than we were when the standing orders committee was in operation.

I find it very interesting nowadays to listen to interjections and points of order at question time about how terrible the standing orders are. I have a quiet smile when I look over at the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). If the opposition thinks that the current standing orders for question time are draconian, terrible, horrid and awful, and that they stop democratic discussion and allow ministers to get away with all sorts of devilment, then they can thank the right honourable member for New England, because these were all his idea when he was persecuting us some years ago.

The Procedure Committee has adopted a more enlightened attitude to many of these things, and I will mention just a couple of those things in this debate and say a few things about what the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) have said. The member for Wakefield wants to dine and the member for Perth wants to go home. The committee looked long and hard at the propositions put forward by people about these sorts of arrangements. When we looked at the cut-off time for debate—6 o'clock on Thursdays—we also consulted the airline timetables.
