We were very careful in our original report to put forward proposals for the sitting patterns of the House that would allow members from every capital city except Hobart to return home on Thursday night. Most country people can return home on Thursday night. There are a few people who come from the very outlying states, and from the very outlying parts of those states, and they would have difficulty getting home on a Thursday night. If we brought the time forward, most of those people might get home just a little earlier, but it would not accommodate people who are from places with more difficult transport connections. While there might be some symmetry in the mind of the member for Perth about the committee asking for question time to be brought forward to 2.30 p.m.—in that that might allow us to finish at 5.30 p.m.—I do not think that that symmetry was intended, and I doubt whether there would be a change in the time that the government would propose as the start of question time.

The member for Wakefield says that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) might have caused one of the member for Wakefield's constituents to believe that the life of us all down here is one long lunch hour, and that that is why we have the parliament sit at 3 o'clock. It is not for that purpose. The sitting at 3 o'clock is to accommodate frontbenchers—ministers from the government side, and opposition frontbenchers—so that they are able to do things in other parts of this city and on the eastern seaboard during the morning and still get back to participate in question time, which is one of the most important parts—if not the most important part—of the parliamentary day. Under the old arrangements of 2 o'clock, that blocked out the day, but 3 o'clock allows people both to do their duty at question time and to be able, often, to see to some political activity in, say, Melbourne, Sydney or the city of Canberra itself. That sort of activity is a far better arrangement for constituents than our being able to finish at 5.30 p.m. on Thursdays.

There are some other matters that the member for Wakefield raised where he thought that we might sit later on a couple of nights of the week so that he and his colleagues can dine with each other. It is good to see that members of the opposition are convivial in this way, because newspaper reports say that they would rather feast on each other's blood than they would sit down—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a monstrous calumny.

—I can hear that echo over there again. I have got to say to the minority whip that he ought to tell his colleague who is sitting next to him that, if he wants to participate in the high-minded activities of the Standing Committee on Procedure, he should not learn these evil little concepts of interjection, particularly when—
—Why are you against free speech?

—It is like a well-known story in this place in the past—it would be most unruly if I used it. We keep getting these echoes. It is going to tempt me to say something to the member for the Princes Highway. I hope that you will protect me from the echo, Mr Deputy Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—The honourable member should concentrate his remarks on the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question whether we should sit late at night is one that a lot of members would not be happy with. What we have in the current sitting pattern is some consistency where people can plan either to dine later at 8.00 p.m. or to go out of the building. It gives people that flexibility, which is what people always demanded. One of the worst aspects of this building in the past was that we were all cooped up in here until 11.00 p.m. each night. We would arrive at 8.30 a.m. and get out at 11.00 p.m., we would go home, go to sleep and come back here at 8.30 the next morning. We never had any contact with the real world. These changes were made to encourage members not just to associate with their colleagues, but also to have the capacity to socialise on a wider sphere in Canberra and to do more human things than to sit around and plot and plan like the old sitting pattern used to encourage people to do. The executives on both sides encouraged this because they do not like backbenchers sitting around plotting and planning.

PARA.TAB: The Main Committee was one of the great innovations of the Procedure Committee. Since the Main Committee has come into operation, we have not had to have any guillotines, except in the first week for some roll-over business from the last session. We have had a far greater capacity for members to participate in debate. I do not think there has been any debate on legislation in the House that we have had to truncate since the Main Committee commenced operating.

The budget debate this year was probably the best example, with the government wanting to have the budget completed by a particular time and sent to the Senate. Had we not had the Main Committee, we would have had about eight hours less debate on the budget this year than we had. The Main Committee has been very useful for that. Indeed, this morning we are going to discuss this report for about 2 1/2 hours. The reality is that running up to the end of session, if we had not had the Main Committee in operation, we would have had the member for Charlton tabling this report in the House—we did not even have a tabling speech—and, with the best endeavour, the government may have got time for half an hour of debate some time this week or next week.

The Main Committee is a singular success in providing opportunities for members of parliament to make contributions to legislation. I take this opportunity to mention the unfortunate demise of the member for Moore (Mr Filing). It is a shame that the opposition did not see fit to leave the member for Moore on the Procedure Committee because it might have been useful to have non-government members other than members of the National Party and members of the Liberal Party represented on the committee.

The member for Moore, as a Liberal member on the committee, made a very good contribution to the work of the committee. Although this is a decision that the opposition can make, it is unfortunate, to my mind, that the member for Moore is not allowed by the opposition to stay on the committee in the quota of non-government members. However, I place on record the fact that, although I did not agree with some of the things that the member for Moore said, the member for Moore made some very useful contributions to the committee. Some of the points of view of the member for Moore are reflected in this report and in previous reports of the committee.

The committee has made a suggestion concerning policy statements made by ministers outside the House, and I hope that the government will take up the committee's suggestion. With the way government works and with concerns about timeliness, et cetera, ministers often make important statements outside the house on matters about which members of parliament are very interested. The most significant statement in this regard is the Justice Statement which was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) recently. If these sorts of statements are not made in the House, they are, in a sense, matters unknown to the parliament.

The proposal of the committee is to the effect that a minister who makes a statement of some significance away from parliament can table the statement in the parliament. The proposal means that a motion can be moved to take note of the statement, the House can find time for it to be debated and members can then make a contribution. Debate on these sorts of papers would probably take place in the Main Committee because the Main Committee provides us with a vehicle in which to deal with such matters. This is a matter that the government could take up.

The committee is not proposing that, when a minister tables a paper, the paper be debated there and then in the House. The committee's proposal is to the effect that a minister could come in and table a paper. A motion could then be moved to take note of the paper and the matter would then go onto the Notice Paper. The government could either make time in the House for debate, or, with the agreement of the opposition, make time for debate in the Main Committee.

In completing my remarks, I pay tribute to my colleague, the opposition whip, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). The business of this committee is carried out by agreement between the opposition whip and I. The approach of the opposition to the operation of the Main Committee is a positive one and the response by members is also positive. The members of the Procedure Committee can take credit for a parliamentary innovation in this country which is unknown in any other part of the Westminster system. I commend the report and I thank the Procedure Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity of rising to speak on the motion to take note of the report of the Procedure Committee on the review of procedural matters operating since 21 February 1994. I am very sorry that the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) is suffering from a frog in his throat or in his head or somewhere. It is something that happens to him quite often and he manages to survive. He will undoubtedly recover from this attack.

PARA.TAB: I would like to start by paying tribute to the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), as Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure, for an excellent job, sometimes under slightly trying circumstances. I allude there to the spirited exchanges sometimes occurring between the honourable member for Watson and the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), which do add a little to the time taken by the committee but also add to the understanding of the issues that are involved. I congratulate the honourable member for Charlton and thank my fellow members of the committee for a job that has been well done. I would also mention the committee secretariat, and particularly our secretary, who has done an excellent job—sometimes under very trying and difficult circumstances indeed. The facility to coalesce a point of view and actually get it down in a few words has been quite outstanding.

I have had not had the opportunity of hearing everybody who has spoken in this debate but I did hear most of what the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) had to say. I must say that I am sorry that he feels inconvenienced in this way but the reality is that you win some and you lose some. It is unfortunate that he finds it difficult living in Perth. We are all responsible for our own choices. I choose to live in the wonderful place called Coffs Harbour, which is subtropical and delightful. That is my choice. If the honourable member for Perth chooses to live in Perth, that it is his choice, and if he cannot stand the heat he should get out of the kitchen. I understand the difficulties he has got. He says that, although he can get home on Thursday night, he gets home late. I cannot get home on Thursday night—with a 6 o'clock rising I cannot get to Sydney in time to catch the last plane to Coffs Harbour. I am more disadvantaged than the honourable member for Perth, who can get home, albeit fairly late at night. So I have not got a great deal of sympathy with that argument.

The honourable member complained also that he has to leave Perth at about 5 o'clock on Sunday evening on 10 Sundays a year. I am surprised that it is only 10—I thought we sat considerably more than that many weeks. But I also leave home at about 5 o'clock on the Sunday evening because I like to be down here for the Monday morning, to know that I can arrive and will not be blocked out by fog as so often happens in Canberra during the winter. It also gives me the opportunity to attend various committee meetings and get organised for the parliamentary week. So I do not see that as a great problem.

The honourable member for Perth said that this year on a majority of the Thursday nights we had been sitting late, until 8 o'clock, because the Leader of the Opposition was making statements in response to various things. In actual fact, there have been two occasions this year and I am not aware of any last year when that has happened.

The honourable member said also that any opposition worth its salt would be moving censures, suspensions of standing orders and so on, and no government business would be done on the Thursday afternoon after question time. The reality is that in the last 18 months, since these new sessional orders came in and we started rising at 6 o'clock, there have been six censure motions. That does not apply to every week. There have also been 16 suspensions of standing orders—surprisingly, or perhaps not surprisingly when one thinks about it, 10 of those from the government. I imagine the six suspensions of standing orders were the same as for the six censures from the opposition, but the government has had need to suspend standing orders on 10 occasions since the new sessional orders came in. Obviously, it wanted to introduce something or change the order of business. The assertion by the honourable member for Perth that government business on every Thursday is disrupted by the opposition is not an absolutely correct assertion.

I do agree with the honourable member for Perth about the airlines' understanding of what happens in this place and the requirements of members and senators. I do not think they have got a clue. He is quite right to suggest that there needs to be a fairly significant improvement in communication between us and the airlines, because they are very significant to our lives.

I want to talk about question time. I do not like the 3 o'clock timing of it. The honourable member for Watson has reminded us all of the fact, which I understood already, that the executive—he mentioned shadow ministers as well but basically it is the ministers—needs to be able to undertake activities in this city and on the eastern seaboard. Consequently it is much more convenient for the executive to have question time at 3 o'clock.

I think the downside of that is that, by having question time at 3 o'clock, it is never televised live. It is televised at half past 12 or 1 o'clock in the morning. Of course, when the ABC replays it at that time, the audience is fairly limited. It is important that the people of Australia have the opportunity of seeing what is happening in question time. After all, question time is the focus of the parliamentary day. It is the only time that we have the Prime Minister there twice a week. Under the old system, we used to have all ministers present at question time—the entire shadow ministry still attends—but there is now a roster for ministers.

Question time is the only time, when it is being televised, when the press gallery is in the chamber. The press gallery is half empty on Tuesdays and Wednesdays. The press gallery is full on Monday and Thursdays, when the Prime Minister is there and we can expect a bit of fireworks. The public galleries generally tend to be full on the Mondays and Thursdays but are half empty on Tuesdays and Wednesdays. This indicates that the people of Australia believe that the parliamentary focus of the day is question time and that the greatest interest is there when the Prime Minister is present. It is absolutely essential that the Prime Minister is present. The Prime Minister is the leader of this country, no matter what party the Prime Minister leads, and we require that he be there and be available to be asked questions and to, hopefully, answer them.

People do not really understand what goes on in question time. Schools come here to go to question time. It used to be very hard to get in but it is much easier these days. Constituents, and particularly children, constantly say, after they have been to question time, `We would not be allowed to act like that at school.' And, of course, they are quite right. However, I tell them that they have to realise that question time is structured in a certain way so as to be very dramatic and very theatrical. It is the focus of the day and oppositions, in the past and in the future, whether us or the present government, have only 30 or 40 seconds in which to ask a question. The government ministers can take five, 10, 15, 20 minutes to answer a question. Mostly they do not answer; they are not in the business of answering questions or providing information. That is one of the shortcomings. I omit the honourable member for Charlton from that criticism because, when he was a minister, he would always answer questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good minister who actually did something.

—He was a good minister. But when he left special funding for the Pacific Highway stopped, the black spots were abandoned. I have no hesitation in praising the former transport minister for the great job that he did in that position. I wish he was still there, at least until the next election, because we might get a bit more money spent on the Pacific Highway.

PARA.TAB: As I said, question time is very important. It is the focus of the parliamentary day. I am opposed to the rostering of ministers. I believe that the Prime Minister should be there for every question time. It is also important that the people of Australia should be able to see their parliament in action. Question time is the only bit that they get to see, if they are still awake at 12.30 or 1 o'clock in the morning. We should change it, if for no other reason than the convenience of the people of Australia—not the convenience of ministers. People keep telling me that they would like to see question time but that they do not want to stay up that late to watch it.

I agree with the proposition that there should be more time for the grievance debate. This is a very significant area, particularly for private members business. I relish the opportunity to speak in the grievance debate and I spoke in the debate this Monday. I would have spoken last Monday but, because of the suspension of standing orders, grievance time was taken up. More time should be allocated for the grievance debate.

The member for Watson said that the Main Committee is a tremendous step forward and I agree with him. I think it is excellent. It is providing opportunities for members to speak about things that are important to them and even more important to their constituents. I approve of what we are doing. However, the member for Watson said that there had been no guillotine. That is absolutely incorrect. He was correct in saying that we had an additional period of time to debate the budget in the Main Committee. Approximately a day and a half extra debating time was provided in this chamber. We did have the guillotine, there was a cut-off point and we did have the gag, which restricted people's opportunity of speaking. Some members did not get the opportunity to speak on the budget. I happen to know because I was one of them. I was down on the list and, because of the guillotine, even with the gag operating, it was still impossible for me to speak on the budget.

The budget is the most important document and piece of legislation to come before the parliament and I believe every member should be given the opportunity of speaking on it. I also make a suggestion which I made in the committee but which was not incorporated in the report: we should have provision in the Standing Orders for this committee to adjourn on certain occasions and in special circumstances when the Prime Minister of the day is making an important statement. During the last sitting there was an occasion when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was making a major statement and all of us who were involved in the Main Committee operation wanted to be in the House listening to the Prime Minister. As the member for Perth said, it is important that all members have the opportunity to hear major statements, whether they be from the Prime Minister or from the Leader of the Opposition. I appreciate the comment that he made about that. I suggest in future considerations we look at putting in the provision for this committee to adjourn when major statements are being made.

Ministerial statements is another area we need to tighten up. Too often many mini-ministerial statements are made in answers to questions. I think that is wrong. I do not point the bone only at the present government. I am sure we did the same thing when we were in government although I would hope that we did not. Ministerial statements should be made as ministerial statements because that then gives members of the parliament representing the people of Australia the opportunity to debate them. Statements can be referred to this chamber and that means there is an opportunity for all of us to have a say on them.

The member for Watson also mentioned the ministerial statements outside the House and I totally agree that, if this happens—and I do not believe it should—they should be tabled in the House so that they can be debated. He mentioned the Justice Statement. I have need of the Justice Statement and only yesterday my staff member was told that we have to buy it from the government bookshop. It is appalling that members of this parliament cannot get hold of such an important parliamentary document as the Justice Statement without having to buy it. I would put that on the record as well.
Mr Melham interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we were told we had to buy it. The final point I make is that we need the Prime Minister of the day to be more statesmanlike and dignified in question time and at other times. I suggest, with the best goodwill in the world, that the present Prime Minister has denigrated the high office of Prime Minister of this country and he needs to comport himself with more dignity in keeping with the traditions of parliamentary democracy.

—I welcome the opportunity to comment on the Standing Committee on Procedure's report entitled Time for review: Bills, questions and working hours. This report is a very worthy additional contribution to the initial reforms that were undertaken as a result of the committee then chaired by the former member for Bonython, Dr Blewett, which I think have very much enhanced the workings of the parliament. I have only been here a relatively short time—a couple of years—but I certainly believe that, in general, those reforms have been very positive. In an overall sense, the comments that are in this report under the auspices of the committee now chaired by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) are very worthwhile.

PARA.TAB: I refer to a number of the specific themes that are mentioned in the report and add my views to some of the things that have been mentioned by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and some of the previous speakers. Firstly, it is fairly widely recognised that this Main Committee has been a successful innovation within the proceedings of the parliament. The comments in the report indicate that the Main Committee should be continued as an integral part of the process of debate, consideration of reports, legislation and the like. I would certainly endorse that and endorse the comments that the honourable member for Cowper made in that regard.

I note the comments that were made in the report with respect to the public gallery and the need to take steps to encourage visitors to parliament to come and watch the proceedings of the Main Committee as well as the proceedings of the House itself. It is fortunate that the members of the committee did not go into any detail about the types of initiatives that we might want to pursue in that regard: perhaps a hot dog stand or one or two other things might assist. But I think it is important to keep these things in perspective—that people do come to see the proceedings of the chambers of the parliament for reasons other than just seeing politicians. It is ultimately the base of our democratic system of government and there is a certain symbolism associated with seeing the parliament, in seeing the House of Representatives, which clearly is not replicated within the Main Committee because the Main Committee is simply an adjunct to the House of Representatives.

Whether we like it or not, I think that this Main Committee will always be something of a poor cousin to the House of Representatives. Therefore we should not concern ourselves unduly with the lack of attendance and the fact that today, in spite of the fact that I am doing my best to make a good contribution, we have only got a couple of people sitting opposite in the seats available for the public.

The second point to which I wish to advert is the issue of question time. Both the rostering system and the timing of question time are raised in the report. With respect to the timing matter, I am something of an agnostic. I think that the later time of question time is marginally better for backbenchers in terms of the various other obligations that backbenchers have. I really do not have a particularly strong view about the alternative that has been put forward of 2.30 p.m. rather than 3 p.m.

However, I do have a couple of views about the question of rostering. One recommendation that is put forward is that the opposition be entitled to demand the presence of one minister at any question time, obviously in order to ensure that, where there is a particular issue running and a particular minister is under pressure, that minister cannot hide behind the fact of not being on a roster on the particular day.

This is probably a reasonable suggestion, but it needs to be kept in mind that ministers do other things; they do have other responsibilities. Part of the difficulty in pursuing this suggestion is that we would need to ensure that ministers actually had some notice that they were going to be required to attend question time. Otherwise they would not be able to schedule alternative commitments: meetings with delegations, functions and the like. In a sense, the more notice we require the opposition to give a particular minister, the more we defeat the purpose of the exercise in the first place. It then becomes very difficult for the opposition to know two or three days in advance that a particular minister is going to be targeted at a particular question time. Of course, it forces them to telegraph their punches, in a sense, as to what type of theme they are going to be running in question time.

In essence, it is a worthwhile and constructive suggestion, and I think that the spirit of the suggestion is very logical and fair, but some further work on the detail may be necessary in order to work up an appropriate proposal. I should add that, in a sense, some of the criticisms that are made of the new system of question time by the opposition really only have value because it has failed to make use of the opportunities, by and large, that are offered by the new arrangements. One of the opportunities that is offered by the new arrangements is the ability to concentrate on particular lower profile ministers in more junior ministries, to really give them a hammering and put them under some pressure, to test just how much they are on top of their portfolios and to see whether they are fully across the difficult issues that might be pertinent at the time.

In spite of those opportunities, the opposition, in my observation, has not yet taken that option. It has not been able to make use of that. I think the opposition would find that it would get greater value out of the new question time arrangements if it started to pay a bit more attention to some of the ministers who very rarely get asked questions by the opposition. I think the statistics would show that a large number of ministers have barely been asked a question by the opposition in the time that this parliament has sat—maybe one or two, but certainly not very many—and that they tend to rely on government backbenchers to ask questions, to keep them occupied in question time.

The next issue I refer to is sitting hours. I have some sympathy with the honourable member for Cowper about the question of being able to get home on Thursday night. I am certainly of the view that we should conduct our arrangements in such a way as to enable pretty well all honourable members to get home on Thursday night. To me, the great advance made by the reforms under the Blewett committee was to enable the vast majority of honourable members to get home on Thursday night. It means for me that I can now work a normal Friday rather than wandering around in a semi-comatose state, unable to do much more than sign correspondence and look at things coming across my in-tray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such a young man, too!
—I know. It is a lack of stamina. I am rapidly approaching 40, so unfortunately my best years are already well behind me.
—No, ahead of you.

—Let us hope so. I do have some sympathy with the view of the honourable member for Cowper. To me, if we are faced with a choice of extra hours on the Thursday evening or, for example, sitting till 9 or 10 o'clock on the Tuesday evening or the Wednesday evening, it is much more logical to sit later on the evenings when we are required to be in Canberra in any event.

PARA.TAB: It is also worth pointing out that we have actually saved the taxpayer a bit of money by enabling honourable members to leave on Thursday night, because there is one less day for which people will claim travel allowance. We have also ensured that honourable members are able to spend a slightly greater amount of time with their families, which is ultimately a fairly important question.

I have some sympathy with the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), when he refers to the speeches by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), with respect to the republic and to the budget, which twice now we have had to have on the Thursday night. This has forced honourable members either to delay their return home until the following morning or to go through some rather bizarre travel arrangements in order to get home late on Thursday night.

I would not mind that quite so much if there were any content in what the Leader of the Opposition said in his speeches. Unfortunately, in the one on the republic he took 30 minutes to say what anybody could have said in about three minutes, and his speech on the budget was essentially rhetoric with no specific propositions about alternatives, about what the opposition would do if it were in government. If there were a greater degree of substance in the speeches I would perhaps not quite mind so much, but to stay back to listen to vacuous nonsense is a bit irritating, to say the least.

I would say as an observation on this question of sitting times, schedules and so forth that I am an opponent of the parliament sitting more. It is a mistake that people in the community often make, to assume that the only real or important work that parliamentarians do is actually being in parliament and sitting. In fact, it is probably less important than the work that parliamentarians do in their constituency. It would worry me that, if we spent more time here, we of all political persuasions would end up being more remote, less in touch with our electors and less in touch with what is going on at the grassroots level in our electorates.

Ultimately what we do, day in, day out, when we are not in parliament, is go around our electorates, be at functions, deal with problems and talk to constituents, delegations and the like. To me that is probably the paramount role of a parliamentarian. Certainly for a backbencher it is the paramount role. To impinge on that for the purposes of longer sittings is wrong. Ultimately it has a undemocratic impact, in that we are less representative of the people who have actually elected us to be here.

The role of parliament is touched on in this report. A commentator a couple of years ago made an observation that parliament in our system is now little more than an electoral college that every two or three years elects an executive and then wallows in irrelevance. I think that is probably being a bit harsh, but there is a certain degree of substance to that. In a sense it reflects the increasing complexity of government. The emergence of parliamentary committees to some extent reflects those changes, so that a lot of the detailed action in consideration of legislation occurs less often in the chambers of parliament than perhaps it once did. So I think we all have a lot of thinking to do—

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.16 p.m. to 12.28 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension, I was making reference to the workings of parliament and its relationship to the executive. One of the things we could look at is how we seem to spend an enormous amount of time debating bills that involve minor, fairly technical amendments to legislation where we have to use the legislation as, in a sense, a heading to enable us to debate broader issues. I suppose there is a necessity for that, but, on some occasions, it also involves the whips of all the major parties asking people to speak and, therefore, to fit themselves into a fairly artificial structure of debate.

PARA.TAB: Our democracy would be much better suited if we were able to have substantive debates in the parliament on the key issues that face the nation rather than having to modify what we are saying and how we are saying it in order to fit in with, say, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 or whatever the case may be. Obviously, we still need to debate all of those technical amendments to legislation and so forth, but I am sure that we could do that in a much shorter time. Consideration of this reform of the parliament may, in future, be taken up by the Standing Committee on Procedure.

The final comment I make relates to the scheduling of parliamentary sessions. I am very pleased to see that I scored a footnote in the committee's report as a result of my brief submission and that relates to the fact that—

TALK.START.PARA: —So long as you don't become a footnote.

—That is right. That relates to the fact that, as a result of the changed timing of the budget, we now have three major breaks in the parliamentary calendar. The winter break is relatively unchanged—roughly seven weeks—but, because of the need to have a substantial break prior to the budget in order to allow ministers to prepare for the budget, the summer break has been shortened. This has led to a rather ridiculous situation where parliament is resuming sitting later in January. It is absurd that we should all be going back home to shiver in our electorates, those of us who do not go overseas—
—We don't shiver in Coffs Harbour.

—Those of us who live in the south shiver in our electorates for seven weeks when we could actually be sitting here for at least some of that time, and yet we are coming here late in January. One of the reasons this can cause problems for members—not that any of us are still likely to be on holidays late in January—is that I find that to come cold back to work and start sitting straightaway is often a problem. We get a little build-up of work over the Christmas-New Year period that we have to deal with and it is certainly better to be able to have a week or two of working in the electorate office before the House starts sitting.

PARA.TAB: I would normally return to work about that time in January so perhaps it is not such a huge problem. I do think that the recommendation the committee has made, that we start sitting on the first Tuesday in February rather than late January, is a sensible one. It gives a little more flexibility at a time of the year when it is better to be away from this place than it is during winter.

I also support the committee's recommendation that we should always sit on Mondays, with one exception. I think that is a sensible suggestion. It gets more value out of a week. It ensures that, if we are coming here, we actually get some substantial value from what we are doing and we do not lose a day for no particular reason other than that it is the start of a session. Overall, the report is a very good one, and I commend the honourable member for Charlton and the committee members for their work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks as one who participates very actively in the parliament—perhaps a little too actively at times. Certainly, in the time I have been here I have embraced the opportunities provided for a private member to put a point of view that, hopefully, on every occasion represents constituents' points of view. I believe I am well qualified after almost six years to make a few observations.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate the Standing Committee on Procedure for its work on this report, Time for review: Bills, questions and working hours, and on the former report. I believe it has done a very good job. I would be interested in being on the committee but I am already on too many committees. We cannot be everywhere. I am certainly very keen for the committee to continue its work. I think those of us who have been here for some time have lots of ideas about how the parliament can be improved.

I suspect the enthusiasm for change—I am not sure; the chairman might tell me—is probably greater on the opposition side than it is on the government side. That would probably be the case no matter who was in government or who was in opposition. Plainly, to a large extent the opposition bears the brunt of the government's decisions in respect of these practices. The government simply has the numbers. In the end, the parliament survives, I suppose, largely because of the conventions and a certain amount of goodwill that exists between the two sides.

There are a number of issues raised in this report that require ongoing consideration. I am sure that that is recommended and that there will be an ongoing process of consideration. I am one who is concerned about question time. I think all of us are: on our side, perhaps for different reasons. It is a pity that question time reflects so badly on us all as members. From our constituents, and particularly from school groups that come here, we all get tarred with the brush that is used in question time, that we are all a mob of louts.

I try to explain to people—I am sure we all do—that question time is a small part of the day. It is always going to be an active part. It is in the House of Lords; it is in every parliament of the world. I suppose to some extent it gives the opposition a good opportunity to make points, one way or another, in the form of the questions that it asks. In the end, the true purpose of question time ought to be as it is defined, to seek information and to have information provided. I understand that that is its purpose. I think the culture has to change.

We can talk about changing the rules as far as the Speaker's independence is concerned, but in the end there has to be an attitude by the government—and, hopefully, by us, if we were in government—that that is the purpose of question time, and that ministers will be required to answer questions and know more. The practice of ministers going off, as they inevitably do, to talk about what the opposition did 10 or 20 years ago, or to make a personal attack on the person who has asked the question, is not the intention. If we were in government, I think we would still find it a temptation to do that, but I am hoping that we would not do so. The chairman of the committee, the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has been here a lot longer than I have, and maybe it is a bit unrealistic of me to expect that to happen. The government can tinker with it and put bandaids on it and talk about the Speaker and his role until the cows come home; but, until it gets to the fundamentals, it is really only putting bandaids on it.

The other thing I would advocate—and I think the committee considered it in its previous deliberations—is that dorothy dix questions be banned. I suspect that I probably would go as far as to suggest that only opposition members ought to ask questions of the government, unless there can be some guarantee that we will not get the sort of charade that we get in question time every day. It really is a charade. Even the government blokes here would have to agree that, when they get up and ask a question that they read out and the minister has the answer prepared, that is really not—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question was written in his office.

—Exactly. That is exactly what happens, as my colleagues says. The minister writes the question out. He might be prompted occasionally—and I do not want to cast too many aspersions—by a member's interest in the subject. If a member asks, `What about we have a question on this?', the minister probably says—and I am only guessing—`Okay; you go away and I'll prepare a question,' and he gets his advisers in.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Melham

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you say this if you ever become a government backbencher?

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Order! Please address your remarks through the chair, and do not respond till you get the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure. The answer is then written out and the minister duly gets up and reads that answer. Inevitably, he goes on through pages 1, 2 and 3, unless he is particularly—
—It should be a ministerial statement.

—That is the other thing that I find, as my colleague says: fundamental abuses of question time occur and it is no wonder that the opposition is annoyed by that. When the present government members are in opposition after the next election, they will be just as annoyed about it, and I hope that, as the government, we will not do it. If ministers are asked questions that require them to make statements, then they ought to make statements. As I understand it, the only objection to doing that is that it then becomes a matter of debate. As my colleague who spoke a moment ago said, very often they ought to be matters of debate, as they are the sort of things we ought to be doing in the parliament.

PARA.TAB: If something is important enough for a minister to get up and talk for 10 or 15 minutes, then he ought to do it. There are plenty of places for him to do it, and I would encourage that. The answer to question time is an attitudinal and cultural thing, and I would like to think that, in government, we would fix question time up in that way, without tinkering around with it and trying to make it work by putting bandaids on it instead of making an actual cultural change.

Sure, it depends a lot on the Speaker and the Speaker's independence, and I certainly would not want to cast aspersions on the current Speaker or on any other, because I think it is improper to do that. Obviously, I would like to somehow see the word `relevant' defined. The Speakers keep throwing it back on the parliament to define it. Maybe it is a difficult thing, but the word has a literal meaning. My experience in the parliament is that, clearly, ministers are very often irrelevant, except in the absolutely broadest interpretation of what `relevance' actually means. That needs to be fixed, and I challenge the government to define what is relevant.

I know the Procedure Committee has considered in the past whether time limits ought to be applied, and that is another thing that has been done in the Senate. I understand the pros and cons of that; but, on balance, I would probably come down on the side of having time limits applied to answers—and, indeed, to questions, if one wanted to be even-handed. Obviously, there needs to be more time for the answer than for the question. I would very much like to see question time work better. I understand that it has a volatile atmosphere, and that is good. It is healthy, and it reflects the healthiness of our democracy, but it does not reflect very well on us.

Some of the displeasure about politicians is simply because of the fact that people watch question time on television, or they actually come here and watch. In that case, we know—because we all have the school groups tell us so—that they are quite aghast at what goes on in question time. I suspect that that is why the government will never sell its proposition—if we were to come to the point—that the election of a president should be left to the politicians. All the people I have spoken to, even my friends, say, `Listen, mate: the plain fact is that people will not trust you with that decision. They see the way you behave and they do not want you to be involved in the process.' If there is going to be a president, as the polls have told us, then people are going to want the right—

TALK.START.PARA: —So they have more of yesterday's performance.

—I do not know that. But the point I am making is that that only reflects a jaundiced view of us in our roles as members of parliament. I know there is a lot more to it than what happens in question time. It is a much bigger issue than that. What happens in question time is only a little bit of what happens here, and we try to explain that to people. But that is all that people see and it is all they think we really do—yell and yahoo—when we go into the parliament. I do not want to be tarred with that brush, because I like to take this role very seriously, participate in debates and really do the job. It is difficult. The process, in the end, is predetermined. You often feel, when you go into the parliament to make a speech, that you are wasting your time—in opposition, anyway, because you are not going to change the government's mind. I think you very rarely do—
—That is not true—you can.

—In theory you can, but I have not seen it happen very often even when we come in and make passionate speeches. The reason is that, no matter how much there might be members of the Labor government who agree with us, they will not express a view. They simply do what they are told. At least we on this side have a limited amount—

—Well, you do. We on this side do have a little amount of flexibility, because I have done it. In fact, I was the whip in this Committee until I did it and then I had to resign that position. But I did not have to resign from the Liberal Party.
—That was your mistake.

—That is where the members opposite would be caught out because I know, from talking to my colleagues in the Labor Party, and a number of them have become friends, that they often agree with the things we say in debate—until it comes to the vote. The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) is the most outstanding. I do not class him necessarily as one of my friends, incidentally. But I ought to say that he is one who very often comes in and speaks against the government—
—He's still in the party.

—That is because he has never voted with us. He speaks against the government, he speaks along the same lines as us in relation to some issue. When it comes to the vote, he is not there. But he never comes in and votes with us.
—That is not true.
—Well, in the six years that the member for Banks and I have been here, he has not voted.
—He did on the gold tax.

—That was before my time and it was before your time too, but the member for Charlton was here. In relation to questions, the rostering of ministers has been a sore point and I am pleased the committee has actually addressed that to improve it, in the opposition's view, to some extent. I am not sure what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has said directly, other than that that he, as Prime Minister, would attend every question time. I think that is absolutely proper and I am sure that with the change of government that would occur.

PARA.TAB: If the Prime Minister does not set an example in making this institution important, nobody else is going to. You have to lead in that regard. The Prime Minister of the country should be in the parliament often. I know he has a million other things to do and we do not expect him to be sitting there all day, but certainly in question time he should—

TALK.START.PARA: —He should be here listening to you.

—Maybe he is listening to me. I know that Mr Howard has said that he, as Prime Minister, would be there when question time is on. We would want to have question time. There are occasions we argue in the parliament that question time could be knocked off. I can understand that, on the odd occasion where we have an extra sitting day or something. But the thing is that the Prime Minister needs to see question time as important. I am not sure how far we would go, but my own view would be that all ministers should be there every question time. I suspect that that is what we will do. But certainly the Prime Minister should be there every question time.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the operation of question time, I notice that the government is going to have another look at it. In other words, it has admitted that that is a much bigger issue. I see in paragraph 6.4.4 that consideration of that will be continued by preparing a discussion paper on possible options for change. I am pleased about that. As I said, I was the initial opposition whip here in this Main Committee, prior to my unfortunate demise.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did a very good job.

—I did a good job because I cooperated with the deputy speaker and, although there was some reluctance on our side to acknowledge that it was going to work, I embraced it enthusiastically because it was a job I was given to do.
—If you had a caucus battle on the position, you might still be in it.

—I probably would not. In the end, I took the view that the Main Committee would work. I did my best to make it work, and, with your chief whip, we have made it work. It works. There are some physical problems—such as access to the public—which have been addressed by the committee, and there are a few procedural problems. However, as I said, the Main Committee does work and it has achieved its objective of allowing debate on reports that may never have got back into the parliament because of the pressure of other business. The concept of the Main Committee dealing with uncontroversial matters is a bit over the top because everything is controversial in this place if you want to make it controversial. By nature, if it is before the parliament there is an element of controversy about it. That aspect has not worried us too much, and the more informal atmosphere in the Main Committee has made it a very—
—You can see the whites of their eyes.
—Exactly. Interchanges in the Main Committee become more enjoyable than sometimes occurs in the chasm of the House of Representatives where honourable members seem lost in the huge chamber.
—We should have a smaller chamber in the House.

—The old chamber had a smaller chamber, as I understand it, but the new one has not. I am happy with the new working hours. I was sceptical about them, but I can now see the benefits to be gained in spreading the hours out, starting in February, and so on. I support these recommendations. I was sceptical about finishing early at night, but I can now see that the earlier finishing time is conducive for those of us who attend the gym. It is much better to go into the gym at 7 a.m. after having slept all night than to go into the gym after staying in this place until 2 o'clock in the morning.
—Much more civilised.
—It is much more civilised.

—In speaking to the report of the Procedure Committee, there are a number of points to touch on. Members need to bear in mind that, as with the first report, this report is a package which we are presenting to the parliament. Some members of the committee have different views from the views expressed in some of the recommendations, but it is give and take. We cannot all have what we want, and this is the problem in relation to hours of sitting and a few other things that I want to speak about.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the creation of the Main Committee, the universal view is that the Main Committee is a success. The Main Committee has a different atmosphere from the main chamber, but a lot of constructive work takes place there. The Main Committee is an unqualified success. The sceptics are proved wrong. The Main Committee is one of the beneficial changes that came into being.

The other beneficial change is standing committees. The House of Representatives committee system provides backbenchers with a meaningful role in the parliament and this situation is as a result of the goodwill between the government and the opposition members on the committees and because these committees operate a little bit differently. Many of the reports which are brought back to the parliament are unanimous reports, and that aspect helps. As Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I am in a position to know that that committee has received the bulk of references in terms of advisory reports. If success can be measured in terms of the government picking up recommendations, the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has achieved a substantial success rate.

There have been some controversial pieces of legislation referred to the committee, and the way the legislation has been dealt with is a credit to the cooperation of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams), the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) and the other members of the committee. Proper resourcing of the secretariat and secondment of officers from the department to assist in specialist reports are the keys to the success of the committee.

In the House of Representatives, where the government has the numbers, honourable members have seen the government take up substantial recommendations. This situation has resulted in alterations which enrich the legislation which originates in the House of Representatives. The area of House of Representatives committees is an area in which backbench members of the government and the opposition can play a constructive and positive role in terms of influencing legislation.

That is where I differ from the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) who just rose to speak. Government members in standing committees can express quite differing views from the government's position in terms of the introduction of legislation and achieve success.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have.

—They can and they have, and the government has accepted it. The culture has changed in terms of the operation of those standing committees in the short time that they have been taking place: they are seen as allowing the participation of members of parliament in the process; they also allow the parliament to bring experts and practitioners in the various fields before it, so that it really is a democratic process.

PARA.TAB: We need government and opposition members to resist the push by the Executive for urgent consideration of this legislation. My view has always been that if the legislation that has been introduced by the Executive into the parliament is so crash hot it will withstand scrutiny by members of the parliament and by members of the public.

In some instances there will be policy differences, and that is when a number of the recommendations may not be taken up. But in the short time that the committees have been operating the parliament has received reports that not only withstand scrutiny but are gaining international recognition. The reports of the legal committee on the child sex tourism bill and the war crimes bill, as I understand it, have been considered model reports, and members of the parliament in New Zealand and other parliaments are using them as a basis of legislation in those countries. I think that says something about the potential for the operation of those committees.

One of the underutilised areas of the committees is our ability—and it is pointed out on page 18 of this report—pursuant to the standing orders, to examine annual reports of government departments. Parliamentary committees, particularly in the House, need to do that a bit more often because that is another useful mechanism for suggesting change to the Executive. There is nothing wrong with reviewing an annual report of the director of public prosecutions or the ombudsman, for instance, by bringing them before the committee and going through how the legislation might currently be working. The committees could bring forward reports to the Executive suggesting areas of change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far from there being nothing wrong with it, it is desirable.

—It is absolutely desirable, but in the end the onus falls on us. That is, a backbench member of parliament on either side can make a substantial contribution. It is an aspect that does not get publicity because it is not one where we are at one another's throats. So I think that—
—There's a great deal of harmony.

—There is harmony. Friendships are forged across the parliament, and in my five and a bit years here I have found the committee work most enjoyable. It is nice to have one's fingerprints over pieces of legislation and legislative change.

PARA.TAB: On the matter of rostering, there is a comment in this report that there has been criticism of the present roster system. Opposition members of the committee expressed a strong view that the roster should be abandoned, that is, in relation to the roster of ministers for question time. The truth is that there are members of the government who are not well disposed to the rostering system. It is a matter of public record that I was one in caucus who felt that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should be at question time every day. I expressed that view because I believe that he is a master in that forum; that he is the equivalent of what Bradman was to cricket when it comes to question time in the parliament; and that it was absurd to select someone like Bradman in a side as captain and then say that because of his outstanding performances and to even up the score he had better go and sign a few signatures out in the paddock and be used for only part of the time. That is my particular view.

What members need to understand, and members of the public as well, is that in politics as in everything else it is the majority view that prevails. The overwhelming view on our side of the parliament is that the roster system has proved beneficial. I think what has happened is that the members of the opposition, quite frankly, have not taken the benefits that they should from the roster. They still need to learn a little about tactics and how to launch an offensive, and this rhetoric about `Yes, we want the Prime Minister back in question time every day'—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they don't.

—The truth is they do not. They say that but, deep down, they know that it is a disadvantage, from this government's point of view, when he is not there because of his total dominance. Frankly, I like him in question time because I think that it shows how he is so dominant and why he is the best person in that position, at this point of time, that this country has to offer and that this parliament has to offer. We only have to look at the galleries at question time—both the public gallery and the press gallery—because when the Prime Minister is not there the galleries are empty. When he is there they are all there, they are all filled. It is an electric atmosphere, it is a charged atmosphere. But that is one where I do not have the numbers. We will still work on it, though.

PARA.TAB: The operation of the sin-bin is on page 28 of this report. Question time is theatre, and we are all guilty of participating. I suppose the truth is that, in terms of government members, I would probably be one of the more culpable ones in terms of the interchange and in being quite vociferous from the backbench, because I do not believe in sitting idle on the backbench when the members of the opposition are in the fray. There is only one way: we have got to give it back to them.

If we are fair dinkum in terms of the operation of the sin-bin and if it is what we want—total decorum and total silence when a question is asked or when a minister is answering a question or when the Prime Minister is answering a question—then I say to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker that they should exercise the sin-bin a lot more harshly and a lot more often than they do. I think that if there were two or three days in succession where the Speaker or Deputy Speaker, whichever is in charge, threw out three or four government members and three or four opposition members—quite frankly, under the present standing orders that is possible, and I would say that I would probably be the first government member to be thrown out, because I have been given a bit of leniency—then we would get a question time where we could hear a pin drop.

But is that what we really want? The truth is that in our heart of hearts most of us do not. I find question time the most engaging and enjoyable part of the operation of the parliament and it is the most electric when the Prime Minister is there. I am not saying that as one who is one of the mates of the Prime Minister—my views are well known in relation to that. It is a balance. So let us not get on with the humbug. I think the power is there. I actually enjoy the interchange between government and opposition members, but I do believe that there are times when that power should be exercised a bit more. I think that the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker have shown enormous tolerance to us as members of the parliament.

The other matter, which I will finish with, concerns the hours of sitting. It is well known that, in relation to the sitting hours, I was one of the main architects in the initial report of what has been adopted and is known as the 8 o'clock rule. Frankly, I will defend that until the very end because I think it has enabled us, as members of parliament on both sides will acknowledge, to lead a decent existence in terms of hours. We are not having the situation where we are all walking around this place as zombies late at night. From the point of view of health and quality of debate, and from the support staff's point of view, we have more civilised hours. I am one who will strongly resist the breaking of the 8 o'clock rule.

I acknowledge that at the end of a session and towards the end of the day we might have to break the 8 o'clock rule or whatever because of the recalcitrant nature of the Senate and the fact that we generally have to wait in relation to it. I think the 8 o'clock rule has been a tremendous success and we should resist any attempt to extend hours on a Monday night, a Tuesday night or a Wednesday night just because we are here. With those comments, I commend the chair in what was a substantial input into this report. He has done a marvellous job. I thank all those members of the committee who hold the parliament dear, as I do. We are very fortunate to have the parliament that we have and the democracy that we have in this country.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—I indicate to the honourable member for Banks that I have taken on board his comments. I will digest them and see what I might consider about them. I accept his offer.
Debate (on motion by Mr Snowdon) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 6 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that funding for the Murray Darling Freshwater Research Centre of $394 000 per annum from the Albury Wodonga Development Corporation will cease on 30 June 1996; and if so why.
(2) Will the Government meet the Centre's funding requirements after 30 June 1996; if so how.
(3) What action is the government taking to avoid the Centre experiencing a funding crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Albury Wodonga Ministerial Council decided on 27 August 1993 to provide the Murray Darling Freshwater Research Centre with funding from the Albury Wodonga Development Corporation (AWDC) until 30 June 1996. However, continued funding beyond this point was considered inappropriate.
The reasons for the decision included:
the AWDC's revised operational arrangements made the funding arrangements inappropriate;
the level of funding provided was out of scale with the AWDC's community services responsibilities;
under the current diverse funding mechanisms, Parliaments would not have access to a complete picture of the resources devoted to this project.

(2) The Centre receives funding through a number of agencies including the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, the CSIRO, the Cooperative Research Centre Program, and the Water Resources Research and Development Organisation.
Future funding support for the Centre will be determined by these organisations/programs according to their budgetary circumstances and objectives.
(3) The AWDC advised the Centre in 1993 that AWDC funding would only be provided until 30 June 1996.
It is up to the Centre to respond appropriately.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many persons have qualified for the Extreme Disablement Adjustment (EDA) since it was introduced.
(2) How many unsuccessful applicants for EDA received lifestyle ratings of (a) 4 and (b) 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since the Extreme Disablement Adjustment was introduced with effect from 22 December 1988, 7520 veterans have qualified for this rate of disability pension. 3936 of these have since died.
(2) Veterans do not have to specifically apply for EDA and there is no special application form.
Eligibility for EDA is automatically considered when Disability Pension is being assessed following a new claim for a disability pension or application for increase in pension, and the veteran is:
assessed at 100% of the General Rate of disability pension,
aged 65 years or over, and
does not qualify for the Intermediate Rate or Special Rate of disability pension.

To be granted EDA a veteran who meets this initial criteria must also be assessed under the Guide to Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions having a Lifestyle Rating of at least 6 and an impairment rating of at least 70 points.

Precise information is not available on veterans considered for EDA. It is known that of those living veterans of all ages assessed at 100% and rated at 70 impairment points since 22 December 1988 some 700 had a lifestyle rating of 4 and some 500 had a lifestyle rating of 5.
